questions.text: (1-3)-B-D glucan assay cannot be used in? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Invasive cryptococcosis

 

(1-3) - B - D glucan assay is used for diagnosis of candida infections, invasive aspergillosis and Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia.

 

It is not useful in case of invasive cryptococcosis and mucor.

 

Cryptococcus species, the causative agents of invasive cryptococcosis, primarily produce glucuronoxylomannan as the major component of their capsule, not (1-3)-β-D-glucan. Therefore, the (1-3)-β-D-glucan assay is not useful for diagnosing invasive cryptococcosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Invasive aspergillosis: Aspergillus species produce (1-3)-β-D-glucan, and the assay is useful for diagnosing invasive aspergillosis.

 

Option C. Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia: Pneumocystis jiroveci produces (1-3)-β-D-glucan, making the assay useful for diagnosing PCP.

 

Option D. Invasive candidiasis and candidemia: Candida species produce (1-3)-β-D-glucan, so the assay is useful for diagnosing these infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The (1-3)-β-D-glucan assay is not useful for diagnosing invasive cryptococcosis as it does not detect the major components of the Cryptococcus capsule.

questions.text: A primigravida came to the labor room at 40 weeks + 5 days gestation for induction of labor. On per vaginal examination, the cervix is less then 1 cm dilated and length is 3 cm. The vertex is at -2 station and the cervix is soft and anterior. What will be the bishop score for this lady? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5

 

Explanation:

 

The Bishop's score, in this case, is 5.

 

  • This is a scoring system used to assess the favorability of the cervix to respond to induction of labor.
  • A cervix that is soft in consistency, a little dilated, short in length, anteriorly placed and the station of the presenting low down will respond well to induction of labor.
  • The Bishop score was replaced by the Modified Bishop score, wherein, the cervical effacement (in terms of percentage) was replaced by cervical length (in cm).
  • The 5 components of the Modified Bishop score are:

 

 

 

  • The scoring is as shown in the table.
  • Each component is scored from 0 to 3
  • The highest score is 13 and the lowest is 0
  • A favourable score is > 6. This means the patient will respond favorably to methods of induction of labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bishop score is used to evaluate the readiness of the cervix for induction of labor. A score of 6 or more suggests that the cervix is favorable for induction.

 

Ref: Page no 600, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Identify the refractive error: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myopia

 

As a result of parallel rays being focused in front of the retina in the image above, myopia is indicated as the refractive error.

 

Myopia, also referred to as "short sight," is a dioptric condition of the eye in which incident parallel rays focus anterior to the light-sensitive layer of the retina while accommodation is at rest.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Presbyopia: It is an age-related condition characterized by a gradual loss of the eyes' ability to focus on nearby objects, due to the hardening of the lens inside the eye.

 

Option C. Hypermetropia: Also known as farsightedness, in this condition, light rays entering the eye focus behind the retina. Individuals with hypermetropia see distant objects more clearly than close ones.

 

 

 

Option D. Astigmatism: This refractive error occurs due to an irregular curvature of the cornea or lens, which causes light to be focused at multiple points in front of, on, or behind the retina, leading to blurred or distorted vision at all distances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myopia results from the focusing of light in front of the retina, making distant objects appear blurry, a condition often corrected with concave lenses.

questions.text: A 30 month old male child was brought with history of fever, and respiratory distress. Suspecting pneumonia , a chest xray was ordered. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent ? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Staphylococcus pneumoniae

 

Chest xray of child shows air filled cysts within lung parenchyma which are also known as pneumatoceles, and these are caused by staphylococcus pneumoniae.

 

Staphylococcus pneumoniae can cause primary or secondary pneumoniae (eg post influenza)

 

Clinical features – dyspnea, tachycardia, high fever, abdominal pain.

 

Staphylococcus aureus is also associated with complications like early development of empyema , pneumatocele , pyopneumothorax and bronchopleural fistula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Klebsiella pneumoniae: While this organism can cause pneumonia, it is more commonly associated with pneumonia in adults with a characteristic "currant jelly" sputum and does not typically lead to pneumatocele formation.

 

Option B. Streptococcus pneumoniae: This is a common cause of bacterial pneumonia but typically does not cause pneumatoceles. It usually presents with lobar consolidation.

 

Option C. Mycoplasma pneumoniae: Often causes atypical pneumonia in older children and young adults, characterized by a more gradual onset of symptoms and a less severe clinical picture compared to bacterial pneumonia. Pneumatoceles are not a common feature.

 

Educational Objective:


Staphylococcus aureus can cause severe pneumonia in children, often complicated by the formation of pneumatoceles and other serious complications such as empyema and bronchopleural fistula.

questions.text: Which of the following features of stroke need not be treated? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neglect

 

Neglect after a stroke, often presenting as a lack of awareness of one side of the body, does not typically require direct medical treatment. While it may indicate a more severe stroke and can impact rehabilitation, many patients improve as they recover from other stroke symptoms. Therapy focuses on aiding patients in adapting to or compensating for this deficit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dysphagia: Must be treated to prevent complications like aspiration pneumonia.

 

Option B. Spasticity: Requires management with medications (baclofen, tizanidine) or physical therapy to improve mobility and reduce discomfort.

 

Option C. Fever: Should be treated promptly as it can exacerbate brain injury and worsen outcomes in stroke patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While neglect is a common symptom following a stroke, it does not typically require specific medical treatment but rather supportive care and rehabilitation to help the patient adapt. Other physical symptoms such as dysphagia, spasticity, and fever require active medical management to prevent complications.

questions.text: Which of the following anti rheumatoid drug increases extracellular adenosine? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Methotrexate

 

Methotrexate works primarily by inhibiting AICAR transformylase and thymidylate synthetase.

 

AICAR accumulates intracellularly and competes with AMP deaminase, resulting in AMP accumulation. AMP is released and converted extracellularly to adenosine, which is acts as the powerful anti-inflammatory agent. As a result, neutrophils, macrophages, dendritic cells, and lymphocytes' inflammatory functions are suppressed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leflunomide: Leflunomide inhibits dihydroorotate dehydrogenase, which is involved in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidines, thereby suppressing the proliferation of activated lymphocytes. It does not increase extracellular adenosine.

 

Option C. Sulphasalazine: Sulphasalazine is a prodrug that is metabolized into sulfapyridine and 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA). Its anti-inflammatory effects are primarily due to the action of 5-ASA. It does not increase extracellular adenosine.

 

Option D. Hydroxychloroquine: Hydroxychloroquine is thought to exert its anti-inflammatory effects by interfering with lysosomal activity and autophagy in immune cells, and by modulating the activity of toll-like receptors (TLRs). It does not increase extracellular adenosine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate increases extracellular adenosine by inhibiting AICAR transformylase, leading to the accumulation of AICAR, which competes with AMP deaminase and causes AMP to accumulate and be converted to adenosine outside the cell, thus exerting anti-inflammatory effects.

questions.text: Which of the following staphylococcal infections is not toxin mediated? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Septicemia

 

Staphylococcal septicemia is not toxin mediated. It occurs due to the invasion of bacterial organisms into the bloodstream causing an inflammatory response to bacterial products, leading to various manifestations seen in sepsis.

 

Toxin mediated staphylococcal infections are:

 

  • Food poisoning - caused by enterotoxin
  • Toxic shock syndrome- caused by toxic shock syndrome toxin
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome- caused by exfoliative/epidermolytic toxin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Food poisoning: Caused by the ingestion of preformed enterotoxins in contaminated food.

 

Option B. Toxic shock syndrome: Caused by the release of TSST-1 and other superantigens leading to severe systemic symptoms.

 

Option D. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome: Caused by exfoliative toxins leading to the destruction of the skin's epidermal layer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Staphylococcal septicemia is not mediated by toxins, unlike staphylococcal food poisoning, toxic shock syndrome, and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, which are all toxin-mediated infections.

questions.text: Pancreatic cancer has the highest association with: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Peutz Jegher’s syndrome

 

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) is significantly associated with an increased risk of pancreatic cancer. PJS is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by the development of benign polyps in the gastrointestinal tract and distinctive pigmented spots on the skin. It is caused by mutations in the STK11 (LKB1) gene. Individuals with PJS have a markedly increased risk of developing several types of cancer, including a 36% lifetime risk of developing pancreatic cancer, which is considerably higher compared to the general population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FAMMM Syndrome: While FAMMM (familial atypical multiple mole melanoma) syndrome, associated with mutations in the p16/CDKN2A gene, increases the risk for melanoma and pancreatic cancer, its association with pancreatic cancer is not as strong as that seen in PJS.

 

Option B. FAP (Familial Adenomatous Polyposis): FAP, primarily known for its high risk of colorectal cancer, also has some association with other cancers including pancreatic cancer, but again not as high as PJS.

 

Option C. Hereditary pancreatitis: Typically caused by mutations in the PRSS1 gene, hereditary pancreatitis does increase the risk for pancreatic cancer, but the risk is less compared to PJS.


Educational Objective:

 

Pancreatic cancer has highest association with Peutz Jeghers syndrome.

 

Hereditary risk factors -

 

  • Peutz Jeghers syndrome- STK 11 (LKB1)
  • Hereditary pancreatitis – PRSS1 / SPIN 11
  • Cystic fibrosis – CFTR
  • FAMMM (familial atypical multiple mole melanoma)- p16/ CDKN2A
  • Hereditary breast &ovarian cancer- BRCA2
  • HNPCC/ Lynch syndrome – MLH1, MSH2, MSH 6, PMS2

choices.text: It is the main restraint in posterior drawer test
It is an extrasynovial structure
It is the main restraint to internal rotation
It originates from anterolateral aspect of medial femoral condyle in the area of intercondylar notch

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about PCL? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is the main restraint to internal rotation

 

LIGAMENT INJURIES OF THE KNEE JOINT

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PCL is the an extrasynovial structure originating from the anterolateral aspect of the medial femoral condyle in the area of intercondylar notch.
  • It is the main restraint to the posterior translation of the knee i.e., the backward gliding of the tibia over the femur.
  • While evaluating the patient during physical examination, PCL is the main restraint in the posterior drawer test.

questions.text:
The diagnosis for a 23-year-old patient presenting with non-scarring alopecia in the vertex region of the head, and exhibiting histological findings of hair loss with haemorrhage into the follicular areas and mild perinuclear lymphocytic infiltrate, is what? 
(AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trichotillomania

 

From the given clinical features & histopathological features, diagnosis is Trichotillomania (TTM) / Trichotillosis / Hair pulling disorder.

 

Clinical features suggestive of Trichotillomania in the clinical vignette:

 

  • The clinical history revealing non scarring alopecia in the vertex region (Hair pulling and plucking is commonest from the scalp)
  • No signs of inflammation
  • Perifollicular hemorrhage

 

Diagnostic criteria for TTM include:

 

  • Recurrent pulling out of one’s own hair resulting in non-scarring hair loss.
  • An increasing sense of tension immediately before pulling out the hair or when attempting to resist the behaviour.
  • Pleasure, gratification, or relief when pulling out the hair.
  • The disturbance is not better accounted for by another mental disorder.
  • The disturbance provokes clinically marked distress and/or impairment in occupational, social, or other areas of functioning.
  • Histopathology: No / Minimal inflammation
  • Peribulbar hemorrhage - due to trauma from plucking of hair.
  • intraepithelial and perifollicular hemorrhage and intrafollicular pigment casts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alopecia areata:

 

  • While it is characterized by non-scarring alopecia and can have lymphocytic infiltrate around the hair follicles, the hemorrhage is not a typical feature.
  • Generally presents as well-defined patches of hair loss.

 

Option B. Telogen effluvium:

 

  • It manifests as a diffuse or generalized hair shedding from the entire scalp rather than localized patches.
  • It's commonly due to stress, certain medications, or illnesses.
  • Histopathology would not typically show hemorrhage or the specific perinuclear infiltrate described.

 

Option C. Tinea infection:

 

  • Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp.
  • It usually presents with scaling and possibly broken-off hairs.
  • Histological examination would show evidence of fungal elements (hyphae and spores) rather than hemorrhage or lymphocytic infiltrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a young patient with non-scarring alopecia in the vertex region and histological findings of hair loss with follicular hemorrhage and mild lymphocytic infiltrate, the diagnosis is likely Trichotillomania.

 

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 86 & 89, page nos 86.17 & 89.31

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page no: 1695

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman underwent a workup for primary infertility. On hysterosalpingography, there was a bilateral cornual block. What is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hysteroscopy and laparoscopy-guided surgery

 

Cornual block, also known as proximal tubal obstruction, can be effectively managed with proximal tubal catheterization and cannulation, typically guided by hysteroscopy and laparoscopy. This method has about an 85% success rate in restoring tubal patency, making it the next logical step in management for a woman with a bilateral cornual block.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Cornual Block: Proximal tubal obstructions often require intervention to restore patency.
  • Hysteroscopy and Laparoscopy: These procedures allow for precise catheterization and cannulation to open the blocked tubes, leading to a high success rate.
  • Success Rate: Approximately 85% success in restoring tubal patency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuboplasty: While tuboplasty is an option for distal tubal occlusion, it is not the first-line treatment for cornual block.

 

Option C. Hydrotubation: This procedure involves flushing the tubes with fluid but is less effective for treating cornual block compared to hysteroscopy and laparoscopy-guided surgery. Success rates are poor (15-30 %)

 

Option D. In-vitro fertilization: IVF is typically considered when surgical interventions fail or are not suitable, particularly in women over 35 or those with severe tubal damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cornual block in a young woman with primary infertility should be managed with hysteroscopy and laparoscopy-guided proximal tubal catheterization and cannulation to restore tubal patency before considering more invasive options like IVF.

 

Ref: Page 1158, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company has developed a novel diagnostic test for a rare metabolic disorder. In clinical trials, the test demonstrated a sensitivity of 0.90 and a specificity of 0.80. In a population where the prevalence of the disease is 30%, the test was applied to every participant. What is the probability that a person who tests negative truly does not have the disease? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 95%

 

  • It’s the Negative Predictive Value (NPV), which tells us the probability that a person with a negative test result truly doesn't have the disease.

 NPV = TN / (TN + FN)

  • Use a hypothetical cohort of 1000 people for easy calculation.

 

Given:

 

  • Disease prevalence = 30% = 300 people with the disease and 700 without the disease out of 1000.
  • Sensitivity = 0.90, so TP = 0.90 * 300 = 270 and FN = 300 - 270 = 30.
  • Specificity = 0.80, so TN = 0.80 * 700 = 560 and FP = 700 - 560 = 140.

 

Using the above formula:

 

NPV = 560 / (560 + 30) = 560 / 590 = 0.9491 or approximately 95%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Negative Predictive Value (NPV) represents the probability that a person with a negative test result truly does not have the disease

questions.text: The flap shown in the picture is? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Serratus anterior flap

 

The given image shows a serratus anterior flap. The serratus anterior flap is a highly reliable flap which has a consistently long pedicle. Its anatomy allows coverage of complex wounds. The underlying rib can be included as a myoosseous flap to expand the versatility of this flap.

 

  • The serratus anterior flap is a reconstructive surgical technique that uses the serratus anterior muscle, which is located between the ribs and scapula.
  • This flap is often used for chest wall reconstruction and breast reconstruction procedures.
  • It provides good vascularization and can be used to cover defects in the chest and axillary regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pectoral Myo-cutaneous Flap: The pectoral myo-cutaneous flap is a surgical technique that utilizes tissue from the pectoral muscle and overlying skin.

 

  • It is commonly used in reconstruction after resection of oral malignancies.
  • This flap can provide a good blood supply and a natural appearance.

 

Option C. TRAM Flap (Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous Flap): The TRAM flap is a reconstructive technique that uses tissue from the lower abdominal wall, including the rectus abdominis muscle and overlying skin.

 

  • It is often employed in breast reconstruction, providing a large amount of tissue.
  • There are two types: pedicled TRAM flap (retains its blood supply through the rectus muscle) and free TRAM flap (microvascular reconstruction).

 

Option D. VRAM Flap (Vertical Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous Flap): The VRAM flap is similar to the TRAM flap but uses tissue from the vertical orientation of the rectus abdominis muscle.

 

  • It is also used in breast reconstruction and abdominal wall reconstruction.
  • Like the TRAM flap, it can be pedicled or free, depending on the surgical technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Flap surgery is a type of plastic surgery that uses tissues from another part of the body to close open wounds while having its own blood supply.
  • The site from which the tissue is obtained is called the donor site, while the site where the tissue is transferred is called the recipient site. Flaps may be of soft tissue, skin, muscle, bone, fat or fascia.

choices.text: Total Thyroidectomy plus Lymph node dissection

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman came with a history of thyroid swelling. FNAC was done and the report was suggestive of papillary carcinoma thyroid. The nodule was "cold" on scan. Which of the following will not be a treatment option for her? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radioiodine ablation of thyroid

 

Radioiodine ablation is typically used after thyroidectomy to eliminate any remaining thyroid tissue and residual cancer cells. However, it is contraindicated during pregnancy due to the risk of harm to the developing fetus from radiation exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total Thyroidectomy: This option involves the complete removal of the thyroid gland and is a standard treatment for papillary thyroid carcinoma. However, the timing of the surgery during pregnancy should be carefully considered in consultation with an experienced healthcare team.

 

Option B. Total Thyroidectomy plus Lymph Node Dissection: In cases where there is evidence of lymph node involvement or a high risk of lymph node metastasis, total thyroidectomy with lymph node dissection may be recommended to remove affected lymph nodes in the neck. Again, the timing and extent of surgery should be carefully evaluated during pregnancy.

 

Option D. Right Hemithyroidectomy: Right hemithyroidectomy involves the removal of one lobe (half) of the thyroid gland. This procedure is considered when there is a single, localized thyroid nodule or cancer confined to one side of the thyroid gland. However, for papillary carcinoma thyroid, total thyroidectomy is often preferred to ensure complete removal of the cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radioiodine ablation of thyroid is contraindicated in pregnant women due to risk of radiation exposure to the fetus.

 

Therapeutic uses for Radioactive lodine

 

  1. In primary thyrotoxicosis after the age of 45 years.
  2. In autonomous toxic nodule after 45 years, it is useful as remaining gland will still function adequately after radiotherapy.
  3. In papillary/follicular carcinoma of thyroid, after total thyroidectomy, if there are secondaries elsewhere in the body, as in bones or lungs, then I 131 is given.

questions.text: Which of the following Immunohistochemistry marker is used in Cyclin D1 negative Mantle cell lymphoma? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SOX11

 

Mantle cell lymphoma is an uncommon lymphoid neoplasm that makes up about 2.5% of NHL.

 

The tumor cells closely resemble the normal mantle zone B cells that surround germinal centers.

 

Typically, the proliferation consists of a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply clefted (cleaved) nuclear contours.

 

Immunohistochemistry - Mantle cell lymphomas express high levels of cyclin D1. Most tumors are also express CD19, CD20, and moderately high levels of surface Ig (usually IgM and IgD with κ or γ light chain). It is usually CD5+ and CD23-, which helps to distinguish it from CLL/SLL. The IgH genes lack somatic hypermutation, supporting an origin from a naive B cell.

 

Cyclin D1 (CCND1) protein overexpression and/or the t(11;14) (q13;q32) translocation are the pathognomonic hallmarks of mantle cell lymphoma (MCL). SOX11 expression serves as a specific biomarker in cases lacking both t (11;14) and cyclin D1 protein but having a gene expression profile suggestive of MCL. SOX11 expression is associated with bad prognosis in mantle cell lymphoma.

 

  • MYD88: Associated with Waldenström macroglobulinemia.
  • Annexin V: Generally used in apoptosis studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DDs of NHL: -

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of inability to move his 4th and 5th digit, cannot hold a pen and he was not able to hold a paper between fingers. Which of the following sites given below is the probable cause of injury to the nerve in question? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 7

 

The given clinical scenario of a patient complaining of inability to move his 4th and 5th digit, not able to hold a pen and also not able to hold paper between fingers, all together suggests towards an ulnar nerve injury. The most likely site of injury would thus be medial epicondyle – structure marked as 7.

 

Given below is the labelling of the structures marked in the figure -

 

  1. Head
  2. Greater Tubercle
  3. Intertubercular Groove
  4. Deltoid Tuberosity
  5. Capitulum
  6. Trochlea
  7. Medial Epicondyle
  8. Olecranon Fossa
  9. Lateral Epicondyle
  10. Lesser Tubercle

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: Head of Humerus: This area is not typically associated with isolated ulnar nerve injuries. Injuries here affect the axillary nerve.

 

Option C. 9: Lateral Epicondyle: The lateral epicondyle is more commonly associated with injuries affecting the radial nerve or conditions like lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow).

 

Option D. 4: Deltoid Tuberosity: This site on the humerus is typically associated with the attachment of the deltoid muscle. Injuries or issues here would more likely affect the deltoid muscle or the radial nerve dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tests for ulnar nerve lesions are as follows:

 

1. Card Test: This isn't a widely recognized test in the context of ulnar nerve pathology. However, in some practices, the card test might refer to asking the patient to hold a card (like a credit card) between their thumb and the side of their index finger. Difficulty or inability to do this due to a weak adductor pollicis muscle (innervated by the ulnar nerve) may suggest ulnar nerve dysfunction.

 

2. Claw Hand Deformity: This is seen in ulnar nerve injuries. In a typical ulnar claw hand, the 4th and 5th digits (ring and little fingers) are hyperextended at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and flexed at the interphalangeal (IP) joints. This occurs due to the loss of function of the lumbricals and interossei of the hand, which are innervated by the ulnar nerve.

 

3. Froment's Sign: This is a classic sign of ulnar nerve palsy. The patient is asked to hold a piece of paper between their thumb and the side of their index finger (pinch grip). If the ulnar nerve is compromised, the patient will compensate by flexing the thumb's IP joint to maintain grip strength, which is a positive Froment's sign. This indicates weakness or paralysis of the adductor pollicis muscle.

 

4. Wartenberg Sign: In ulnar nerve injury, there's unopposed action of the extensor digiti minimi, which leads to abduction of the little finger. The patient will be unable to bring their little finger back to the side of the hand, leading to the "Wartenberg sign."

 

5. Palmaris Brevis Sign: This is a sign of ulnar nerve functionality. The palmaris brevis muscle is innervated by the ulnar nerve. Upon tapping or massaging the hypothenar eminence (palm side of the hand, base of the little finger), contraction of the palmaris brevis muscle can be observed as a twitching or dimpling. If present, it indicates that at least part of the ulnar nerve's function remains intact.

questions.text: Under anaerobic metabolism which of the following substrates yields 3 molecules of ATP? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glycogen

 

Breakdown of glycogen yields glucose-6-phosphate which can enter the glycolysis pathway bypassing the first step thus saving one ATP and producing 3 ATPs.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amino acid: Amino acids are not directly involved in anaerobic glycolysis and do not yield ATP through this pathway.

 

Option C. Glucose: The glycolysis of one glucose molecule under anaerobic conditions yields a net gain of 2 ATP molecules, not 3, because the initial phosphorylation step consumes one ATP.

 

Option D. Galactose: Galactose is converted to glucose-6-phosphate, but this conversion involves steps that consume ATP, resulting in a net gain similar to that of glucose, which is 2 ATP molecules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under anaerobic conditions, glycogen yields 3 molecules of ATP per glucose unit because it enters glycolysis as glucose-6-phosphate, bypassing the initial ATP-consuming step of glycolysis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of facial puffiness and frothy urine. Given below is the histological image of the condition. What do you think is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Membranous nephropathy

 

The image is characteristic of membranous nephropathy. The given hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained image shows uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall. (Intense pink color)

 

 

Membranous nephropathy is a common cause of the nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is characterized by diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall due to the accumulation of electron-dense, Ig-containing deposits along the subepithelial side of the basement membrane.

 

It is a form of chronic immune-complex-mediated disease.

 

Microscopy:

 

  • Light microscopy: The GBM is thickened without cellular proliferation.
  • Immunofluorescence microscopy: granular deposits containing lg and complement along the glomerular basement membrane
  • Electron micrograph: electron-dense subepithelial deposits (epimembranous spikes) and effacement of foot processes of podocytes

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): FSGS is characterized by segmental scarring of the glomeruli, which is not seen in the provided image. FSGS also typically presents with focal lesions rather than the diffuse thickening observed in membranous nephropathy.

 

Option C. Membranoproliferative nephritis: This condition is characterized by hypercellularity and a thickened, double-contoured glomerular basement membrane, often referred to as "tram-track" appearance, which is different from the thickened, smooth GBM seen in membranous nephropathy.

 

Option D. Dense deposit disease: Also known as Type II membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, this condition is marked by ribbon-like electron-dense deposits within the GBM, which is not consistent with the features of membranous nephropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Membranous nephropathy is characterized by uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall with subepithelial immune deposits, as evidenced by the histological image provided.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortans pathologic basis of disease, page no. 1766, 1767

questions.text: Atropine is indicated in all of the following poisonings except? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Endrin

 

Atropine is an anticholinergic agent used to counteract the effects of excessive acetylcholine, such as those seen in organophosphate and carbamate poisoning. It works by blocking the action of acetylcholine on muscarinic receptors, thereby alleviating symptoms of excessive cholinergic activity like salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, gastrointestinal distress, and emesis (SLUDGE syndrome).
 

  • Endrin is an organochloride pesticide, primarily causing neurotoxic effects, including seizures. The mechanism of toxicity involves disruption of the central nervous system rather than the cholinergic system. Therefore, atropine is not effective in managing Endrin poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Baygon: Atropine is indicated as it counters the acetylcholine accumulation due to acetylcholinesterase inhibition caused by organophosphates/carbamates in Baygon.

 

Option B. TIK 20: As an organophosphate, TIK 20 poisoning results in excessive acetylcholine, where atropine is beneficial.

 

Option C. Parathion: Parathion is an organophosphate pesticide causing acetylcholinesterase inhibition, making atropine an effective treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endrin is an organochloride pesticide. It leads to neurotoxicity, and in that case, Atropine cannot be used in the treatment. Parathion and TIK20 are organophosphates and baygon is a combination of organophosphate and carbamate. For all of these poisonings, atropine is the mainstay of management.

questions.text: Black foot is seen in which poisoning: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Arsenic

 

Blackfoot disease is an endemic peripheral vascular disease found among the inhabitants of a limited area on the southwest coast of Taiwan, where well water with a high concentration of arsenic causes peripheral vascular disease resulting in gangrene.

 

Other options are incorrect as the term Blackfoot disease is used only for arsenic

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Arsenic, cadmium, lead and mercury are the heavy metals which can cause peripheral vascular disease due to chronic poisoning. This leads to general clinical features of peripheral vascular disease (numbness in feet, rest pain etc.).
  • Blackfoot disease is a unique term given to peripheral vascular disease produced by chronic Arsenic poisoning. The name "Blackfoot" refers to the characteristic darkening and gangrene of the feet and lower legs. This ultimately leads to amputation.
  • In peripheral vascular disease caused by other heavy metals, gangrene is not a common manifestation

 

  • Above picture shows Blackfoot disease:

choices.text: Excretion in saliva
Excretion in urine
Large volume of distribution
Small volume of distribution

questions.text: Which of the following suggests storage of drugs in tissue (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Large volume of distribution

 

Large volume of distribution suggests storage of drugs in tissue. The volume of distribution (Vd) is a pharmacokinetic parameter that reflects the extent of drug distribution throughout the body. A large Vd indicates that a drug is extensively distributed throughout the tissues, including organs and fluids. This suggests that the drug is likely to be stored in the tissues and may have a long half-life. In contrast, a small Vd indicates that the drug is primarily confined to the bloodstream and has limited distribution to the tissues. Excretion in saliva or urine does not necessarily suggest storage of drugs in tissues, and the volume of distribution is not directly related to excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excretion in saliva: Excretion in saliva does not provide direct information about the extent of drug distribution or storage in tissues. It is more related to the route of elimination.

 

Option B. Excretion in urine: Excretion in urine indicates renal elimination of the drug or its metabolites. It provides information about the drug's elimination route but not about its distribution or storage in tissues.

 

Option D. Small volume of distribution: A small Vd indicates that the drug is largely confined to the bloodstream and has limited distribution to the tissues. This means the drug is not significantly stored in the tissues and is more likely to be readily available in the blood for excretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A large volume of distribution (Vd) suggests that a drug is extensively distributed and stored in the body's tissues, which can result in a prolonged half-life and slower elimination from the body.

questions.text: A young male patient has been on 5 mg haloperidol for several days. However, he has been experiencing inner restlessness and a strong want to move for the past four days. The most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Akathisia

 

The patient is presenting with inner restlessness and a compelling desire to be in constant motion, which is consistent with akathisia. This is a common extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotic medications like haloperidol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tardive dyskinesia: Tardive dyskinesia is a late-onset extrapyramidal side effect that can present as involuntary, repetitive movements of the tongue (e.g., twisting, protrusion), jaw (e.g., chewing also called. 

 

Option C. Rabbit syndrome: Rabbit syndrome lips (e.g., smacking, puckering), trunk and extremities.

 

Option D. Acute dystonia: Acute dystonia is the earliest side effect of antipsychotic and is characterized by sudden onset of muscle spasms, typically in the head and neck, occurring within hours to days of drug initiation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Akathisia is characterized by a sense of inner restlessness along with objective, observable movements such as fidgeting of legs, pacing around, inability to sit or stand in one place for a long time. They can present soon after starting the antipsychotic or after dosage adjustments. It is the most common extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics. Drug of choice is Propranolol (beta blockers).

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 114

questions.text: In fetal alcohol syndrome, which of the following is not seen? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Macrocephaly

 

  • Fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) is associated with microcephaly, not macrocephaly.

 

 

Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) is a condition that arises from excessive alcohol exposure during pregnancy, which leads to a range of developmental abnormalities. FAS is characterized by several key features, including facial anomalies, central nervous system (CNS) dysfunction, and growth deficiencies.

 

  • Facial Anomalies: The classic facial features of FAS include small eye openings (narrow palpebral fissures), a smooth philtrum (the area between the nose and upper lip), and a thin upper lip. Other features may include epicanthic folds, a flattened nasal bridge, a short nose, low-set and unparallel ears, and midfacial hypoplasia.
  • CNS Dysfunction: This includes microcephaly (small head size), mental retardation, and neurobehavioral abnormalities such as attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). The presence of microcephaly is a common finding in FAS, reflecting the overall poor brain growth and development.
  • Thinning of Corpus Callosum: FAS can lead to structural brain abnormalities such as thinning or complete agenesis of the corpus callosum, which is the band of nerve fibers that connects the two hemispheres of the brain.
  • Holoprosencephaly: This is a severe brain malformation where the forebrain fails to divide into two hemispheres, which can be seen in more severe cases of FAS.

 

Macrocephaly (enlarged head size) is not a feature of FAS. On the contrary, FAS is typically associated with microcephaly, reflecting the impaired brain growth caused by alcohol exposure during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thinning of corpus callosum: This is a known CNS abnormality in FAS, reflecting the significant impact of alcohol on brain structure and development.

 

Option B. Microcephaly: One of the hallmark features of FAS, microcephaly indicates reduced brain size and development, commonly seen in affected infants.

 

Option C. Holoprosencephaly: This severe brain malformation can occur in the context of FAS, particularly in cases where the alcohol exposure has profoundly disrupted early brain development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) is associated with microcephaly and other CNS abnormalities, but macrocephaly is not a feature of this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is the constituent of the marked area in the electron microscopic picture of muscle? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alpha actinin

 

The image shows a sarcomere and the arrow marks the Z line which is constituted by Alpha actinin.

 

The orderly arrangement of actin, myosin, and related proteins that produces this pattern. The area between two Z-lines is called sarcomere.

 

 

  • Each muscle fiber contains several hundred to several thousand myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril is composed of about 1500 adjacent myosin filaments and 3000 actin filaments.
  • The thick filaments are myosin, and the thin filaments are actin
  • The myosin and actin filaments partially interdigitate and thus cause the myofibrils to have alternate light and dark bands.
  • The light bands contain only actin filaments and are called I bands because they are isotropic to polarized light.
  • The dark bands contain myosin filaments, as well as the ends of the actin filaments where they overlap the myosin, and are called A bands because they are anisotropic to polarized light.
  • Small projections from the sides of the myosin filaments are cross-bridges. The interaction between these cross-bridges and the actin filaments that causes contraction.
  • The ends of the actin filaments are attached to a so-called Z disc. From this disc, these filaments extend in both directions to interdigitate with the myosin filaments.
  • The Z disc is composed of filamentous proteins different from the actin and myosin filaments, passes
  • crosswise across the myofibril and also crosswise from myofibril to myofibril, attaching the myofibrils to one another all the way across the muscle fiber. Therefore, the entire muscle fiber has light and dark bands, as do the individual myofibrils giving the skeletal and cardiac muscle their striated appearance.
  • The portion of the myofibril (or of the whole muscle fibre) that lies between two successive Z discs is called a sarcomere.

 

Note: Some sources say that even titin is a component of Z-disc so if alpha actinin is not given in the options titin is the second-best answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Actin: A thin filament protein that interacts with myosin for muscle contraction but is not specific to the Z line.

 

Option C. Titin: A large elastic protein that spans from the Z line to the M line, providing elasticity and stabilizing the sarcomere's structure. Although titin is associated with the Z line, alpha actinin is the primary constituent.

 

Option D. Tropomyosin: A protein that lies along the actin filament and regulates muscle contraction by controlling access to the myosin-binding sites on actin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Z line in a sarcomere is primarily constituted by alpha actinin, which plays a critical role in anchoring actin filaments and maintaining the structural integrity of the muscle fiber.

questions.text: A young patient presented with hypoparathyroidism, absent thymus and tetany. Which of the following marked areas in the picture is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 12

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario of hypoparathyroidism, absent thymus, and tetany is suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome. It is caused by defective development of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouch.

 

In the image of pharyngeal pouches, "12" points to the thymus (derivative of 3rd pharyngeal pouch). Since in the above question, the thymus is absent, option 3 will be the most appropriate answer.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. (1): 1st Pharyngeal pouches, which is unrelated to the thymus or parathyroid glands directly involved in this case.

 

Option B. (10): External auditory meatus, which is not implicated in DiGeorge syndrome.

 

Option D. (13): Superior parathyroid gland, derived from the fourth pharyngeal pouch. Although it's closely related to the condition described, the primary indicator in this scenario, given the patient's symptoms, is the thymus rather than the parathyroid glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DiGeorge syndrome, also known as 22q11.2 deletion syndrome, is a genetic disorder caused by a missing piece of chromosome 22. It is characterized by a wide range of symptoms that can vary in severity, but are typically grouped together as mnemonic CATCH -22

 

Mnemonic "CATCH-22":

 

C - Cardiac abnormalities, such as ventricular septal defects (VSD) and tetralogy of Fallot.

 

A - Abnormal facies, including a small chin, low-set ears, and wide-set eyes.

 

T - Thymic aplasia or hypoplasia, leading to a weakened immune system.

 

C - Cleft palate or other palate abnormalities.

 

H - Hypocalcemia or low levels of calcium due to underdeveloped or missing parathyroid glands.

 

22 - Refers to the chromosome 22q11.2 deletion, which causes the syndrome.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male with Marfanoid habitus presents with sharp chest pain and sudden onset dyspnea. Chest X-ray was performed and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pneumothorax

Explanation:

The given CXR shows the presence of pneumothorax, which represents air in the pleural space. 

DIAGNOSIS: Right pneumothorax
MEDIASTINAL SHIFT: Contralateral
MOST SENSITIVE IX: CT scan
MOST SENSITIVE X-RAY: Expiratory X ray

Other Options:

Option A. Pulmonary embolism on a CXR shows enlarged pulmonary artery (Fleischer’s sign and Palla’ sign).

Option B. Hydropneumothorax - concurrent presence of a pneumothorax and pleural effusion. On Chest X-ray air-fluid level is seen. 

Option D. Aortic dissection will present with mediastinal widening and will be detected in CECT. 

Educational Objective:

Pneumothorax is characterized by the presence of air in the pleural space and can be identified on a chest X-ray by a clear line indicating the separation of the lung from the chest wall, with absent lung markings in the affected area. This diagnosis is particularly concerning in individuals with Marfan syndrome due to their increased vulnerability to spontaneous pneumothorax.

choices.text: Closure of aortic and pulmonary valves
Vibrations in the ventricular wall during systole
Closure of mitral and tricuspid valves

questions.text: The fourth heart sound is caused by: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ventricular filling

 

The fourth heart sound is caused by ventricular filling.

 

  • Atrial Heart Sound (Fourth Heart Sound) – Occurs when the atria contract, and presumably, it is caused by the inrush of blood into the ventricles, which initiates vibrations similar to those of the third heart sound.

 

Other heart sounds:

 

  • First heart sound – contraction of the ventricles first causes sudden backflow of blood against the A-V valves (the tricuspid and mitral valves) causing them to close producing the first heart sound.
  • The second heart sound results from sudden closure of the semilunar valves at the end of systole.
  • Third Heart Sound – occasionally a weak, rumbling third heart sound is heard at the beginning of the middle third of diastole. Most probably it is due to oscillation of blood back and forth between the walls of the ventricles initiated by inrushing blood from the atria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fourth heart sound (S4) is caused by the atrial contraction and the subsequent inrush of blood into the ventricles, which initiates vibrations similar to those of the third heart sound.

questions.text: Which of the following can be responsible for Bezold-Jarisch reflex? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Serotonin

 

Bezold-Jarisch reflex is the reflex characterized by bradycardia and hypotension, caused by stimulation of chemoreceptors present in the wall of left ventricles by substances such as alkaloids. It is also called coronary chemoreflex. Vagal fibers form the afferent and efferent pathways of this reflex.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Histamine; C. Prostaglandin and D. Angiotensin: do not involved in the Bezold-Jarisch reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotonin, capsaicin, phenyl biguanide, and veratridine can cause Bezold-Jarisch reflex.

choices.text: Ciprofloxacin and tinidazole
Only ciprofloxacin
Only ORS
Ciprofloxacin, tinidazole and ORS

questions.text: A young male developed 5 episodes of loose stools 2 hours after eating in a restaurant. He is afebrile and has mild dehydration. What should be the treatment? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Only ORS

 

Management of diarrhea in an afebrile patient is mainly based on the presence or absence of dehydration. In case of no dehydration or some dehydration, we can manage it using only ORS. If there is severe dehydration, then IV fluids have to be used. There is no role of antibiotics in such case. Empirical antibiotics are used only in case of febrile patients. If only bacterial etiology is suspected, the Ciprofloxacin is used, and it amoebiasis or giardiasis is suspected, then Metronidazole is used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ciprofloxacin and tinidazole: This combination is used for treating bacterial and protozoal infections. However, it is not indicated here because the patient is afebrile and the condition is likely self-limiting.

 

Option B. Only ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is an antibiotic used for bacterial infections. Since the patient is afebrile and has mild dehydration, there is no indication for antibiotic therapy. ORS alone is sufficient.

 

Option D. Ciprofloxacin, tinidazole and ORS: This combination is unnecessary and potentially harmful. Overuse of antibiotics can lead to resistance and other side effects. The primary treatment needed is rehydration with ORS

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a young male with afebrile, mild dehydration due to acute diarrhea, the appropriate treatment is oral rehydration solution (ORS) to replace lost fluids and electrolytes. Antibiotics are not indicated unless there is a suspicion of bacterial infection with severe symptoms or fever.

questions.text: Which of the following histological image represents a holocrine gland? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. B

 

The histopathological image marked 'B' represents the sebaceous gland, which is a type of holocrine gland.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options A: Image A. Sweat glands - Eccrine/merocrine glands; glands remain intact

 

 

Options C: Image C. Mammary gland - Apocrine gland; apical part sheds to secrete

 

 

Option D: Image D. Ceruminous gland - Apocrine glands

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Holocrine secretions are produced in the cytoplasm of the cell and released by the rupture of the plasma membrane, which destroys the cell and results in the secretion of the product into the lumen.

 

Examples of holocrine glands are: -

 

  • Sebaceous glands of the skin and
  • Meibomian glands of the eyelid

choices.text: Naive B cells in Interfollicular zones

questions.text: Origin of B cell in CLL/SLL is: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Naive B cells in Interfollicular zones

 

In CLL/SLL, B cells originate from naive B cell or Pre/Post Germinal Centre memory B cell. CLL arises in the lymph node.

 

DNA sequencing has revealed that the Ig genes of some CLL/SLL are somatically hypermutated, whereas others are not, suggesting that the cell of origin may be either a post germinal center memory B cell or a naïve B cell. For unclear reasons, tumors with unmutated Ig segments (those putatively of naive B-cell origin) pursue a more aggressive course

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Centrocytes: Centrocytes are B cells located in the germinal center of lymphoid follicles, where they undergo selection during the immune response. However, they are not the origin of CLL/SLL, as CLL/SLL originates from naive B cells or memory B cells, not centrocytes.

 

Option B. Extranodal mature Peripheral B cells: While peripheral B cells are involved in immune responses, the origin of CLL/SLL is not from these mature peripheral B cells but rather from naive B cells within interfollicular zones.

 

Option D. Bone Marrow Progenitors: Bone marrow progenitors are the precursors of various blood cells, including B cells, but they are not the immediate origin of the B cells involved in CLL/SLL. CLL/SLL originates from more differentiated B cells, specifically naive B cells in interfollicular zones or memory B cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The origin of B cells in CLL/SLL is primarily from naive B cells in interfollicular zones or post-germinal center memory B cells. Tumors originating from naive B cells, as indicated by unmutated Ig segments, tend to pursue a more aggressive course.

choices.text: 2 FC and 1 FAB fragment
1 Variable chain and 1 constant chain
1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments

questions.text: When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, which of the following are the end products? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments

 

When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, the end products are 1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments.

 

If an antibody molecule is digested with papain, cleavage occurs above the disulfide bonds that hold the heavy chains together. This generates 3 separate fragments, two of which are called Fab (fragment antigen binding), and one of which is called Fc (fragment crystallizable).

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

When an immunoglobulin molecule is digested with papain, the end products are 1 Fc fragment and 2 Fab fragments.

questions.text: Which of the following is a tool used in gene editing: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CRISPR

 

The core technologies now most commonly used to facilitate genome editing are -

 

1. Clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats (CRISPR)-CRISPR-associated protein 9 (Cas9) – CRISPs are guide RNAS. By delivering the Cas9 nuclease complexed with a synthetic guide RNA (gRNA) into a cell, the cell's genome can be cut at a desired location, allowing existing genes to be removed and/or new ones added in vivo.

 

 

2. Transcription activator-like effector nucleases (TALENs)

 

3. Zinc-finger nucleases (ZFNs)

 

4. Homing endonucleases or meganucleases.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Big data: Refers to the large volume of data that can be analyzed to reveal patterns, trends, and associations, especially relating to human behavior and interactions, but it is not a tool for gene editing.

 

Option C. Gene Xpert: Is a diagnostic tool used to detect genetic material from specific pathogens (e.g., Mycobacterium tuberculosis) and is not related to gene editing.

 

Option D. GWAS (Genome-Wide Association Studies): Involves scanning genomes from many different people to find genetic markers associated with specific diseases. While related to genetics, it is not a tool for directly editing genes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRISPR is a powerful gene editing tool that enables precise modifications of the genome and is used extensively in genetic research and therapeutic applications.

questions.text: "a" wave on JVP is for: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atrial contraction

 

 

The "a" wave on the jugular venous pressure (JVP) tracing represents atrial contraction. This wave occurs when the right atrium contracts, pushing blood into the right ventricle. It is the first positive deflection in the JVP waveform and is a key component in assessing right atrial pressure and function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrial filling: Incorrect. Atrial filling is represented by the v wave, which occurs as the atrium fills with blood during ventricular systole.

 

Option C. Ventricular relaxation: Incorrect. Ventricular relaxation corresponds to the x descent and y descent in the JVP tracing.

 

Option D. Ventricular filling: Incorrect. Ventricular filling is associated with the y descent.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: On the action line
Before the action line
On the alert line
After the alert line

questions.text: In a Partogram, where do you start plotting the cervical dilatation? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) On the alert line

 

Explanation:

 

In the WHO modified partograph, labor progression is charted using alert and action lines. The cervical dilatation is plotted starting in the active phase of labor, typically at 4 cm dilation.

 

  • Alert Line: Represents a cervical dilation rate of 1 cm per hour. The first marking of cervical dilatation should be on this line.
  • Action Line: Plotted 4 hours to the right of the alert line. It indicates when intervention should be considered if labor is not progressing as expected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. On the action line: Plotting starts on the alert line, not the action line. The action line is used for intervention planning.

 

Option B. Before the action line: This is incorrect as the plotting starts on the alert line.

 

Option D. After the alert line: This is incorrect since plotting should start on the alert line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a Partogram, cervical dilatation is first plotted on the alert line, which indicates the expected rate of progress in labor.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/337693/9789240017566-eng.pdf

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with severe back pain, vomiting, and hypotension. CT findings are given below. What is the diagnosis?(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Renal angiomyolipoma

 

Explanation:

 

The CT image shows a left renal lesion with negative /low attenuation (black in color) that indicate fatty tissue. This is consistent with renal angiomyolipoma. Clinical findings of severe back pain, vomiting, and hypotension and hematoma around the renal mass are suggestive of rupture. This is known as Wunderlich syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal cysts are homogeneous hypodense lesions.

 

Option B. Renal cell carcinoma will appear heterogeneous and hypervacular with areas of necrosis.

 

Option C. Para pelvic cyst are  simple renal cysts that plunge into the renal sinus from the adjacent renal parenchyma. A parapelvic cyst at times may cause compression of the pelvicalyceal system resulting in hydronephrosis. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal angiomyolipoma is typically composed of fat, muscle, and blood vessels and appears as a low-attenuation mass on CT scans. When associated with symptoms like severe pain and hypotension, it raises concerns for potential hemorrhage or rupture, emphasizing the need for prompt evaluation and management.

questions.text: In the 2 vessels shown below, assume the pressure along both the vessels is the same and both follow linear flow pattern. What will be the amount of blood flow in A compared to B? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 8 times

 

According to Poiseuille's law:

 

 

in which F is the rate of blood flow, ∆P is the pressure difference between the ends of the vessel, r is the radius of the vessel, l is length of the vessel, and h is viscosity of the blood.

 

Therefore, blood flow (F) inside the vessel is

 

  • ﻿﻿Directly proportional to the pressure difference
  • ﻿﻿Inversely proportional to the viscosity:
  • ﻿﻿Directly proportional to the fourth power of radius
  • ﻿﻿Inversely proportional to length of the vessel

 

So, if the radius is doubled flow will increase by 2 to the power of 4 = 16

And if the length of the vessel is also doubled, the reduces by half (÷2) = 8

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to Poiseuille's law blood flow (𝐹F) is:

 

  • Directly proportional to the pressure difference (Δ𝑃ΔP)
  • Inversely proportional to the viscosity (𝜂η)
  • Directly proportional to the fourth power of the radius (𝑟4r4)
  • Inversely proportional to the length of the vessel (𝑙l)

choices.text: Endobronchial neoplasm
Bronchial asthma
Myasthenia gravis

questions.text: The flow volume curve after spirometry in patient 1 is given below. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myasthenia gravis

 

In patient 1, flow volume curve shows restrictive pattern, and it corresponds to myasthenia gravis.

 

The flow volume curve shown indicates a restrictive pattern, which is characterized by reduced lung volumes but relatively preserved flow rates, consistent with non-obstructive lung pathology. Myasthenia gravis, a neuromuscular disorder, often affects the respiratory muscles leading to a restrictive ventilatory defect as depicted in the flow volume loop. This condition results from antibodies that block or destroy nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the junction between the nerve and muscle, leading to muscle weakness including the respiratory muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endobronchial neoplasm: Typically presents with an obstructive pattern on spirometry due to airway obstruction.

 

Option B. Bronchial asthma: Asthma would show an obstructive pattern characterized by decreased peak expiratory flow and difficulty exhaling, which is not observed in the given curve.

 

Option D. Emphysema: Emphysema, part of chronic obstructive pulmonary diseases (COPD), would also exhibit an obstructive pattern with a "scooped out" appearance on the expiratory curve due to air trapping and reduced elastic recoil, which is not seen in the curve provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis can present with a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests due to respiratory muscle weakness, differentiating it from conditions that cause obstructive patterns such as asthma and emphysema.

choices.text: Blurred vision
Steven Johnson Syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is not an idiosyncratic reaction of carbamazepine?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Blurred vision

 

Idiosyncrasy is defined as a genetically determined abnormal reactivity to a drug. The drug interacts with some unique feature of the individual, not found in majority of the subjects and produces uncharacteristic reactions. As such the type of the reaction is restricted to individuals with a particular genotype.

 

Idiosyncratic Reactions of Carbamazepine:

 

  • Agranulocytosis: This is a serious idiosyncratic reaction where the drug causes a significant drop in white blood cells, particularly neutrophils, leading to a higher risk of infection.
  • Rash: Skin reactions, including rashes, are common idiosyncratic reactions to carbamazepine. These can range from mild to severe.
  • Steven Johnson Syndrome (SJS): Although rare, carbamazepine can cause severe skin reactions like SJS, which is a serious condition involving the skin and mucous membranes and requires immediate medical attention.

 

Non-Idiosyncratic Reactions:

 

  • Blurred Vision: This is a common side effect of carbamazepine related to its pharmacological action and dose rather than an idiosyncratic reaction. Blurred vision typically occurs due to the drug's effects on the central nervous system and is not unique to specific individuals based on genetic or other idiosyncratic factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Agranulocytosis: Agranulocytosis is a potentially life-threatening idiosyncratic reaction associated with carbamazepine, characterized by a significant reduction in granulocytes, a type of white blood cell.

 

Option C. Rash: Skin rashes are common idiosyncratic reactions to carbamazepine and can vary in severity from mild to severe.

 

Option D. Steven Johnson Syndrome: SJS is a rare but severe idiosyncratic reaction to carbamazepine, involving extensive skin and mucous membrane damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blurred vision is not an idiosyncratic reaction of carbamazepine; it is a common dose-related side effect. Idiosyncratic reactions to carbamazepine include agranulocytosis, rash, and Steven Johnson Syndrome, which are unpredictable and occur due to individual genetic predispositions.

choices.text: They are unable to mount inflammation against the virus
Virus can integrate with host DNA and form complementary DNA
There is a risk of elevation of transaminases
Liver parenchymal cells are in a state of high proliferation

questions.text: There are 3 to 5% healthy hepatitis B carriers in India who are asymptomatic. They are at the risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma in the future because? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Virus can integrate with host DNA and form complementary DNA

 

In most tumors, HBV DNA is integrated into the cell genome, and in most cases, the virus DNA has undergone rearrangements, including deletions. After integration, it promotes the overexpression of cell genes that can also contribute to oncogenesis.

 

The only viral gene product that is consistently present in the tumor cells is the X protein.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Inability to mount inflammation against the virus is not the primary reason for the increased risk of HCC.

 

Option C: Elevated transaminases indicate liver inflammation but are not directly related to the integration of viral DNA and oncogenesis.

 

Option D: High proliferation of liver parenchymal cells is not the primary reason for the increased risk of HCC due to HBV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B virus can integrate its DNA into the host genome, leading to genetic mutations and increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma.

choices.text: Single dose of 0.75 after 12 hrs
Two doses 12 hrs apart
Three doses 12 hrs apart
None of the above

questions.text: For emergency contraception, a single tab of 0.75 mg of LNG was taken, it should be followed by which of the following? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Single dose of 0.75 after 12 hrs

 

Explanation:

 

  • In this case, the 2nd dose of LNG 0.75 mg (levonorgestrel) is taken after 12 hours.
  • One tablet of LNG 0.75mg should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse and another 12 hours later.
  • Alternately, two tablets (of 0.75mg) or a single 1.5mg tablet can be taken as a single dose.
  • The tablets can be offered up to 72h of an act of unprotected intercourse, but the efficacy decreases with the longer coital-drug interval.

 

Other emergency contraceptives available:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emergency contraception using levonorgestrel requires a follow-up dose of 0.75 mg taken 12 hours after the initial dose to ensure efficacy.

 

Ref: Page no 243, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition

questions.text: Criminal responsibility of Insane is defined in: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. McNaughten's Rule

 

“McNaughten’s Rule” also known as “Legal test of insanity”, “right or wrong test” is the legal standard for determining criminal responsibility in cases of insanity.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Curren's rule: of 1964 states that an accused person is not criminally responsible, if at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of the law, as a result of mental disease or defect.

 

Option C. Durham 's rule: of 1954 States that an accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental disease or mental defect.

 

Option D. American law institute test: (1972) A person is not responsible for the crime, if at the time of committing it, he lacks adequate capacity to appreciate the criminality of his conduct or to adjust it to the requirements of the law.

 

Educational Objective:

 

McNaughten's rule is defined by section 84 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC)

 

It states that "A person of unsound mind is not liable for an act."

 

It implies that the defendant was unable to distinguish between right and wrong or otherwise didn't understand what they did because of a "disease of the mind."

questions.text: A patient was sputum negative for tuberculosis, but chest X-ray was suggestive of tuberculosis. Which is the next step according to RNTCP? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CBNAAT

 

CB-NAAT and Line probe assay are rapid molecular diagnostic techniques used for diagnosis of tuberculosis and also to assess resistance to isoniazid and rifampicin.

 

CB NAAT (Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) provides rapid and accurate diagnosis of TB by detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis and mutations responsible for rifampicin resistance. It can be used for sputum samples as well as samples from extrapulmonary sites.

 

It is mainly used for diagnosis of DR-TB in presumptive DR-TB patients and TB in key populations such as pediatric population, PLHIV and extrapulmonary TB.

 

It is done when smear is negative for TB but chest X-ray is suggestive of tuberculosis and also in cases smear is negative and chest X-ray is not suggestive of TB but there is high index of clinical suspicion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Line probe assay: Line probe assay is another molecular diagnostic test used for detecting resistance to first-line and second-line anti-TB drugs. However, it is not the first choice for initial diagnosis following a negative sputum smear but suggestive chest X-ray.

 

Option C. Liquid culture: Liquid culture is used for confirming TB diagnosis and drug susceptibility testing. It is more time-consuming compared to molecular tests like CBNAAT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with negative sputum smears but chest X-ray findings suggestive of TB, CBNAAT is the recommended next diagnostic step under RNTCP guidelines.

choices.text: It confirms that the person does not have the disease
It suggests that if the disease is rare, the person surely has the disease
It confirms that the person has the disease if the disease is common
It is an expected finding in case the disease is prevalent

questions.text: A sensitive diagnostic test for a certain disease returns a positive result for a patient. What statement accurately describes the significance of a positive result from the sensitive test? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) It confirms that the person has the disease if the disease is common

 

  • If a sensitive test yields a positive result, it indicates the presence of the disease, especially when the disease is prevalent.
  • The sensitivity of a screening test refers to its capacity to accurately identify individuals with the disease.
  • In simpler terms, sensitivity measures the test's capability to correctly spot true positives (TP) among all cases of the disease (TP+FN). 

 

Sensitivity = TP / TP + FN X 100

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It confirms that the person does not have the disease: Incorrect. A sensitive test returning a positive result indicates the presence, not the absence, of the disease.

 

Option B. It suggests that if the disease is rare, the person surely has the disease: Incorrect. If the disease is rare, the positive predictive value (PPV) might be low, and the result may be less reliable.

 

Option D. It is an expected finding in case the disease is prevalent: Incorrect. While a positive result is more likely in a prevalent disease, it does not solely rely on sensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A positive result from a highly sensitive test confirms the presence of the disease, particularly when the disease is common.

questions.text: The histopathology picture below is suggestive of? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

  • The given slide shows a row of tombstones' appearance, which is classically seen in Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • The production of antibodies, specifically those against Desmoglein 3, is seen in Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Desmoglein 1 antibodies are also occasionally associated.

 

 

  • Usually, the antibodies are IgG antibodies. The skin and mucosa's basal and suprabasal layers contain the majority of Desmoglein 3.
  • Hemidesmosomes help in connecting basal layer to underlying dermo-epidermal junction, in pemphigus vulgaris there are no antibodies against Hemidesmosomes, so the basal layer remains attached to the underlying dermo-epidermal junction giving the classical Row of tombstones appearance.
  • The patients, therefore, present with flaccid bullae over the skin and due to Desmoglein 3 involvement, mucosal involvement can also be seen.
  • Oral mucosa is commonly affected.

 

 

  • Other areas where ulceration can be seen are conjunctiva, nasopharynx, larynx, etc.
  • Cutaneous lesions are more common over the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back as seen in the image below.

 

 

Biopsy: The basal layer remains adherent to the basement membrane and gives the resemblance to a row of tombstones.

 

 

IMAGE of row of tombstones appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Psoriasis vulgaris:

 

  • This is an autoimmune disease characterized by hyperproliferation of keratinocytes leading to thickened, scaly plaques.
  • Histologically, it shows parakeratosis (retention of nuclei in the stratum corneum), elongation of rete ridges, and a neutrophilic infiltrate (Munro's microabscesses) as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The tombstone appearance is not a feature of psoriasis.

 

Option B. Leishmaniasis:

 

  • It's a parasitic infection caused by the Leishmania species.
  • Histologically, it is characterized by macrophages containing the parasite (Leishman-Donovan bodies) in the dermis as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The tombstone appearance is not seen in leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Mycosis fungoides:

 

  • This is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.
  • Histologically, there is an atypical lymphocytic infiltrate in the epidermis (epidermotropism), and the formation of Pautrier's microabscesses (collections of lymphocytes in the epidermis) as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • It does not exhibit a tombstone appearance.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The histopathology image suggests Pemphigus vulgaris, which is characterized by intraepidermal blistering due to acantholysis, or separation of keratinocytes, as a result of autoantibody attack on desmosomal proteins.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page no 50.1

Robbins & cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10e- page no 1160

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male presents with a history of decreased vision. Fluorescein angiography showed the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Proliferative diabetic retinopathy

 

  • Image shows neovascularization in proliferative diabetic retinopathy, arising from optic nerve head.
  • Neovascularization of the disc (ND). and along large vessels, as well as neovascularization elsewhere (NVE) present.
  • Treatment for proliferative diabetic retinopathy is photocoagulation of ischaemic areas.
  • Aim is to reduce metabolic demand and prevent release of vasoproliferative factors.

 

 

Birdshot retinochoroidopathy (also known as birdshot chorioretinopathy, vitiliginous chorioretinitis, or simply birdshot uveitis) is a chronic, bilateral, posterior uveitis with characteristic yellow-white lesions in the fundus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mild Non-proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy - Characterized by microaneurysms and retinal hemorrhages but does not feature neovascularization.

 

Option B. Severe Non-proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy - More extensive than mild, including hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and sometimes severe retinal ischemia, but still lacks neovascularization.

 

Option C. Birdshot Choroidopathy - Typically presents with distinctive yellow-white lesions in the retina, which are not apparent in the provided angiography images. This condition is an inflammatory process, not related to neovascularization seen in diabetic retinopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy is the advanced stage of diabetic eye disease, marked by neovascularization, which requires aggressive treatment like laser photocoagulation to prevent severe visual loss. It is crucial for diabetics, particularly those with a long history or poorly controlled diabetes, to undergo regular eye examinations for early detection and management of diabetic retinopathy.

choices.text: B cells, dendritic cells, mononuclear phagocytes

questions.text: Among the following, which cells have MHC class II? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) B cells, dendritic cells, mononuclear phagocytes

 

Class II major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules are mainly expressed on macrophages, B lymphocytes, and dendritic cells. These cells present ingested antigens to T-cells.

 

Class I major histocompatibility complex are expressed on all nucleated cells

 

Class III major histocompatibility complex are some components of the complement system (C2 and C4) coded on HLA complex but are not associated with HLA expression and are not used in antigen identification.

 

 

MHC antigens present on the cell surface help the macrophage in its function of bacterial antigen recognition i.e., they help to identify self from foreign, and accordingly present the foreign antigen to T cells (CD4+ or CD8+) or to B cells.

 

MHC I are located on a portion of chromosome 6p of all nucleated cells of the body and platelets. These genes occupy four regions or loci—A, B, C and D, on the short (p) arm of chromosome 6 and exhibit marked variation in allelic genes at each locus. Therefore, the product of HLA antigens is highly polymorphic.

 

The genes encoding HLA molecules are clustered on the short arm of chromosome 6.

 

Role of MHC/ HLA typing include:

 

  1. Organ Transplantation
  2. Regulation of immune system
  3. Association of diseases with HLA. An increasing number of diseases have been found to have association with some specific histocompatibility antigens. Ex:
  4. Inflammatory disorders e.g., ankylosing spondylitis
  5. Autoimmune disorders e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, insulin dependent diabetes mellitus.
  6. Inherited disorders of metabolism e.g., idiopathic haemochromatosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. NK cells: While natural killer (NK) cells play a role in immune responses, they do not express MHC class II molecules.

 

Option B. All nucleated cells: This describes MHC Class I expression, not MHC Class II.

 

Option D. Platelets: Although platelets are derived from nucleated cells, they do not express MHC Class II molecules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MHC Class II molecules are primarily expressed on antigen presenting cells (B cells, dendritic cells, and mononuclear phagocytes), which are essential for antigen presentation to T-helper cells.

questions.text: A metal factory worker suffers from noise-induced hearing loss. Which of the following structures will be affected? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Outer hair cells

 

  • Noise-Induced Hearing Loss (NIHL) causes damage to outer hair cells.
  • NIHL Hearing loss, in this case, is due to chronic exposure.
  • It can be of two types
     
    1. Temporary threshold shift (TTS). The hearing is impaired immediately after exposure to noise but recovers after an interval of a few minutes to a few hours even up to 2 weeks
    2. Permanent threshold shift (PTS). The hearing impairment is permanent and does not recover at all.

 

The audiogram in NIHL shows a typical notch, at 4 kHz, both for air and bone conduction. This is referred to as acoustic dip or Boiler's notch.

 

 

The damage caused by noise trauma depends on several factors:

 

  1. Frequency of noise. A frequency of 2000–3000 Hz causes more damage than lower or higher frequencies.
  2. Intensity and duration of noise. As the intensity increases, permissible time for exposure is reduced.
  3. Continuous noise is more harmful.
  4. Susceptibility of the individual. Degree of TTS and PTS varies in different individuals.
  5. Pre-existing ear disease.

 

Other Options:
