Option A. Crista ampullaris: This structure is located within the semicircular canals of the inner ear and is primarily involved in sensing rotational movements of the head, not in hearing. Thus, it is not typically affected by noise-induced hearing loss.

 

Option B. Macula: Found in the utricle and saccule of the vestibular system, the macula detects linear accelerations and head tilts but is not directly involved in the auditory response to sound waves.

 

Option C. Cupola: The cupola is a gelatin-like structure in the vestibular system's semicircular canals that responds to changes in head position. Like the crista ampullaris, it is unrelated to the hearing process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Noise-induced hearing loss specifically damages the outer hair cells in the cochlea, leading to hearing impairment.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 36, 37

choices.text: Assess the patient's response, Activate ERS, check carotid pulse, Start CPR
Check carotid pulse, Start CPR, call for help and activate ERS, Defibrillate
Defibrillate, assess response, check carotid pulse, Maintain airway
Start CPR, Activate ERS, Defibrillate, Check pulse

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence for CPR in Basic life support?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Assess the patient's response, Activate ERS, check carotid pulse, Start CPR

 

The American Heart Association (AHA) provides guidelines for BLS as part of its Advanced Cardiac Life Support (ACLS) recommendations. Here are the core steps of BLS as per the latest AHA guidelines :

 

1. Scene Safety: Before you start, ensure that the scene is safe for both the patient and the rescuer.

 

2. Check Responsiveness: Gently tap the patient and shout, "Are you okay?" to determine if the patient is responsive.

 

3. Activate the Emergency Response System: If the person is unresponsive, call for help or have someone else call emergency services (like 911 in the U.S.) and get an automated external defibrillator (AED) if available.

 

4. Check Breathing and Pulse Simultaneously: Look for normal breathing while checking for a pulse. If the person isn't breathing or is only gasping and has no pulse, begin CPR.

 

5. CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation):

 

  • Compressions: Start with chest compressions. Place the heel of one hand on the center of the chest and the other hand on top, interlocking the fingers. Compress the chest hard and fast, at a depth of at least 2 inches (5 cm) for adults, at a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute. Allow complete chest recoil after each compression.

  • Airway: After every 30 compressions, open the airway using a head-tilt-chin-lift maneuver.

  • Breathing: Give 2 rescue breaths after 30 compressions. Make sure there's a good seal with the patient's mouth and give a breath over one second that makes the chest rise visibly. If the chest doesn't rise, reposition the head and try again.

 

6. AED Use: As soon as an AED is available, turn it on and follow its prompts. Apply the pads and allow the AED to analyze the rhythm. If a shockable rhythm is detected, make sure no one is touching the patient and deliver the shock. Immediately resume chest compressions after the shock.

 

7. Continue CPR: Keep going with CPR (30 compressions:2 breaths) until emergency medical help arrives, the person starts to show signs of life (like breathing), the scene becomes unsafe, or the rescuer is too exhausted to continue.

 

Educational Objective : Assess the patient's response, Activate ERS, check carotid pulse, Start CPR is the correct sequence in Basic life support.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 2715-2716

questions.text: During development, thymic cells recognizing self-antigens are removed to prevent autoimmunity. Which gene among the following is involved in the process? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AIRE

 

The above process is called central tolerance and the AIRE (Autoimmune Regulator) protein is necessary for this process.

 

Immature self-reactive T and B lymphocyte clones recognize self-antigens during their maturation in the central lymphoid organs (thymus for T cells, bone marrow for B cells). They are killed or rendered harmless.

 

The removal of self-reacting T lymphocytes in the thymus is called negative selection/ deletion. A protein called AIRE (autoimmune regulator) stimulates expression of some “peripheral tissue-restricted” self-antigens in the thymus and is thus critical for deletion of immature T cells specific for these antigens. Mutations in the AIRE gene are the cause of an autoimmune polyendocrinopathy

 

B cells undergo a process called receptor editing. When developing B cells encounter an antigen, it formulates a change in the receptor that makes the antigen unrecognizable. Self-reacting B cells can also undergo apoptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NOTCH1: Involved in T cell development but not specifically in the central tolerance process.

 

Option B. RB gene: A tumor suppressor gene involved in regulating the cell cycle, not in immune tolerance.

 

Option C. CPK gene: Not relevant to the process of central tolerance or immune regulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The AIRE gene is crucial for central tolerance in the thymus, preventing autoimmunity by ensuring the deletion of self-reactive T cells.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 397-398

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman was undergoing cholecystectomy. During the procedure, the resident accidentally advanced the scissors along the superior border of the epiploic foramen causing injury. Which of the following structures is likely to be injured?(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Caudate lobe of liver

 

Explanation:

 

The caudate lobe is a small, distinct lobe of the liver that lies posterior to the porta hepatis and forms the posterior border of the lesser omentum. Importantly, it forms the superior border of the epiploic foramen. Thus, during cholecystectomy, an injury advancing the scissors along the superior border of the epiploic foramen could damage the caudate lobe.

 

Epiploic foramen is a vertical slit of about 3 cm behind the free right border of the lesser omentum. It connects the lesser sac to the greater sac.

 

 

Clinical note: Pringle maneuver (as shown below) is a technique where the free margin of the lesser omentum is compressed to obtain rapid control of bleeding from the hepatic artery and portal vein in liver trauma and surgery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right lobe of liver: The right lobe of the liver is a major lobe, and it constitutes the majority of the liver's mass. It does not directly border the epiploic foramen. The anterior surface of the right lobe faces the anterior abdominal wall, and the posterior surface is related to the diaphragm and right kidney.

 

Option B. Quadrate lobe of liver: The quadrate lobe is a smaller lobe situated on the visceral surface of the liver. It is bounded by the gallbladder on the right and the round ligament of the liver on the left. It is separated from the left lobe by the fissure for the ligamentum teres. While it's close to the region, the quadrate lobe does not form the superior border of the epiploic foramen.

 

Option D. Fundus of gallbladder: The fundus is the most distal part of the gallbladder and it usually projects beyond the inferior border of the liver, contacting the anterior abdominal wall. It is not directly related to the epiploic foramen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Boundaries of epiploic foramen

questions.text: Identify the marked bond in Orange? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrogen bond

 

Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) is composed of four deoxyribonucleotides, i.e. deoxyadenylate (A), deoxyguanylate (G), deoxycytidylate (C), and thymidylate (T).

 

These units are linked by 3′ to 5′ phosphodiester bonds (covalent bonds) to form a long polypeptide chain. The nucleotide is formed by a combination of base + sugar + phosphoric acid. The 3′-hydroxyl of one sugar is linked to the 5′-hydroxyl of another sugar through a phosphate group.

 

The DNA strands are held together mainly by hydrogen bonds between the purine and pyrimidine bases. There are two hydrogen bonds between Adenine (A) and Thymine (T) while there are three hydrogen bonds between Cytidine (C) and Guanine (G). The GC bond is therefore stronger than the AT bond.

 

The spatial alignment of the helix allows only purine to pyrimidine base pairing.

 

A-T and C-G base pairs have almost the same shape. A mispairing will disturb the stable double helical structure.

 

 

Other interactions contributing to DNA stability include:

 

  • Hydrophobic effects - DNA has an arrangement wherein the non-polar, uncharged bases are present in the interior of the structure, while the negatively charged phosphates are present on the outside. As the cellular environment is aqueous and polar, the hydrophobic bases in the interior of the helix are kept away from the surrounding water and the hydrophilic heads are exposed and interact with the exterior water. This property increases the solubility of DNA in water.
  • Van der Waals forces - The nitrogenous bases stacked upon one another are spaced based on their van der Waals distance. Van der Waals distance is the distance at which two molecules are attracted to each other. If this distance reduces, the electrons of the two molecules may overlap causing repulsion. These forces are very distance dependent and are inversely proportional to the sixth power of distance (r6). Although a single van der Waals interaction has a very small effect on the overall structure of DNA, the net effect of several interactions leads to substantial stability.
  • Ionic interactions - The electrostatic (ion-ion) repulsion of the negatively charged phosphates on the outside can make DNA potentially very unstable. However, magnesium ions (Mg2+) and cationic proteins along with arginine and lysine residues interact with the negatively charged groups in the DNA and stabilize it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. lonic bond: This type of bond occurs between charged atoms (ions), typically in the form of salts and is not involved in the structure of DNA.


Option B. Covalent bond: Covalent bonds are strong bonds formed by sharing electrons between atoms. In DNA, covalent bonds (phosphodiester bonds) link the sugar-phosphate backbone but are not marked in the provided image.

option D. Phosphodiester Bond: This is a covalent bond that forms the sugar-phosphate backbone of DNA. It is not the bond marked in orange in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrogen bonds between purine and pyrimidine bases stabilize the double helix structure of DNA.

questions.text: Which of the following will not be avid on FDG PET scan? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Typical carcinoid

 

Explanation:

 

Typical carcinoids generally do not show avid uptake on an FDG PET scan because they are well-differentiated tumors with relatively low metabolic activity compared to more aggressive cancers. FDG PET scans are most effective in identifying tumors that have high glucose metabolism, which is more characteristic of rapidly growing and less differentiated tumors. Typical carcinoids, being slow-growing, often exhibit minimal FDG uptake, making them less detectable on PET scans.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Small cell carcinoma: This type of cancer is highly aggressive and shows high metabolic activity, making it usually very avid on FDG PET scans.

 

Option C. Atypical carcinoid: More aggressive than typical carcinoids, often showing intermediate to high FDG uptake due to higher metabolic activity.

 

Option D. Large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma: A highly aggressive neuroendocrine tumor that generally shows significant FDG uptake due to its rapid growth and high metabolic rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumors false-negative on PET-CT:

 

Lung adenocarcinoma

Mucinous adenocarcinoma

Typical carcinoid

questions.text: A woman whose obstetric score is G2 P1 L1 had an LMP of Jan 9th 2017. Calculate the EDD according to Naegele's rule? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) October 16

 

  • Normal duration of pregnancy: 280 days (40 weeks)
  • Calculating the EDD: Naegele’s formula. To the LMP (1st day of the last menstrual day 
    • Add 9 months + 7 days
    • Subtract 3 months and add 7 days
    • For IVF Pregnancies: add 9 months and subtract 7 days from the date of the embryo transfer
  • For e.g. The EDD of this patient will be 16/10/2017.
  • Dating the pregnancy: If discrepancy in dates/ unsure of LMP; the best way to determine the dating is by ULTRASOUND.
    • 1st trimester CRL: most accurate (till 14 weeks)
    • BPD in the 2nd trimester

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Naegele's rule is a standard way of calculating the estimated date of delivery by adding 9 months and 7 days to the first day of the last menstrual period. This method assumes a regular 28-day menstrual cycle.

 

Ref: Page no 83, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Joint pains with nodules on skin

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with history of back ache and polyarthralgia was investigated and found to have nucleolar pattern in IF. Which of the following is the best fit in her case? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Raynaud phenomenon and sclerodactyly

 

Nucleolar pattern refers to the presence of a few discrete spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and represents antibodies to RNA. This pattern is reported most often in patients with systemic sclerosis. Hence, Raynaud phenomenon and sclerodactyly will be seen.

 

 

Systemic sclerosis is more common in middle-aged women. The clinical manifestations include:

 

  • Claw-like flexion deformity of hands
  • Raynaud’s phenomenon - manifested as episodic vasoconstriction of the arteries and arterioles of the extremities, is seen in virtually all patients and precedes other symptoms in 70% of cases
  • Esophageal fibrosis causing dysphagia and hypomotility
  • Malabsorption syndrome
  • Respiratory distress due to pulmonary fibrosis
  • Malignant hypertension
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Biliary cirrhosis.

 

Other IF Patterns: -

 

Examples of ICAP-classified IIFA staining patterns:

 

 

 

ENA: Extractable nuclear antigens; RNP; ribonucleoproteins; SLE; systemic lupus erythematous; MCTD: mixed connective tissue disease; PM: polymyositis; dsDNA: double-stranded deoxyribonucleic acid; CENP: centromere protein

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Genital and oral painful ulcers: These are more characteristic of Behçet's disease, which is associated with HLA-B51 and presents with recurrent oral and genital ulcers, uveitis, and other systemic symptoms, not a nucleolar pattern on IF.

 

Option C. Glomerulonephritis and heart failure: These features are more consistent with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which may show a different pattern on IF, such as a homogenous or peripheral (rim) pattern, rather than the nucleolar pattern associated with systemic sclerosis.

 

Option D. Joint pains with nodules on skin: This description is typical of rheumatoid arthritis, which is associated with rheumatoid nodules and not the nucleolar pattern seen in systemic sclerosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nucleolar pattern in IF is most often associated with systemic sclerosis, a condition characterized by Raynaud phenomenon and sclerodactyly, among other systemic manifestations.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 405, 425

questions.text: While examining a patient in supine position, the examiner keeps his hand below the heel of one foot and asks the patient to flex the other hip against resistance, while keeping the week leg straight. This is known as:(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hoover’s sign

 

HOOVER TEST:

 

  • Hoover’s sign is a maneuver to separate organic from non-organic paresis of Leg.
  • Principle: Synergistic Contraction.
  • Involuntary extension of normal leg occurs with flexion of contralateral limb against resistance.
  • Test Positioning:
    • The subject relaxes in a supine position on the table while the examiner places both of the subject’s heels into their palm.
  • Action:
    • The subject is asked to perform a unilateral straight leg raise.
  • Positive Finding:
    • The inability to lift the leg may reflect a neuromuscular weakness.
    • A positive finding is also noted when the examiner does not feel increased pressure in the palm that underlies the resting leg.
    • Organic Cause: Flexion of paralyzed limb → heel of normal limb pushes the examiner’s hand.
    • Functional Weakness: Heel does not pushdown, i.e. the effort is not being transmitted.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Waddell’s test. Tests of malingering. Each test counts as +1 if +ve, 0 if –ve. This includes Superficial skin tenderness to light pinch over wide area of lumbar spine; Deep tenderness over wide area, often extending to thoracic spine, sacrum, and/or pelvis; Low back pain on axial loading of spine in standing; SLR test positive in supine, but not when seated with knee extended to test Babinski reflex; Abnormal or inconsistent neurological (motor and/or sensory) patterns; Overreaction. If 3+ points or more are there, investigate for non-organic cause.

 

Option B. O’ Donoghue’s test. Structures affected: Cervical spinal muscles and/or cervical spinal ligaments. The cervical spine of a seated patient is passively flexed, extended, laterally flexed to both sides, and rotated in both directions against patient resistance. Pain precipitated by such isometric contraction indicates cervical strain. The test is then repeated without patient resistance. Pain precipitated by passive unrestricted motion signifies cervical sprain.

 

 

O’Donoghue’s Maneuver for Knee Joint: This maneuver can be used to diagnose meniscal pathologies in the knee. With the patient in prone, the examiner flexes the knee to 90° and then rotates the tibia internally and externally twice, then fully extends the knee and repeat the rotations. Increased pain during rotation in either or both knee positions indicates a meniscal tear or joint capsule irritation. With a valgus force to a flexed and laterally rotated knee, the medial meniscus, medial collateral ligament (MCL), and ACL all may be injured, representing the O'Donoghue triad.

 

Option D. McMurray test. This test indicates tears of the middle or posterior horn of the meniscus. With the patient supine and the hip and knee fully flexed, apply a valgus force and externally rotate the tibia while extending the knee. An audible or palpable pop or snap indicates a medial meniscal tear. Lesions of the lateral meniscus are tested by applying a varus force and internally rotating the tibia during knee extension. The snap is produced as the torn fragment rides over the femoral condyle during extension. A snap in extreme flexion is indicative of a posterior horn tear; a click at 90° of flexion indicates a lesion in the middle section of the meniscus. Only 57% of meniscal root tears result in a positive McMurray test. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

While examining a patient in supine position, the examiner keeps his hand below the heel of one foot and asks the patient to flex the other hip against resistance, while keeping the week leg straight. This is known as Hoover’s sign.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a dimorphic fungus? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumocystis jirovecii

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii is not a dimorphic fungus, it is a yeast like organism that causes Pneumocystis pneumonia, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS.

 

Dimorphic fungi:

 

  • Dimorphic fungi are fungi that can exist in two different forms depending on the temperature.
  • At 25°C (room temperature), they grow in a mold (mycelial) form.
  • At 37°C (body temperature), they grow in a yeast form.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomyces dermatitidis: A dimorphic fungus causing blastomycosis.

 

Option B. Histoplasma capsulatum: A dimorphic fungus causing histoplasmosis.

 

Option D. Penicillium marneffei: A dimorphic fungus causing penicilliosis.

 

Educational Objective

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii is not a dimorphic fungus

 

Dimorphic fungi:

 

  • Blastomyces dermatitidis
  • Histoplasma capsulatum
  • Paracoccidioides brasiliensis
  • Penicillium marneffei
  • Sporothrix schenckii
  • Coccidioides immitis
  • Coccidioides posadasii

questions.text: A 37-year-old presented with fever. On examination, he had enlarged and ulcerated tonsils. His peripheral blood smear showed lymphocytosis. Monospot test was negative. Tonsillectomy was done and it showed large cells mixed with lymphocytes. The cells were positive for CD20, EB LMP1, MUM1, CD 79a. Background cells were positive for CD3. The cells are negative for CD15. Your most probable diagnosis is? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) EBV positive – DLBCL, NOS

 

The given clinical scenario suggests a likely diagnosis of EB positive DLBCL, NOS (Epstein Barr virus-positive Diffuse Large B Cell Lymphoma, not otherwise specified.

 

The given slide shows sheets of large lymphoid cells with irregular vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli typical of DLBCL.

 

Approach to the question:

 

  • Negative monospot test rules out the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis
  • Absence of Reed-Sternberg cell or its variants rules out Hodgkins lymphoma.
  • EBV-positive mucocutaneous ulcer is seen in immunocompromised individuals presenting as self-limiting ulcer which subsides on treatment. Biopsy will show atypical large B cells with RS cell-like morphology. Hence, this is cannot be the diagnosis.

 

EBV positive DLBCL (Diffuse Large B Cell Lymphoma)

 

  • Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common form of NHL.
  • Age > 50yrs
  • No past history of lymphoma
  • Presents as a rapidly enlarging mass at nodal or extra-nodal site.
  • Immunodeficiency-associated large B-cell lymphoma occurs in the setting of severe T-cell
  • immunodeficiency (e.g., advanced HIV infection and allogeneic bone marrow transplantation). The neoplastic B cells are usually infected with EBV, which plays a critical pathogenic role. Restoration of T-cell immunity may lead to regression of these proliferations
  • Immunohistochemistry is positive for CD 20, CD 79a, IRF4/MUM1. EBV LMP-1 (Latent membrane protein-1) is positive in about 2/3rd of cases, while EBNA-2 (Epstein-Barr nuclear antigen) is positive in the remaining 1/3rd of cases. It is negative for CD10 and BCL6.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hodgkin lymphoma: This diagnosis is less likely because Hodgkin lymphoma typically presents with Reed-Sternberg cells, which are positive for CD15 and CD30, not the immunophenotype seen in this case.

 

Option C. Infectious mononucleosis: This condition is ruled out by the negative Monospot test and the presence of large atypical cells positive for B cell markers, which are more indicative of lymphoma.

 

Option D. EBV positive mucocutaneous ulcer: This condition usually occurs in immunocompromised individuals and presents as a self-limiting ulcer. The biopsy may show atypical large B cells with RS cell-like morphology, but the clinical scenario and histopathological findings are more consistent with EBV positive DLBCL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most probable diagnosis for a patient with enlarged, ulcerated tonsils, lymphocytosis, a negative Monospot test, and immunohistochemical findings of CD20, EB LMP1, MUM1, and CD79a positivity is EBV positive Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma, NOS.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 1121-1123

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with signs of shock. The attending physician decides to calculate the Modified Shock Index to better assess the patient's condition and predict the risk of mortality. Which of the following parameters is used to calculate the Modified Shock Index?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HR/MAP

 

The Modified Shock Index (MSI) is calculated as Heart Rate (HR) divided by Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP). It has been shown to be a better predictor of mortality in patients with shock than the original Shock Index. MAP provides a more accurate assessment of tissue perfusion, as it reflects the overall blood pressure status more comprehensively than systolic blood pressure (SBP) alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HR/SBP: This is the original Shock Index, which calculates the ratio of heart rate to systolic blood pressure. While useful, the Modified Shock Index (HR/MAP) is considered a better predictor of patient outcomes.

 

Option B. HR/DBP: Diastolic blood pressure (DBP) is not used in the calculation of the Modified Shock Index.

 

Option D. PR/SBP: Pulse rate (PR) and systolic blood pressure (SBP) are not used together to calculate the Modified Shock Index.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Modified Shock Index (MSI) is calculated using heart rate (HR) divided by mean arterial pressure (MAP), and it is a more sensitive indicator of hemodynamic stability and mortality in shock compared to the original Shock Index (HR/SBP).
  • MAP provides a better assessment of tissue perfusion and disease severity in critically ill patients.

questions.text: Which of the following labelled structures of the scapula is palpable in the infraclavicular fossa? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation:

 

The part of the scapula marked as "A" in this image is palpable and it is the coracoid process.

 

The apex of the coracoid process lies approximately 2.5cm below the clavicle, immediately lateral to the infraclavicular fossa (deltopectoral triangle). Hence, the coracoid process can be palpated below the clavicle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. B- Acromion process - Located at the top of the shoulder, this process forms the highest point of the shoulder and serves as an attachment for the clavicle and muscles of the shoulder. It is not palpable in the infraclavicular fossa.

 

Option C. C- Glenoid fossa - This is the socket part of the scapula that articulates with the head of the humerus to form the shoulder joint. It is not palpable externally due to its deep location.

 

Option D. D- Infraspinous fossa - A broad surface on the posterior aspect of the scapula, covered largely by the infraspinatus muscle. It is not palpable from the anterior aspect of the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The coracoid process (marked as A) is the scapular structure that can be palpated in the infraclavicular fossa, just below the clavicle. This palpation is useful for clinical assessments related to shoulder injuries and muscular attachments.

choices.text: Slowly taper the drug over next 6 months
Continue levetiracetam since a 5-year seizure free interval is needed
Stop levetiracetam and start on a different anti-epileptic
Discontinue the drug as he is seizure free

questions.text: An epileptic patient on levetiracetam has been seizure-free for 2 years. But he develops agitation and anger issues interfering with his day-to-day activities as a result of the drug intake. Which of the following measures is to be taken next? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Slowly taper the drug over next 6 months

 

Levetiracetam is an antiepileptic drug that binds to SV2A on the vesicles and modulates the release of Neurotransmitters. It can cause anger, agitation and mood disturbances as a side effect. In such cases, the drug should be gradually tapered over the next 6 months, but not abruptly stopped as that might lead to rebound seizures.

 

Rationale for Tapering:

 

  • Side Effects: The patient is experiencing significant side effects (agitation and anger) that are interfering with daily activities.
  • Seizure-Free Period: While the patient has been seizure-free for 2 years, abruptly stopping the medication could lead to rebound seizures.
  • Gradual Tapering: Tapering the medication slowly over the next 6 months is a safer approach. It allows the patient's body to adjust and reduces the risk of withdrawal seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Continue levetiracetam since a 5-year seizure-free interval is needed: While a longer seizure-free interval might be ideal, continuing the medication despite significant side effects is not practical. The patient’s quality of life is important, and the side effects need to be addressed.

 

Option C. Stop levetiracetam and start on a different anti-epileptic: Abruptly stopping levetiracetam is not recommended due to the risk of withdrawal seizures. Switching to a different antiepileptic drug (AED) should be done cautiously, and often a cross-tapering strategy is used.

 

Option D. Discontinue the drug as he is seizure-free: Discontinuing the drug abruptly is not advisable, even if the patient has been seizure-free, because it could trigger rebound seizures. A gradual tapering is always preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a patient on levetiracetam experiences significant psychiatric side effects, the best approach is to slowly taper the medication over several months to prevent rebound seizures and address the side effects.

questions.text: A patient has a blood glucose level of 200 mg/dL and GFR of 90 ml/min. What is the amount of glucose excreted if the transport maximum of the patient is as shown below? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 30 mg/min

 

The amount of glucose excreted in the above scenario is 30 mg/min.

 

Calculation:

 

Step 1: Total filtered glucose calculated by GFR x Plasma glucose concentration

Here,

 

  • ﻿﻿GFR = 90 ml/min
  • ﻿﻿Plasma glucose concentration = 200 mg/dL= 2 mg/ml (1 dL=100 ml).
  • ﻿﻿Total filtered glucose = 90 ml/min X 2 mg/ml = 180 mg/min.

 

Step 2: Check transport maximum:

Here, as shown in the graph transport maximum is 150 mg/min.

 

Step 3: Calculate the excretion

 

  • Excretion = Total filtered glucose - Total reabsorbed glucose (Transport Maximum)
  • As calculated above, total filtered glucose is 180, Transport maximum is 150
  • = 180-150 mg/min = 30 mg/min is the excretion

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total filtered glucose=GFR × Plasma glucose concentration

Excretion=Total filtered glucose−Total reabsorbed glucose (Transport Max.)

choices.text: 90 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds
80 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds
100 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds
70 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds

questions.text: Which of the following fits into the criteria of severe variable deceleration, variations less than: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 70 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds.

 

Severe variable decelerations in fetal heart rate (FHR) are characterized by a significant reduction in the heart rate below the baseline. The specific criterion for a severe variable deceleration is when the heart rate drops below 70 beats per minute and this reduction persists for at least 60 seconds.

 

Variable decelerations are sudden decreases in the FHR that occur with or without contractions. They are commonly caused by umbilical cord compression, which impedes blood flow through the umbilical vein and arteries, leading to a reduction in fetal cardiac output. This type of deceleration is defined by a decrease of at least 15 beats per minute below the baseline and typically lasts between 15 seconds and less than 2 minutes.

 

Classification of Variable Decelerations:

 

  • Mild: Heart rate decreases to greater than 80 beats per minute regardless of duration, or decelerations lasting less than 30 seconds regardless of the heart rate, or heart rate between 70-80 beats per minute lasting less than 60 seconds.
  • Moderate: Heart rate decreases to more than 70 beats per minute for 30-60 seconds, or heart rate between 70-80 beats per minute lasting more than 60 seconds.
  • Severe: Heart rate decreases to less than 70 beats per minute for an extended duration (at least 60 seconds).

 

(70 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds) meets the criteria for severe variable deceleration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe variable decelerations are defined by a fetal heart rate dropping to less than 70 beats per minute for at least 60 seconds, typically due to umbilical cord compression.

choices.text: BCG, DPT-1, OPV-1, Measles - 1, Vit. A -1

questions.text: A pediatrician in a remote village encounters an 18-month-old child with no vaccination history. According to the National Immunization Schedule, which set of vaccines should the child receive? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) DPT-1, OPV-1, Measles -1, Vit. A - 1

 

  • According to India's National Immunization Schedule (NIS), an 18-month-old child who has not received any immunizations should be given their initial doses of DPT, OPV, measles vaccine, and vitamin A.

 

Age Limits for Delayed Immunization in NIS, India

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Case studies

questions.text: Bio-film confer resistance to antibiotics by all except? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adherence

 

Adherence is a mechanism of bacteria to attach to host cell for penetration. It is not a mechanism of resistance.

 

Mechanisms of biofilm-mediated resistance to antibiotics:

 

  • Mechanical barrier: The lipopolysaccharide biofilms prevent entry of water-soluble drugs.
  • Efflux pumps: These pumps on the biofilms actively excrete drug out.
  • Slow metabolism: Decreased oxygen and nutrients passage through the biofilms slows down the metabolism of bacteria.
  • Anaerobic pathway: Because of the above reason bacteria follow anaerobic metabolism.
  • Persisters: Some bacteria undergo phenotypic modification into dormant, spore-like structure and survive antibiotic insult. These are called as persisters which are activated later.
  • Enzymatic inactivation of drugs by biofilms
  • Genetic adaptation to antibiotic insults
  • Quorum sensing: It is cell to cell signaling among the bacteria to coordinate among themselves for contribution in biofilm synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mechanical barrier: Correct. Biofilms provide a physical barrier that prevents the entry of antibiotics.

 

Option B. Increased excretion of antibiotics: Correct. Efflux pumps in biofilms actively expel antibiotics, reducing their intracellular concentration.

 

Option C. Slow metabolism: Correct. The slow metabolic rate within biofilms makes bacteria less susceptible to antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biofilms confer resistance to antibiotics through mechanisms such as mechanical barriers, efflux pumps, slow metabolism, and the presence of persisters. Adherence, while important for colonization, does not contribute directly to antibiotic resistance within biofilms.

questions.text: Management of hyperkalemia includes all except : (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Magnesium sulphate

 

Magnesium sulfate is not typically used for the treatment of hyperkalemia. It is more commonly used in the management of eclampsia in pregnant women and for its neuromuscular blocking effects in various other medical conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

The management of hyperkalemia typically involves interventions that stabilize the cardiac membrane, shift potassium into cells, and remove potassium from the body. Common treatments include:

 

Option A. Calcium gluconate: Which stabilizes the cardiac membrane and does not lower potassium levels but protects the heart from the effects of hyperkalemia.

 

Option B. Insulin drip: Often accompanied by glucose, which drives potassium back into cells, thereby lowering its serum concentration.

 

Option  C. Salbutamol nebulization: A beta-agonist that promotes the movement of potassium into cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of hyperkalemia

 

  • Calcium gluconate- reduces plasma K+ concentration by redistribution in cells rapidly
  • Insulin- lowers plasma K+ concentration by moving potassium intracellular, insulin dose used – 10units of IV regular insulin f/b 50ml of 50%dextrose
  • Salbutamol
  • Cation exchange resins, diuretics, dialysis.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of high-grade fever & altered sensorium. He was diagnosed to be suffering from meningococcal meningitis. Which of the following is the most appropriate empirical treatment? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ceftriaxone

 

Ceftriaxone or cefotaxime is the drug of choice for empirical treatment of meningococcal meningitis. However, Penicillin G remains the antibiotic of choice for susceptible strains.

 

Empirical antimicrobial therapy is initiated in with patients with suspected bacterial meningitis before the results of CSF Gram stain and culture are known.

 

S. pneumoniae and N. meningitidis are the most common etiologic organism of community acquired bacterial meningitis. Due to the emergence of penicillin resistant and cephalosporin resistant S. pneumoniae, empirical therapy of community acquired suspected bacterial meningitis should include a combination of –

 

  • Dexamethasone
  • Third or fourth generation cephalosporin (E.g., ceftriaxone, cefotaxime or Cefepime)
  • Vancomycin
  • Acyclovir- HSV Encephalitis is the main differential
  • Doxycycline –during tick season

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penicillin G: While effective against Neisseria meningitidis, it is not the first choice for empirical treatment due to broader resistance concerns and coverage needs in initial therapy settings.

 

Option C. Cefotetan and D. Cefoxitin: These are second-generation cephalosporins, which are not typically used for the treatment of meningococcal meningitis due to insufficient CNS penetration and coverage compared to third-generation cephalosporins like ceftriaxone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ceftriaxone is the preferred empirical therapy for meningococcal meningitis due to its effective CNS penetration, broad antibacterial coverage, and favorable dosing regimen. Immediate initiation of empirical therapy is crucial in suspected bacterial meningitis to prevent severe outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in tumor lysis syndrome ? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypercalcemia 

 

Tumor lysis syndrome occurs due to destruction of large no of rapidly proliferating neoplstic cells. It is characterised by Hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia , hyperphosphasphatemia, hypocalcemia, acidosis, acute renal failure.

 

It mainly occurs after initiation of chemotherapy and is diagnosed by Cairo bishop criteria (includes both lab and clinical features)

 

Management includes - allopurinol , rasburicase along with aggressive hydration .

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperphosphatemia: Typically occurs as phosphate is released from lysed tumor cells.

 

Option B. Hyperuricemia: Results from the metabolism of nucleic acids from destroyed cells.

 

Option D. Hyperkalemia: Occurs due to the release of potassium from the intracellular to the extracellular space.

 

Educational Objective:


In tumor lysis syndrome, the rapid breakdown of tumor cells leads to hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia, making this the key distinguishing feature in identifying the condition. Management strategies like hydration, use of allopurinol, or rasburicase are critical in preventing renal failure and other serious complications.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male came with complaints of acute abdominal pain. A plain X-ray abdomen erect was taken which is shown below. What is likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pneumoperitoneum

 

Explanation:

 

The presence of subdiaphragmatic free gas in the right upper quadrant is clearly visible in the X-ray above. This is an indication of pneumoperitoneum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subdiaphragmatic abscess: Typically presents with localized fluid collections that may contain gas produced by bacteria, but the extensive free air pattern as seen in this X-ray is more characteristic of pneumoperitoneum.

 

Option C. Pneumopericardium: Involves air in the pericardial cavity, not typically visible as free air under the diaphragm.

 

Option D. Intestinal obstruction: May show air-fluid levels and dilated bowel loops, but the clear presence of free air under the diaphragm is distinctly indicative of pneumoperitoneum rather than an obstruction alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MOST SENSITIVE X RAY: CXR-PA erect

 

 

Air under the diaphragm-Right

 

  • MOST SENSITIVE Ix: CECT with oral contrast
  • NEXT STEP: Resuscitation with iv fluids, Exploratory laparotomy

questions.text: Glucosamine supplementation is given in:(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Arthritis

 

TREATMENT OF OSTEOARTHRITIS

 

  • Maintain movement and muscle strength by physiotherapy and graded muscle exercise.
  • Protects the joint from overload by giving rest and weight reduction.
  • Correction of deformities if present.
  • Thermal modalities, analgesic medication, wedged insoles, orthosis and arthroscopic debridement and lavage.
  • Progressive joint destruction require joint replacement in elderly and HTO in young.
  • Stages of osteoarthritis:

 

 

  • Classification system and stage-wise management for osteoarthritis (OA) knee:
    • Initial treatment is always conservative (exercise and glucosamine are preferred).
    • Clinical picture is more significant than radiology or X-ray changes.
    • If activities of daily living are affected, surgery is advised.
    • Surgery for young patients is high tibial osteotomy (HTO) (if not contraindicated), if contraindicated, total knee replacement (TKR) is performed.
    • Surgery for elderly (> 65 years) is TKR.
    • Usually for stage 2 onwards in elderly, TKR is finally carried out.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glucosamine supplementations are given in the treatment of osteoarthritis.

choices.text: EBM mandates that clinical decisions should exclusively rely on findings from high-quality randomized controlled trials, disregarding other forms of evidence.
EBM categorically negates the intrinsic value of accumulated clinical experience, positioning empirical research findings as the sole determinant of clinical practice.
EBM harmoniously amalgamates the clinician's individual expertise, accrued through years of practice, with the most robust and relevant external scientific evidence.
EBM emphasizes a dependency on recommendations primarily made by pharmaceutical companies, given their investment in large-scale research.

questions.text: A recent medical graduate is attending a seminar on Evidence-Based Medicine (EBM). The speaker emphasizes EBM's integrative approach to patient care. Which statement most accurately encapsulates the core philosophy of EBM? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) EBM harmoniously amalgamates the clinician's individual expertise, accrued through years of practice, with the most robust and relevant external scientific evidence

 

  • It integrates individual clinical expertise with the best external clinical evidence.
  • EBM is a combination of research evidence, clinical experience, and patient values/preferences.

 

 

  • Critical appraisal of research findings and decisions regarding whether, and how, to use findings in the care of patients

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EBM mandates that clinical decisions should exclusively rely on findings from high-quality randomized controlled trials, disregarding other forms of evidence: Incorrect. EBM values a combination of different types of evidence, including clinical expertise and patient preferences.

 

Option B. EBM categorically negates the intrinsic value of accumulated clinical experience, positioning empirical research findings as the sole determinant of clinical practice: Incorrect. EBM values clinical experience alongside empirical research findings.

 

Option D. EBM emphasizes a dependency on recommendations primarily made by pharmaceutical companies, given their investment in large-scale research: Incorrect. EBM focuses on unbiased, high-quality evidence rather than recommendations from potentially biased sources.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The core philosophy of Evidence-Based Medicine (EBM) is to integrate the clinician's expertise with the best available external evidence and patient values to make informed clinical decisions.

questions.text: A patient presents with endophthalmitis 5 days after cataract surgery. All of the following treatments can be used, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intravenous steroids

 

  • Intravenous steroids are not used for the treatment of endophthalmitis.
  • Endophthalmitis is an intraocular inflammation affecting the vitreous and/or the anterior chamber.
  • Etiology: exogenous infection (trauma, surgery), endogenous or metastatic endophthalmitis, secondary infections from surrounding structures.
  • Cardinal features: pain, lid swelling, diminished vision.
  • Maintain high index of suspicion, especially in postoperative cases, and treat empirically with antibiotics and steroids from the beginning.

 

Treatment

 

All cases are treated empirically with a combination of broad-spectrum antibiotics and corticosteroids from the beginning. The aim is to maintain a high intraocular concentration of antibiotics throughout treatment.

 

  • Therapeutic regimen 
    • Topical antibiotics: Fortified cefazolin or vancomycin with gentamicin or amikacin.
    • Topical atropine: for cycloplegia.
    • Subconjunctival antibiotics: not frequently used.
    • Intravitreal antibiotics: The treatment of choice and are injected after taking vitreous aspirate for preparing smears and obtaining cultures. A combination of vancomycin and ceftazidime is preferred. Amikacin or gentamicin is used less frequently (risk of macular infarction). Simultaneous injection of dexamethasone is optional.
    • Intravitreal injection of amphotericin B: In suspected fungal aetiology, without the use of any adjunctive steroids.
    • Oral antifungals: Given, if fungal cultures are positive.
    • Vitrectomy: Hastens bacterial and fungal endophthalmitis recovery.
    • Corticosteroids: 
      • Some authorities recommend the combined use of corticosteroids from the outset (unless there is a strong clinical suspicion of a fungal aetiology in which case steroids should be withheld), while others prefer to wait for a confirmed positive clinical response to antibiotic therapy before administering steroids over the next 24–48 hours.
      • The rationale for corticosteroid therapy derives from its anti-inflammatory effects, leading to preservation of the ocular structures.
      • Routes of administration are:
        1. Intravitreal injection of dexamethasone
        2. Subconjunctival injection of dexamethasone
        3. Topical dexamethasone or predacetate
        4. Oral prednisolone
    • Patients need to be reviewed every 4–8 hours. The visual outcome depends on the duration between the onset of infection and institution of therapy, and the nature of the infecting organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A Intravitreal antibiotic injection: This is a standard treatment for endophthalmitis, involving direct administration of antibiotics into the eye to quickly achieve high intraocular concentrations, crucial for combating the infection.

 

Option C. Pars plana vitrectomy: Often recommended for severe cases, this surgical intervention can remove infectious agents and inflammatory debris directly from the vitreous, thereby reducing bacterial load and improving drug penetration.

 

Option D. Topical antibiotic: Used to provide high local concentrations of antibiotics at the site of infection, though not sufficient alone for severe cases, they support the main treatment regimen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For endophthalmitis following ocular surgery, intravitreal antibiotics are crucial, while systemic steroids are generally avoided due to the risk of exacerbating the infection.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes the following disease? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coxsackievirus

 

The image shows vesicles on the palms, soles, and oral mucosa, consistent with hand-foot-and-mouth disease. It is caused by coxsackievirus.

 

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is an exanthematous fever affecting mainly young children, characterized by oral and pharyngeal ulcerations and a vesicular rash of the palms and soles that may spread to the arms and legs. Vesicles heal without crusting, which clinically differentiates them from the vesicles of herpesviruses and poxviruses. It is usually a benign illness resolving in 1-2 weeks.

 

Coxsackie A16, A9, and B 1-3 are common causative agents.

 

Other diseases caused by Coxsackie A virus:

 

  • Aseptic meningitis associated with a maculopapular rash.
  • Herpangina
  • Minor respiratory infections

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Human herpes virus 7: Associated with roseola infantum, not HFMD.

 

Option C. Pox virus: Causes diseases like smallpox and molluscum contagiosum, characterized by different types of lesions.

 

Option D. Molluscum contagiosum: Causes dome-shaped, pearly lesions with central umbilication, distinct from HFMD vesicles.

 

Educational Objective

 

Coxsackievirus is the causative agent of hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD), which presents with vesicles on the palms, soles, and oral mucosa.

 

Palms and Soles rash is seen in – CARS

 

  1. Coxsackievirus A16
  2. Rocky mountain spotted fever
  3. Secondary Syphilis

questions.text: In the histological section of a lymph node shown below, the area indicated by the yellow arrow corresponds to which of the following zones? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Mantle zone

 

The area marked in the above image is the mantle zone of a lymph node.

 

The mantle zone is produced as surrounding cells are marginalized by the rapidly growing germinal centre. It is populated by mainly quiescent B cells with condensed heterochromatic nuclei and little cytoplasm (hence the deeply basophilic staining of this region in routine preparations), a few helper T cells, Follicular Dendritic cells and macrophage

 

Lymph node has a primary follicle composed of small, quiescent lymphocytes, and a secondary follicle with a germinal centre composed mainly of antigen-stimulated B cells.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In peripheral lymph nodes, the marginal zone is often inappropriate because they are mixed with the mantle zone cells. And often not well developed in lymph nodes.

 

Option B. The paracortex lies between the cortical follicles and the medulla and is populated mainly by T cells, which are not organized into follicles

 

Option C. Germinal Center located within secondary follicles and is primarily composed of rapidly dividing antigen-stimulated B cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mantle zone in lymph nodes is a critical area populated by B cells surrounding the germinal centers, playing a key role in the adaptive immune response by providing a site for B cell quiescence and interaction with helper T cells and antigen-presenting cells.

questions.text: Sprengel’s deformity associated with all except: (INICET Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Dextrocardia

 

SPRENGEL’S DEFORMITY

 

  • It consists of permanent elevation of the shoulder girdle due to developmental defect.
  • The scapula is smaller in its vertical diameter and appears broad. It lies high in position.

 

 

  • Para scapular muscles are composed of imperfectly developed muscle fibers or fibrous tissue.
  • From the superior angle of scapula a sheet or band-like structure composed of fibrous tissue cartilage or bone extends upwards to attach to the transverse process of several cervical vertebrae known as Omovertebral bar.

 

 

  • It is associated with Klippel-Feil Syndrome/Scoliosis/Spina bifida (Diastematomyelia)/Cervical rib.
  • Clinical Feature: Shoulder and the scapula at a higher level than the opposite one, restriction of shoulder movement.
  • Treatment: There is no definitive treatment available. Surgery (Woodward procedure) is done for cosmetic reasons only.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dextrocardia is rarely associated with Sprengel’s Deformity.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with heartburn and increased salivation. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy was done, and the biopsy result is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Barrett’s esophagus

 

This image indicates the diagnostic features of Barrett's esophagus. Note the transition between esophageal squamous mucosa and Barrett metaplasia, with abundant metaplastic goblet cells.

 

 

Barrett's esophagus is a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) characterized by intestinal metaplasia within the esophageal squamous mucosa. It is a premalignant condition that confers an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

 

Hence, patients diagnosed with Barrett's Esophagus require that periodic endoscopy with biopsy, for detection of dysplasia every 1-2 years to detect dysplasias.

 

The presence of dysplasia is associated with prolonged symptoms, longer segment length, increased patient age, and Caucasian

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophagitis: While esophagitis, inflammation of the esophagus, may be seen in GERD, it does not show the characteristic intestinal metaplasia with goblet cells as seen in Barrett's esophagus.

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type of cancer originates from the squamous cells of the esophagus and does not involve the metaplastic changes characteristic of Barrett's esophagus.

 

Option C. Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma of the esophagus can develop from Barrett's esophagus, but the histological image provided is more consistent with the premalignant stage of Barrett's esophagus rather than adenocarcinoma itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barrett's esophagus is a premalignant condition marked by intestinal metaplasia with goblet cells within the esophageal squamous mucosa, requiring regular surveillance for dysplasia and potential progression to adenocarcinoma.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 1464

questions.text: Glucosamines are used in which of the following conditions? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arthritis

 

Glucosamine and chondroitin sulphate are used in the treatment of arthritis which is a degenerative joint disease.

 

Glucosamines are amino sugars. Mucopolysaccharides or glycosamino glycans (GAG) are heteropolysaccharides, containing uronic acid and amino sugars. Acetylated amino groups, sulfate and carboxyl groups are also generally present. Because of the presence of these charged groups, they attract water molecules and so they produce viscous solutions.

 

Examples of mucopolysaccharides are hyaluronic acid, heparin, chondroitin sulfate, dermatan sulfate and keratan sulfate.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Niemann-Pick disease: This is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by the accumulation of sphingomyelin, not treated with glucosamines.

 

Option C. Alzheimer's disease: This neurodegenerative condition involves the accumulation of amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. Glucosamines are not used in its treatment.

 

Option D. Cancer: Cancer treatment involves a wide range of therapies such as chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and immunotherapy. Glucosamines are not used in cancer treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucosamine is used in the treatment of arthritis due to its role in maintaining healthy cartilage and joint function.

questions.text:
Dr. Geeta, a senior epidemiologist in Delhi, receives weekly updates on the prevalence of several diseases in the states/region she oversees. Recently, she noticed distinct patterns in three different diseases over a two-week period: [AIIMS NOV 2017]

 

Disease 1: Number of cases last week = 42, this week = 43

 

Disease 2: Number of cases last week 2 and present week 42

 

Disease 3: Number of cases last week 6 and present week 1

 

How should these diseases be categorized?
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Endemic, epidemic, sporadic

 

Disease 1 - The similarity of the cases suggests that it must be endemic.

 

Disease 2 - The surge in case numbers is deeply concerning, suggesting the potential emergence of an epidemic.

 

Disease 3 - The decrease in the number of cases has occurred without a clear explanation, suggesting that it may be sporadic in nature. An epidemic, on the other hand, is characterized by the occurrence of a disease at a rate exceeding the expected frequency.

 

Endemic

 

  • Constant presence of a disease or infectious agent in a defined geographical area. It is the usual or expected frequency’ of a disease in a population
  • Types of Endemic:
  • Hyper-endemic: Constant presence of a disease or infectious agent at high incidence/prevalence AND affects all age groups equally
  • Holo-endemic: A high level of infection beginning early in life AND affecting most of the children population

 

Pandemic

 

  • An epidemic usually affecting a large proportion of the population, occurring over a large geographical area such as part of a nation, nation, continent or world (Country-to-country spread)

 

Sporadic

 

  • Cases which are ‘scattered about’
    • Cases are widely separated in space and time
    • Show little or no connection with each other
    • There is no recognizable source of infection

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endemic diseases show a stable presence, epidemics show a sudden increase in cases, and sporadic diseases occur irregularly.

questions.text: A 25yr old woman came to OPD one year after the birth of her last child. She had been treated for iron deficiency anemia while pregnant. On examination, she is pale, and investigations show a HB of 5mg/dl and a reticulocyte count of 9%. What is her corrected reticulocyte count ? (take normal Hb as 15mg/dl) (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3

 

Corrected reticulocyte count (CRC)= reticulocyte % X (actual Hb/normal Hb)

 

CRC= 9 X 5/15 = 3%

 

CRC can also be calculated using hematocrit

 

CRC= Reticulocyte % X (Actual PCV/ normal PCV )

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corrected reticulocyte count (CRC) adjusts the observed reticulocyte percentage to reflect the degree of anemia by using the patient's actual hemoglobin compared to a normal hemoglobin level.

 

The corrected reticulocyte count is crucial for assessing bone marrow response in anemic patients, providing insight into whether the bone marrow is responding appropriately to the anemia. This is particularly important in managing patients with iron deficiency anemia to monitor recovery or response to therapy.

choices.text: Low MSAFP, high hCG, low UE3
High MSAFP, low hCG, high UE3
Low MSAFP, high hCG, high UE3
High MSAFP, low hCG, low UE3

questions.text: A pregnant woman has a fetus with Down's syndrome. Triple test done at 15-16 weeks will have? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Low MSAFP, high hCG, low UE3

 

Explanation:

 

The triple and quadruple test is done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

 

 

*Easy to remember: B for Big; so in Down’s syndrome; Beta hCG and InhiBin A: Big/ Increased

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triple test results for Down's syndrome typically show low MSAFP, high hCG, and low uE3.

 

Ref: Page 859, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Is coenzyme for pyruvate and alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
Interferes with energy production from amino acids

questions.text: Thiamine deficiency results in decreased energy production, because TPP? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Is coenzyme for pyruvate and alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

 

Pyruvate and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase use Thiamine as a co-enzyme to produce ATP using NADH.

 

Thiamine also acts as a coenzyme for transketolase in the pentose phosphate pathway (HMP shunt) but there is no ATP generation here, hence option C is correct.

 

Physiological Role of Thiamine:

 

  1. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: The co-enzyme form is thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP). It is used in oxidative decarboxylation of alpha keto acids, e.g. pyruvate dehydrogenase catalyzes the breakdown of pyruvate, to acetyl CoA, and carbon dioxide
  2. Alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: An analogous biochemical reaction that requires TPP is the oxidative decarboxylation of alpha ketoglutarate to succinyl CoA and CO2
  3. Transketolase: The second group of enzymes that use TPP as co-enzyme are the transketolases, in the hexose monophosphate shunt pathway of glucose. 
  4. The main role of thiamine (TPP) is in carbohydrate metabolism. So, the requirement of thiamine is increased along with higher intake of carbohydrates

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interferes with alcohol metabolism: While thiamine is important for alcohol metabolism, the primary reason for decreased energy production in thiamine deficiency is its role in the citric acid cycle, not alcohol metabolism.

 

Option B. Interferes with transketolase activity: Although TPP is a coenzyme for transketolase, this enzyme operates in the pentose phosphate pathway, which does not generate ATP.

 

Option D. Interferes with energy production from amino acids: Thiamine's primary role is in carbohydrate metabolism through its function in the citric acid cycle, not directly in amino acid metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiamine deficiency leads to decreased energy production because thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) is a critical coenzyme for pyruvate and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase in the citric acid cycle, essential for ATP generation.

questions.text: All are features of Zika Fever except? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Petechial rash

 

Petechial rash is not a feature of Zika Virus. Though petechia may rarely appear in Zika virus disease it is however not included in the CDC case definition of Zika virus disease.

 

Petechial rash points towards a diagnosis of Dengue fever while a maculopapular rash suggests a Zika virus disease.

 

Petechial rash is not typically associated with Zika virus infection. It is more commonly associated with Dengue fever, where petechiae (small red or purple spots caused by bleeding into the skin) are a common feature.

 

Zika virus infection is characterized by influenza-like clinical signs including fever, headache and malaise. A maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, myalgia and arthralgia usually accompany or follow those manifestations.

 

The complications of Zika virus are:

 

  • Gullian Barre Syndrome
  • Fetal microcephaly in pregnant women.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Guillain-Barre syndrome: Zika virus has been linked to Guillain-Barre syndrome, which can cause severe muscle weakness and even paralysis.

 

Option C. Fever with arthritis: Fever with arthritis or arthralgia is a common feature of Zika virus infection.

 

Option D. Conjunctivitis: Conjunctivitis (red eyes) is a frequent symptom of Zika virus infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zika fever typically presents with a maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, fever, and arthralgia, and it can be complicated by Guillain-Barre syndrome. Petechial rash is not a common feature and is more indicative of Dengue fever.

choices.text: Esilon Amino Caproic Acid

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used as an antidote for fibrinolytic therapy? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Esilon Amino Caproic Acid

 

Fibrinolytic therapy, also known as thrombolytic therapy, is used to dissolve blood clots. Sometimes, it is necessary to reverse the effects of fibrinolytic drugs, especially in cases of excessive bleeding.

 

Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid (EACA):

 

  • Mechanism of Action: Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid is an antifibrinolytic agent. It works by binding to plasminogen competitively, which prevents plasminogen from binding to fibrin and being converted to plasmin. Plasmin is an enzyme responsible for breaking down fibrin in blood clots. By inhibiting this process, EACA effectively stops fibrinolysis and stabilizes blood clots, reducing the risk of bleeding.
  • Clinical Use: EACA is used to treat conditions where fibrinolysis is excessive, such as after the administration of fibrinolytic drugs (e.g., streptokinase, alteplase).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protamine: Protamine is used to neutralize the anticoagulant effects of heparin. It is not effective against fibrinolytic agents. Protamine binds to heparin, forming a stable complex that neutralizes heparin's anticoagulant activity.

 

Option B. Streptokinase: Streptokinase is itself a fibrinolytic agent used to dissolve clots. It works by converting plasminogen to plasmin, which then breaks down fibrin. Streptokinase would increase fibrinolysis, not inhibit it.

 

Option C. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant that works by inhibiting thrombin and other clotting factors. It does not act as an antidote to fibrinolytic therapy. Heparin would actually increase the risk of bleeding if administered during fibrinolytic therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid is the appropriate antidote for fibrinolytic therapy because it inhibits fibrinolysis by preventing the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, thereby stabilizing blood clots and reducing bleeding risks.

questions.text: Best method of diagnosis for Clostridium difficile? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Toxin gene detection by PCR

 

Nucleic acid amplification tests, including PC assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool have been approved for diagnostic purposes of Clostridium difficile infection due to high sensitivity, specificity and rapid turnaround time.

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

 

  1. Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause plus
  2. Toxin A or B detected in the stool, toxin- producing C. difficile detected in the stool by PCR or ELISA, or pseudo membranes seen in the colon.

 

Other diagnostic methods include:

 

  • Stool Culture in selective media
  • Demonstrating Toxin by Hep-2 cell cultures
  • Toxin gene identification by Enzyme immunoassay
  • Colonscopy or sigmoidoscopy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pure strain isolation from culture: Stool culture on selective media can identify C. difficile. However, it is not the best method due to longer turnaround times and the need for specialized techniques. It is highly sensitive but less practical for rapid diagnosis. Also the mere presence of clostridium difficile does not suggest infection with the organism unless toxin production is checked.

 

Option B. Immunofluorescence:

Immunofluorescence can be used for detecting C. difficile antigens. It is less commonly used due to the complexity of the procedure and lower sensitivity compared to PCR.

 

Option D. Toxin Detection by ELISA: ELISA can detect toxins in stool samples. Although it is a useful method, it is less sensitive and specific compared to PCR, making it a secondary choice for diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best method for diagnosing Clostridium difficile infection is through nucleic acid amplification tests, such as PCR assays, which detect the toxin A or B genes in stool due to their high sensitivity, specificity, and rapid turnaround time.

questions.text: A 15-day-old infant had conjunctivitis, which later developed into respiratory distress and pneumonia. Chest X-ray examination revealed bilateral lung infiltrates. Peripheral smear count showed 14,300/ML (N 43, L 54, and E3). Which of the following is the most likely pathogenic organism? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chlamydia trachomatis

 

The most likely organism causing the infections described in this case is Chlamydia trachomatis. Infants born to women with active, untreated chlamydial infections are at risk of acquiring C. trachomatis, which can lead to neonatal conjunctivitis and pneumonia. The latter is characterized by an insidious onset of symptoms, generally appearing between 1 and 3 months of age.

 

Key clinical features of C. trachomatis pneumonia include a persistent cough, tachypnea (rapid breathing), and the absence of fever, which are typical in affected infants. On auscultation, rales (abnormal breath sounds) are commonly noted, but wheezing is rare, helping to distinguish this type of pneumonia from other respiratory infections such as those caused by respiratory syncytial virus (RSV).

 

Laboratory findings often include peripheral eosinophilia (eosinophil count >400 cells/µL), which is a distinctive marker of C. trachomatis pneumonia in infancy. Chest radiographs commonly show hyperinflation of the lungs with minimal interstitial or alveolar infiltrates, which are consistent findings in this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Streptococcus pneumoniae: While Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common cause of pneumonia in children, it is less likely in this case because the onset is typically more acute and associated with high fever. Moreover, this bacterium does not usually cause conjunctivitis.

 

Option C. Neisseria gonorrhoeae: This pathogen can cause neonatal conjunctivitis, but it is less likely to cause pneumonia. Moreover, Neisseria gonorrhoeae typically causes a more severe conjunctivitis within the first few days of life, not at 15 days of age.

 

Option D. Mycoplasma pneumoniae: Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common cause of atypical pneumonia in older children and young adults, but it is very uncommon in infants. It also does not typically present with the characteristic features described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chlamydia trachomatis can cause neonatal conjunctivitis and pneumonia, typically presenting with an insidious onset of cough, tachypnea, absence of fever, and peripheral eosinophilia in infants aged 1 to 3 months.

questions.text: A young boy was brought to the casualty with a history of fever and acute right lower abdominal pain. On examination, he was febrile and his pulse rate was 106 beats/min. Tenderness was felt in right iliac fossa. The CT scan image is shown below. Which of the following signs will not be seen in this disease? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ballance sign

 

The patient's history and CT findings are indicative of acute appendicitis. Ballance sign is not seen in acute appendicitis.

 

Ballance's sign is seen in splenic trauma, where dullness is seen on right flank on percussion, which doesn’t shift on lateral position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. McBurney's tenderness: Deep tenderness at McBurney's point, known as McBurney's sign, is a sign of acute appendicitis. McBurney's point is a point at one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine and umbilicus.

 

Option B. Rovsing sign: Rovsing sign is seen in appendicitis. Deep palpation of the left iliac fossa causes pain in the right iliac fossa.

 

Option C. Psoas sign: Psoas sign is seen in appendicitis. Sometimes, the inflamed appendix lies on the psoas muscle, and the patient, often a young adult, will lie with the right hip flexed, for pain relief.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Findings on CT that are suggestive of acute appendicitis include:

 

  • Appendiceal dilatation (>6 mm in diameter)
  • Appendiceal wall thickening (>3 mm) and enhancement

choices.text: Cell cycle will stop at G2
Cell cycle will stop at G1
There will be no effect on cell cycle as RB gene phosphorylation is not needed
The cell cycle progresses and cell divides

questions.text: If the RB gene is hypophosphorylated, which of the following will happen? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cell cycle will stop at G1

 

If the retinoblastoma (RB) gene is hypophosphorylated, then cell cycle will stop at G1.

 

The Rb protein is a tumor suppressor, which plays a pivotal role in the negative control of the cell cycle and in tumor progression. It has been shown that Rb protein (pRb) is responsible for a major G1 checkpoint, blocking S-phase entry and cell growth by binding to and inactivating a transcription factor (E2F). The phosphorylation of RB results in the release of E2F activating gene transcription and cell-cycle progression occurs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cell cycle will stop at G2: This is incorrect because the Rb protein specifically regulates the G1 to S phase transition, not the G2 phase.

 

Option C. There will be no effect on cell cycle as RB gene phosphorylation is not needed: This is incorrect. The phosphorylation state of the Rb protein is crucial for its function in regulating the cell cycle. Hypophosphorylated Rb actively suppresses cell cycle progression at G1.

 

Option D. The cell cycle progresses and cell divides: This is incorrect because the hypophosphorylated form of Rb prevents the cell from progressing past the G1 phase, thereby halting cell division.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hypophosphorylated state of the Rb protein prevents the cell cycle from progressing past the G1 phase by binding to and inactivating E2F, thereby acting as a crucial checkpoint in preventing uncontrolled cell proliferation.

choices.text: Check radial pulse by displacing the cast

questions.text: Earliest way to detect development of compartment syndrome by a nurse in a patient with cast is:(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Decreased response to analgesia

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndromes, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.
  • Most commonly, compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).
  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.
  • Most common cause is fractures and dislocations.
  • Other causes are:
    • Crush injury/Burn/Infection/Surgical procedure/Tight circumferential dressing
    • Exercise: Exercise may increase intracompartmental pressure and muscle edema, so it is avoided in cases of acute compartmental syndrome.
  • Clinical Features:
    • The diagnosis of compartment syndrome is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.
    • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) (1st sign).
    • The pain is unrelieved with opioid analgesia.
    • In compartment syndrome, the order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intracompartmental pressure is: Capillary compression, venous compression, arterial compression.
    • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome.
    • The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
    • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.
    • Pressures in the deep volar compartment are significantly elevated compared with pressures in other compartments.
    • Deep flexor muscles are involved, particularly flexor digitorum profundus > flexor pollicis longus.
  • Treatment: 
    • The limb should be kept at the level of heart rather than elevated.
    • Removal of all circumferential dressing reduce pressure up to 85%.
    • Fasciotomy is recommended in the presence of clinical signs of compartment syndrome, such as undue pain and a palpable firmness in the forearm.
    • The morbidity caused by fasciotomy is minimal, whereas that caused by an untreated compartment syndrome is much greater.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Check radial pulse by displacing the cast. Pulselessness is the late feature to appear in compartment syndrome. It is not a reliable indicator for the presence of the condition.

 

Option C. Change in colour of fingers. This can occur due to vascular insufficiency but is an uncommon entity.

 

Option D. Change in odor. This is not usually observed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The earliest way to detect compartment syndrome in a patient is a decreased response to the analgesics. The patient will complaint of no reduction in the pain symptoms.

questions.text: A young man had a fall on his outstretched hand, presented to the hospital with pain on the radial side of wrist and swelling in the anatomical snuff box. X-ray showed the following findings. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Scaphoid fracture

 

SCAPHOID FRACTURE

 

  • Scaphoid is the most commonly fractured bone in the carpus, in adult as well as children.
  • Scaphoid fracture is seen most commonly in males between the ages of 15 and 30.
  • Middle third (waist) fractures are most common accounting for 70% of scaphoid fractures > proximal pole fracture (20%) > distal pole fracture (10%), in adults and adolescents.
  • Distal pole avulsion type fracture is most common fracture type in children.
  • Salient Features:
    • Most of the blood supply to the scaphoid enters distally, so blood supply of scaphoid diminishes proximally. This accounts for the fact that 1% of distal third, 20% of middle third, 40% of proximal third and 100% of proximal pole fractures result in avascular necrosis or non-union of the proximal fragment.
    • A delay in diagnosis and treatment of this fracture may alter the prognosis for union.
    • A wrist sprain that is sufficiently severe to require radiographic examination initially should be treated as a possibe fracture of the scaphoid, and radiographs should be repeated in 2 weeks even though initial radiographs may be negative.
    • Fullness and tenderness in anatomical snuff box. Proximal pressure along the axis of the thumb may be painful.
  • Radiological Investigations:
    • Recent fracture shows only in the oblique view.
    • MRI can diagnose occult fractures.
    • MRI, especially with gadolinium enhancement, also is useful in assessing the vascularity of a fractured scaphoid.
  • Management:
    • Non-displaced, stable scaphoid fractures: Scaphoid glass holding cast

 

  • Displaced, unstable scaphoid fractures: Headless screw (Herbert) is used
  • Complication: Non-union > Avascular necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trans-scaphoid perilunate disruption fracture. Trans-scaphoid fracture-dislocation is an unusual traumatic injury mainly seen in young patients due to high energy trauma. These dislocations may be missed in 25% of cases. If it is neglected, it leads to progress of carpal instability and post-traumatic arthritis. The treatment aims at reducing dislocation, internally fixing fracture, and repairing ligament injuries. In the acute period, there is pain and swelling over the hand and wrist, and gross deformity of the wrist can be noted. Evidence of median nerve injury is common. Acute carpal tunnel syndrome is observed in about 25% of patients. Radiographs of the contralateral wrist for comparison can be helpful to confirm scapholunate widening, also called a ‘Terry Thomas sign.’

 

 

 

Terry Thomas Sign
