Option C. Hook of hamate fracture. Hook of hamate fractures are rare, often missed injuries generally as a result of a direct blow to the hamate bone. It is most commonly seen in athletes. Mechanism of injury is a direct blow to the volar proximal palm. Ulnar-sided wrist pain is the most common complaint, hypothenar pain, pain with activities requiring tight grip. On examination, there is limited ulnar deviation and decreased grip strength. Diagnosis is confirmed with radiographic carpal tunnel view or CT scan. Treatment is either observation, surgical excision, or surgical fixation depending on the severity of the symptoms and activity demands of the patient.

 

 

Option D. Distal radius fracture. Distal radius fractures are the most common injury, resulting from fall on an outstretched hand. It is more common in older patients with osteoporosis due to fall. The patient presents with wrist pain, swelling, and deformity.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given x-ray, mechanism of injury, and presenting complaints of the patient points towards the diagnosis of scaphoid fracture.

questions.text: X, Y, Z are three permeable ions. X = -50 and Y = -30. At RMP, if there is no net electrogenic transfer, what is the value of Z? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) + 80

 

No net electrogenic transfer at RMP implies that X + Y + Z = 0

 

So, - 50 + (-30) + Z =0

 

Z = 50 + 30 = 80

 

Educational Objective:

 

No net electrogenic transfer at resting membrane potential (RMP) implies that the sum of the equilibrium potentials of the ions is zero

questions.text: Which of the following, all are findings of the condition in the below chest X-ray except: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pulmonary venous hypertension

 

The chest X-ray provided shows the characteristic "egg-on-a-string" appearance, which is indicative of Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA). In TGA, the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle, leading to parallel circulation. This is a severe congenital heart defect that requires immediate attention.

 

In TGA, the following findings are seen:

 

  • Right atrial enlargement: This occurs due to increased venous return to the right side of the heart, as blood from the body is directed to the right atrium and ventricle, which then pumps it to the aorta and systemic circulation. This enlargement is visible on the X-ray.
  • Narrow vascular pedicle: The "string" appearance of the mediastinum is due to a narrow vascular pedicle, which is a common radiographic finding in TGA. This narrowness results from the abnormal positioning and arrangement of the great arteries.
  • Increased pulmonary blood flow: Depending on the presence and size of any associated shunts (like a patent ductus arteriosus or a ventricular septal defect), there can be increased pulmonary blood flow, which is often observed in cases of TGA.

 

However, pulmonary venous hypertension is not a typical finding in TGA. Pulmonary venous hypertension is usually seen in conditions that increase pressure in the pulmonary veins, such as left heart failure or mitral valve disease. It is not characteristic of TGA, where the primary issue is with the arteries and not the pulmonary veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased pulmonary blood flow: This can occur in TGA, especially if there is a shunt allowing some oxygenated blood to reach the systemic circulation.

 

Option B. Narrow vascular pedicle: The "string" part of the "egg-on-a-string" appearance refers to the narrow mediastinum, which is due to the narrow vascular pedicle, a common finding in TGA.

 

Option C. Right atrial enlargement: Right atrial enlargement: Enlargement of the right atrium is seen in TGA due to the abnormal circulation pattern but is a rare feature.
Both atria can enlarge in TGA, but left predominates
With mixing lesions (VSD, ASD), right atrial enlargement can happen

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "egg-on-a-string" appearance on a chest X-ray is characteristic of Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA), and pulmonary venous hypertension is not a typical finding in this condition.

﻿﻿﻿Superior vena-caval syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Abdominal aorta syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Supine vena cava syndrome

questions.text: A pregnant lady with PIH was being monitored with bed rest in supine position. Which of the following is a complication of the below representation? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supine vena cava syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

The image illustrates supine hypotension syndrome, also known as supine vena cava syndrome. This condition occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy when the gravid uterus compresses the inferior vena cava (IVC) while the woman is in a supine position. This compression leads to reduced venous return to the heart, causing hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope. It is especially dangerous during cesarean sections, as spinal anesthesia can exacerbate hypotension. To prevent this, a wedge is placed beneath the right hip during the procedure to tilt the patient slightly to the left, thereby relieving pressure on the vena cava.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ascending aorta syndrome: This condition is not typically associated with pregnancy and does not involve the pressure of the gravid uterus on the IVC.

 

Option B. Superior vena-caval syndrome: This syndrome involves obstruction of the superior vena cava, leading to symptoms such as facial swelling and dyspnea. It is unrelated to the position of a pregnant woman and the compression of the IVC.

 

Option C. Abdominal aorta syndrome: There is no specific syndrome by this name. The abdominal aorta may be compressed during pregnancy, but it does not lead to the symptoms associated with supine hypotension syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supine vena cava syndrome occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy due to the pressure of the gravid uterus on the inferior vena cava when the woman is in a supine position, leading to hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope.

 

Ref: Page no 2237, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with fever, weight loss came to the hospital. On examination, he was pale and had significant lymphadenopathy. The bone marrow histology of the person is as given below. Your diagnosis is: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia

 

The given scenario with bone marrow histology showing lymphoblasts (condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, scanty agranular cytoplasm) is suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

 

 

PBF Findings in acute lymphoblastic (ALL). The cell is large, with round to convoluted nuclei having high N/C ratio and no cytoplasmic granularity.

 

ALL is more common in childhood.

 

Clinical features of ALL include:

 

  • Bone marrow failure - anemia, fever, infections, bleeding
  • Mass effects due to neoplastic infiltration - bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement
  • CNS manifestations - headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies
  • B-ALL - Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement
  • T-ALL - Mediastinal mass, compression of large vessels and airways in the mediastinum, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute monocytic leukemia and Option B. Acute myelomonocytic leukemia: These leukemias typically present with different morphologic features, including monoblasts and myeloblasts, which show different cytological characteristics such as cytoplasmic granularity and different nuclear morphology.

 

Option D. Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML): JMML is a rare childhood leukemia with a different clinical presentation, often including hepatosplenomegaly and elevated monocyte counts, and it does not present with the lymphoblast morphology seen in ALL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) in children is characterized by the presence of lymphoblasts in the bone marrow and peripheral blood, along with clinical features of bone marrow failure and organ infiltration by malignant cells.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 1113

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes with a history of postcoital bleeding and a visible mass seen in cervix per speculum. The next step to be done? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Targeted biopsy

 

A targeted biopsy (punch biopsy) is the next line of management in the above case as the patient is symptomatic (postcoital bleeding) and has a visible lesion. This approach allows for the direct sampling of the lesion to assess for malignancy or other pathological changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conisation: Conisation is an excisional procedure that is typically performed once biopsy-proven cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN 2 and 3) is diagnosed. It is not the initial step for a visible mass with postcoital bleeding.

 

Option B. Cryotherapy: Cryotherapy is an ablative procedure used for treating CIN1 or 2. It is not suitable for initial diagnosis or for lesions suspected of being malignant.

 

Option D. Pap smear: A Pap smear is done when there are symptoms with no identifiable lesion. It is a screening tool and not diagnostic for a visible lesion with postcoital bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a symptomatic patient with a visible cervical lesion and postcoital bleeding, a targeted biopsy is the appropriate next step to obtain a definitive diagnosis.

 

Ref: Page 327, DC Dutta’a Textbook of gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with involuntary dancing movements of his right hand. He was diagnosed with rheumatic fever. What constitutes the ganglia involved in the presenting complication? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Caudate nucleus and putamen

 

Sydenham chorea is considered to be an autoimmune disease that is triggered by a streptococci infection, subsequently resulting in a hypersensitivity humoral reaction to the infection and cross-reactivity streptococci antigens and human tissue antigens through antigen mimicry.

 

The stimulated antibodies target the basal ganglia brain cells in the host and cause a diffuse inflammatory process in the corpus striatum, mainly the caudate nucleus and putamen.

 

Other Option: 

 

Option A. Caudate nucleus and globus pallidus: Incorrect. While the caudate nucleus is involved, the globus pallidus is not primarily affected in Sydenham chorea.

 

Option B. Globus pallidus and putamen: Incorrect. The globus pallidus is not primarily affected in Sydenham chorea.

 

Option C. Globus pallidus and lentiform nucleus: Incorrect. The globus pallidus is not primarily involved in Sydenham chorea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ganglia involved in Sydenham chorea, associated with rheumatic fever, are the caudate nucleus and putamen, which are part of the basal ganglia.

choices.text: Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same
Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

questions.text: A new combined treatment regimen of chemotherapy and immunotherapy has significantly increased survival in patients with metastatic melanoma. If the number of new cases remains consistent, but patients live longer, which epidemiological impact would be observed? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

 

  • Due to the new drug combination, patient survival rates have risen, resulting in a situation where the incidence remains unchanged while prevalence sees an increase.

 

PREVALENCE

 

  • Total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over.
  • Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of disease [P = I × d]
  • Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery

 

INCIDENCE

 

  • Number of new cases occurring in a defined population over a specified period of time.

 

Since New cases will keep on occurring at the same rate, Incidence will remain same. Duration will increase (as survival increases). So, overall Prevalence will increase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When patient survival increases due to a new treatment, the incidence of the disease remains the same, but the prevalence increases due to longer survival duration.

questions.text: What is the type of fracture shown in the X-ray of left shoulder? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Neer classification grade 4

 

IMPORTANT CLASSIFICATIONS OF VARIOUS FRACTURES

 

 

NEER CLASSIFICATION OF PROXIMAL HUMERUS FRACTURE

 

  • The classification consists of four major groupings, based on the number of displaced parts.
  • One-part fracture:
    • Fracture lines involves 1 to 4 parts
    • No or minimal displacement (i.e. <1 cm and <45°)
    • Account for ~70-80% of all proximal humeral fractures and are almost always treated conservatively.

 

 

  • Two-part fracture:
    • Fracture lines involves 2 to 4 parts
    • One part is displaced (i.e. >1 cm or >45°)
    • Four possible types of two-part fractures are: 
      1. Surgical neck: most common
      2. Greater tuberosity
        • Frequently seen in anterior shoulder dislocation
        • A lower threshold of displacement (>5 mm)
      3. Anatomical neck
      4. Lesser tuberosity: uncommon
    • These fractures account for approximately 20% of proximal humeral fractures.

 

 

  • Three-part fracture:
    • Fracture lines involves 3 or 4 parts
    • Two parts are displaced (i.e. >1 cm or >45°)
    • 2 three-part fracture patterns are encountered:
      1. Greater tuberosity and shaft are displaced with respect to the lesser tuberosity and articular surface which remain together – most common pattern
      2. Lesser tuberosity and shaft are displaced with respect to the greater tuberosity and articular surface which remain together
    • These fractures account for approximately 5% of proximal humeral fractures.

 

 

  • Four-part fracture:
    • Fracture lines involves all 4 parts
    • Three parts are displaced (i.e. >1 cm or >45°) with respect to the 4th.
    • These fractures are uncommon (<1% of proximal humeral fractures).
    • This pattern has poor non-operative results as the articular surface is no longer attached to any parts of the humerus. This pattern has a high incidence of osteonecrosis. These fractures require operative management.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ideberg classification grade 4. This system is used to classify the scapular fractures.

 

 

 

Option C. Garden classification grade 3. The Garden classification of subcapital femoral neck fractures is the most widely used. It predicts the development of osteonecrosis.

 

 

 

Option D. Schatzker classification grade 5. This is used to classify tibial plateau fracture.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the grade 4 of the Neer’s classification of the proximal humerus fracture where all the fractured parts of the humerus are displaced.

choices.text: Orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb
Orbicularis oculi, neck, facial muscles, upper limb, thorax
Neck, muscles of eyelid, upper limb, thorax
Neck, muscles of eyelid, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb

questions.text: In what sequence do muscles develop rigor mortis, progressing from early to late? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb

 

Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in various muscle groups.

 

Rigor mortis begins from the head and progresses down the body. The order of appearance of rigor mortis is:

 

  1. Myocardium
  2. Eyelids
  3. Neck and lower jaw
  4. Face
  5. Chest
  6. Upper extremities
  7. Abdomen
  8. Legs
  9. Fingers and toes

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigor mortis

 

Rigor mortis is the post-mortem stiffening and contraction of muscles in the body, resulting from the depletion of energy stores, usually becoming noticeable a few hours after death and gradually resolving over time.”

 

  • It first affects the involuntary muscles first starting with the myocardium
  • Nysten’s law deals with the progression of rigor mortis in voluntary muscles
  • Order of appearance of Rigor mortis in different organs:

questions.text: Identify the organism from the given staining technique? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nocardia asteroids

 

The organism shown above is the Nocardia species. The above image shows acid-fast staining, where the organisms are shown appear as acid-fast (stained with fuschia) and branching rods or filaments. They are aerobes found particularly in the soil and are found to produce lung infections in the immunocompromised.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A, B: Mycobacteria species are acid-fast but do not have branching filaments.

 

Option C: Actinomyces species is gram-positive but not acid-fast.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia species are partially acid-fast, branching, filamentous rods that are found in the soil and cause lung infections in immunocompromised individuals.

questions.text: Desmosomes are abundant in which of the following layer of skin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A

 

Desmosomes are abundant in the stratum spinosum layer of the epidermis of the skin. Stratum spinosum in the above image is represented by 'A'.

 

The desmosomes appear like spines on microscopy and hence this layer is also called as the prickle layer.

 

Keratinocytes in the skin's epidermis are connected by desmosomes, also known as macula adherens. It is a cell structure designed specifically for adhesion between cells.

 

  • Due to their strong adhesiveness, they can withstand mechanical stress.
  • Desmoglein (Dsg), Desmocollin (DsC), and DesmoPlakin (Dp) are some of the proteins found in desmosomes.
  • Acantholysis can result from the separation of keratinocytes caused by the loss of any one protein.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune condition brought on by antibodies that target Desmoglein found in desmosomes.
  • Loss of desmosomes causes keratinocyte cohesion to break down (acantholysis), which leads to blister formation.
  • Diseases of the skin and the heart can result from desmosome dysfunction. The primary cause of arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy is mutations within the desmosomes (ARVC).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stratum Corneum (B): This layer is the outermost layer of the epidermis, consisting of dead, keratinized cells. Its main function is to provide a barrier to protect underlying tissue.

 

Option C. Stratum Basale (D): This is the deepest layer of the epidermis, responsible for generating new cells. Desmosomes are present here but not as abundant as in the stratum spinosum.

 

Option D. Stratum Granulosum (C): This layer is characterized by granules of keratohyalin, which play a role in the keratinization process of the skin cells. While desmosomes may be found in this layer, they are more prominent in the stratum spinosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stratum spinosum, indicated by arrow A, is the layer of the skin where desmosomes are most abundant. These structures are key for cell adhesion and strength in this layer, which is situated above the stratum basale and below the stratum granulosum.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page no 2.1, 2.2, 2.18

questions.text: Which of the following is not ligated for the control of epistaxis?(AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Internal carotid artery

 

Internal carotid artery is not ligated in epistaxis control due to high percentage of cerebral complications and high mortality.

 

Ligation of the following arteries is done in epistaxis control:

 

  • Trans nasal Endoscopic Sphenopalatine artery - TESPAL
  • If not controlled, maxillary artery ligation
  • If still not controlled, external carotid artery ligation
  • In case, the bleeding site is superior to the level of middle turbinate, then anterior and posterior ethmoidal vessels should be ligated.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior ethmoidal artery: This artery may be ligated if the bleeding site is superior to the level of the middle turbinate, as it is one of the contributing vessels to the nasal cavity that might be involved in epistaxis.

 

Option C. Maxillary artery: Ligation of the maxillary artery is considered if epistaxis is not controlled by less invasive methods such as the ligation of the sphenopalatine artery.

 

Option D. External carotid artery: As a last resort, if bleeding persists despite ligation of more specific branches, ligation of the external carotid artery may be performed to control severe epistaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of severe epistaxis, it is critical to understand the hierarchy of arterial ligation, starting with the least risky options. The internal carotid artery should never be ligated due to its vital role in cerebral blood supply, highlighting the importance of targeted vascular control in surgical interventions to minimize complications.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with chronic liver disease is evaluated using the Child-Pugh score, which categorizes patients into classes based on disease severity. Which type of data does the Child-Pugh scoring system represent? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Ordinal

 

  • The Child-Pugh score is used to assess the severity and prognosis of chronic liver disease by categorizing patients into different classes based on specific criteria.
  • This score assigns patients to Class A, B, or C based on their total points, indicating varying levels of disease severity and prognosis.
  • It is an ordinal scale of data.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nominal: Incorrect. Nominal data involves categories without order, which does not apply to the ordered nature of the Child-Pugh score.

 

Option C. Qualitative: Incorrect. While the Child-Pugh score is qualitative in describing severity, the specific classification into ordered categories makes it ordinal.

 

Option D. Metric: Incorrect. Metric data involves quantitative measurements with consistent intervals, which does not describe the ordinal nature of the Child-Pugh score.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of the condition seen in the image? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pterygium

 

  • The given image shows Pterygium which is a triangular/wing shaped encroachment of conjunctiva on the cornea.

 

PTERYGIUM:

 

  • A pterygium is a triangular fibrovascular subepithelial ingrowth of degenerative bulbar conjunctival tissue over the limbus onto the cornea.
  • Typically develops in patients who have been living in sunny countries and may represent a response to UV exposure and chronic surface dryness.
  • Familial.
  • Histologically similar to a pinguecula: shows elastotic degenerative changes in vascularized subepithelial stromal collagen.
  • Encroaches onto the cornea, invading the Bowman layer.
  • Clinical features 
    • Mostly asymptomatic.
    • Irritation and grittiness are caused by a dellen – localized drying effect.
    • Lesions may interfere with vision by obscuring the visual axis or inducing astigmatism.
    • Cosmesis may be a significant problem.
    • Extensive lesions (if recurrent) may have subconjunctival fibrosis extending to the fornices causing restricted ocular excursion.
    • Made up of three parts: a ‘cap’ (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge), a head and a body.
    • Linear epithelial iron deposition (Stocker line): seen in the corneal epithelium anterior to the head of the pterygium.
    • Fuchs islets are small discrete whitish flecks consisting of clusters of pterygial epithelial cells often present at the advancing edge.
    • Aggressive growth or an atypical appearance should prompt excision biopsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pinguecula: Unlike pterygium, a pinguecula does not grow across the cornea but remains confined to the conjunctiva. It appears as a yellowish, slightly raised lesion on the conjunctiva near the cornea, usually on the nasal side.

 

Option C. Chemical Burn: This would typically present with more diffuse redness, possible corneal haze, and severe discomfort. The eye would look more acutely inflamed and could show signs of limbal ischemia or whitening.

 

Option D. Thermal Burn: Similar to chemical burns, a thermal burn would involve more diffuse damage and typically present signs of acute injury, such as eyelid burns, charred lashes, or more extensive tissue damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pterygium is identifiable by its characteristic growth from the conjunctiva onto the cornea, often due to prolonged UV exposure, appearing as a wing-shaped film on the eye.

questions.text: A patient with glaucoma presents with a bulging cornea. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Staphyloma

 

High intraocular pressure leads to the thinning of the ocular tissue, thereby resulting in a staphyloma.

 

Staphyloma: It is an abnormal protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weak and thin portion of the cornea or sclera. So, staphyloma is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera.

 

 

Ciliary and equatorial staphylomas are most commonly associated with glaucoma.

 

Types of Staphylomas     -

 

 

Note:

 

The most common cause for anterior staphyloma is sloughing corneal ulcer.

 

The most common cause for posterior staphyloma is degenerative high axial myopia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratoconus: This condition involves a progressive thinning and coning of the cornea, leading to visual distortion, but it is not typically associated with glaucoma.

 

Option B. Keratomalacia: A severe form of vitamin A deficiency leading to corneal softening. The association between keratomalacia and glaucoma is not typical, as keratomalacia results primarily from nutritional deficiencies.

 

Option D. Granular dystrophy: A type of corneal dystrophy characterized by the accumulation of granular deposits in the cornea. It is a genetically inherited condition, unrelated to the thinning caused by glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Staphyloma, particularly anterior and ciliary types, can develop due to high intraocular pressure in glaucoma, leading to the protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weakened cornea or sclera.

choices.text: Do a routine episiotomy
Manual support to perineum to maintain flexion of head
Never give warm compress to the perineum
Perform labor in lithotomy position

questions.text: Which of the following is part of the WHO guidelines for the management of second stage of labor? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Manual support to perineum to maintain flexion of head

 

Explanation:

 

The WHO Recommendations 2018 for the intrapartum second stage of labor emphasize the importance of a positive birth experience. The guidelines suggest manual support to the perineum to maintain the flexion of the fetal head, which helps in reducing perineal trauma.

 

WHO Recommendations 2018 (Intrapartum Second Stage):

 

Recommended:

 

  • Duration of the second stage in primigravida: up to 3 hours; in multigravida: up to 2 hours
  • Allowing the birthing position of choice
  • Encouraging the mother to follow her own urge to push
  • Reducing perineal trauma by using techniques such as hands-on guarding, warm compresses, and perineal massage

 

Not recommended:

 

  • Routine episiotomy
  • Fundal pressure

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Do a routine episiotomy: This is not recommended as a routine practice according to WHO guidelines. Episiotomy should only be performed when clinically indicated.

 

Option C. Never give warm compress to the perineum: This is incorrect. Warm compresses to the perineum are recommended to help reduce perineal trauma.

 

Option D. Perform labor in lithotomy position: The WHO guidelines recommend allowing the woman to choose her birthing position, rather than mandating the lithotomy position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Manual support to the perineum and maintaining the flexion of the fetal head are part of the WHO recommendations for the second stage of labor to reduce perineal trauma and ensure a positive birth experience.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/337693/9789240017566-eng.pdf

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease

 

Histopathological image shows acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules suggestive of nodular glomerulosclerosis/intercapillary glomerulosclerosis seen in Kimmelstiel Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

 

These lesions are specific for type 1 diabetes (juvenile onset diabetes) or islet cell antibody-positive diabetes mellitus.

 

The pathologic changes consist of one or more nodules in a few or many glomeruli. Nodule is an ovoid or spherical, laminated, hyaline, acellular mass located within a lobule of the glomerulus.

 

The nodules are surrounded peripherally by glomerular capillary loops which may have normal or thickened GBM. The nodules are PAS-positive and contain lipid and fibrin. These nodular lesions are frequently accompanied by prominent accumulations of hyaline material in capillary loops (“fibrin caps”) or adherent to Bowman's capsules (“capsular drops”).

 

 

As the nodular lesions enlarge, they compress the glomerular capillaries and obliterate the glomerular tuft. As a result of glomerular and arteriolar involvement, renal ischemia occurs leading to tubular atrophy and interstitial fibrosis and grossly small, contracted kidney.

 

Renal failure is the second common cause of death in diabetes mellitus, the first being myocardial infarction.

 

Diabetic nephropathy encompasses 4 types of renal lesions in diabetes mellitus:

 

1. Diabetic glomerulosclerosis (Diffuse/ Nodular)

 

  1. Diffuse lesions are characterized by diffuse involvement of the glomeruli showing thickening of the GBM and diffuse increase in the mesangial matrix with mild proliferation of mesangial cells and exudative lesions (fibrin caps and capsular drops)
  2. Nodular lesion (Kimmelstiel-Wilson Lesion) is characterized by one or more hyaline nodules within the lobules of glomeruli, surrounded peripherally by glomerular capillaries with thickened walls.

 

 

2.  Vascular lesions – Hyaline arterioslerosis

Morphology

 

 

3. Diabetic pyelonephritis – Papillary necrosis / Necrotizing papillitis

 

4. Tubular lesions (Armanni-Ebstein lesions).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal amyloidosis: Amyloidosis presents with amyloid deposits, typically visualized using Congo red stain, which is different from the PAS-positive nodules seen in Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease.

 

Option B. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): FSGS is characterized by segmental scarring of some glomeruli and does not present with the diffuse nodular glomerulosclerosis observed in Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease.

 

Option D. Lupus nephritis: Lupus nephritis involves immune complex deposition, which leads to a different set of histological changes, including "wire loop" lesions, which are not present in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease, a specific form of diabetic nephropathy, is characterized by PAS-positive nodules within the glomeruli, often associated with type 1 diabetes mellitus.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 2206

choices.text: Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry molars
Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson molars
Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry incisors
Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson incisors

questions.text: Which of the following constitutes Hutchinson's triad? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson incisors

 

Hutchinson's triad refers to:

 

  1. Interstitial keratitis
  2. 8th nerve deafness
  3. Hutchinson incisors

 

Commonly seen in late congenital syphilis.

 

 

Features of Hutchinson Teeth:

 

  • Peg-shaped with a crescent-shaped notch
  • Thinning or discoloration of enamel
  • Smaller teeth
  • Widely spaced teeth

 

Mulberry molars:

 

Mulberry molars (also known as Moon or Fournier molars) are also seen in Congenital Syphilis. They are multicuspid first molars in which the tooth's grinding surface, which is narrower than that at the gingival margin, has many small cusps instead of the usual four well-formed cusps.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry molars: Mulberry molars are also seen in congenital syphilis but are not part of Hutchinson's triad. Mulberry molars (also known as Moon or Fournier molars) are first molars with a narrower grinding surface and multiple small cusps rather than the usual four well-formed cusps.

 

Option B. Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, Hutchinson molars: The correct dental component of Hutchinson's triad is Hutchinson incisors, not molars.

 

Option C. Interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, mulberry incisors: The term "mulberry incisors" is not accurate; Hutchinson incisors are the correct term, which refers to the characteristic dental deformity in Hutchinson's triad.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hutchinson's triad consists of interstitial keratitis, 8th nerve deafness, and Hutchinson incisors, and it is a diagnostic feature of late congenital syphilis.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presented to the OPD with a scald injury on his arm. The lesion was pink, oozing, and painful to moving air and touch. Which of the following would be the most appropriate management? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Collagen dressing

 

Scald injury (damage due to contact with hot liquids) that appears pink in colour, has oozing, and pain is suggestive of a 2nd-degree superficial burn (i.e., partial-thickness burn). Collagen dressing is the most appropriate management for this injury.

 

Collagen dressings are an appropriate choice for partial-thickness burn wounds and scald injuries. They provide several advantages, including promoting wound healing, reducing pain, and helping to maintain a moist environment, which is conducive to tissue repair. Collagen dressings can be especially helpful in managing painful wounds like scald injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silver Sulphadiazine Cream Dressing: Silver sulfadiazine cream is commonly used for burn wounds. However, in the case of a scald injury like the one described (pink, oozing, and painful), silver sulfadiazine cream may not be the first choice. This cream is used for second degree deep and third degree burns.

 

Option B. Excision and Grafting: Excision and grafting are typically reserved for severe burn injuries that involve full-thickness damage to the skin and underlying tissues. In the case of a pink, oozing, and painful scald injury, which is likely partial-thickness, excision and grafting may be overly aggressive and not necessary.

 

Option C. Paraffin Gauze Dressing: Paraffin gauze dressings are often used for burn wounds. They provide a non-adherent surface and help maintain a moist wound environment. While this dressing may be suitable, collagen dressings (Option D) are better at promoting wound healing and tissue repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best dressing for burn wounds is skin; collagen is a good substitute for skin, especially in partial-thickness burns. For full-thickness burns, sequential excision and grafting must be considered.

 

Initial treatment for burns includes cleaning the burnt areas and removing loose dead skin. Blisters are de-roofed and an appropriate dressing is applied.

 

Biological dressing (collagen dressings, amniotic membrane, etc.) is the preferred dressing material, especially in partial thickness burns.

 

If this is not available then a non-adhesive dressing like paraffin gauze impregnated with silver sulfadiazine (SSD) cream, colloidal silver, ionic silver cream, or silver nitrate cream may be applied. Since increased resistance to SSD has recently emerged, it should be used judiciously and reserved for deep dermal, full thickness, infected, and old neglected burns.

choices.text: T cell rich B cell lymphoma

questions.text: A young male presented with cervical lymphadenopathy. The biopsy of the lymph node showed RS cells with vague nodule formation and a background of reactive T-lymphocytes. The cells were positive for CD20, LCA, EMA and negative for CD15 and CD30. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nodular Lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma (NLPHL)

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma (NLPHL).

 

Axial group (cervical) lymphadenopathy and along with the L&H variant of Reed-Sternberg cells is characteristic.

 

RS cells are neoplastic giant cells. In NLPHL, the cells have vague nodular formation. Immunophenotyping is positive for CD20 (B cell-associated), LCA (CD45), EMA (epithelial marker), and negative for CD15 (monocyte or macrophage-associated) and CD30 (activation marker).

 

 

 

  • TYPES OF RS CELLS:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nodular Sclerosis - Hodgkin Lymphoma: This subtype of classical Hodgkin lymphoma (CHL) typically shows RS cells that are positive for CD15 and CD30 but negative for CD20, which is the opposite of what is seen in NLPHL.

 

Option B. CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia): CLL is characterized by small, mature-looking lymphocytes in the blood and bone marrow, not by the presence of RS cells or the nodular pattern seen in NLPHL.

 

Option C. T cell rich B cell lymphoma: This is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that could show a nodular pattern, but it lacks the characteristic L&H cells and the immunophenotypic profile seen in NLPHL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nodular Lymphocyte Predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma (NLPHL) is characterized by the presence of L&H cells, vague nodular formation, and a specific immunophenotypic profile (CD20+, CD45+, EMA+, CD15-, CD30-), which differentiates it from classical Hodgkin lymphoma and other lymphomas.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis based on the given image? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6th nerve palsy

 

  • The left eye of the patient has limitation of movement laterally.
  • The sixth cranial nerve innervates the lateral rectus. In case of lateral rectus palsy,
    • ﻿﻿There is a convergent squint with limitation of movement outwards, and the face is turned towards the paralysed side.
    • ﻿﻿Homonymous diplopia occurs on looking to the paralysed side.
    • ﻿﻿The images are on the same level and erect, becoming more separated on looking more towards the paralysed side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd cranial nerve palsy:

 

  • Oculomotor nerve supplies all intraocular muscles (sphincter and dilator pupillae) and extraocular muscles (LPS, MR, SR, IR, IO) except lateral rectus and superior oblique.
  • Its paralysis results in
    • Ptosis - Due to the paralysis of LPS
    • Down and out eye (due to unopposed lateral rectus and superior oblique)
    • Loss of accommodation (due to paralysis of ciliary muscle)
    • Loss of light reflex
    • Dilated pupil
    • Crossed diplopia

 

Option C. Bell’s palsy:

 

  • Bell palsy is the most common cause of peripheral facial palsy.

 

 

Option D. Horner’s syndrome:

 

  • Sympathetic denervation of face:
    • Ptosis (slight drooping of eyelid: superior tarsal muscle)
    • Miosis (pupil constriction)
    • Anhidrosis (absence of sweating)
    • Flushing of affected side of face

 

Educational Objective:

 

6th nerve palsy is characterized by an inability to abduct the eye, typically presenting as inward turning of the eye due to unopposed medial rectus action, leading to horizontal diplopia that worsens when looking towards the side of the affected nerve. This diagnosis is crucial in patients presenting with lateral gaze limitation following trauma, raised intracranial pressure, or an ischemic event.

choices.text: Closure of active gates of sodium channel
Closure of inactive gates of sodium channel

questions.text: Absolute refractory period is due to? (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Closure of inactive gates of sodium channel

 

The absolute refractory period is due to the closure of the inactive gates of sodium channels. During this period, a second action potential cannot be elicited, even with a strong stimulus. A new action potential cannot occur in an excitable fiber as long as the membrane is still depolarized from the preceding action potential. This is because shortly after the action potential is initiated, the sodium channels become inactivated, and no amount of excitatory signal applied to these channels at this point will open the inactivation gates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option  A. Opening of calcium channels: Incorrect. The opening of calcium channels is not related to the absolute refractory period.

 

Option B. Closure of potassium channels: Incorrect. The closure of potassium channels does not define the absolute refractory period.

 

Option C. Closure of active gates of sodium channel: Incorrect. The closure of active gates does not account for the absolute refractory period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The absolute refractory period is due to the closure of the inactive gates of sodium channels, preventing the initiation of a new action potential during this period.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman considers chopping her fingers; she plots and imagines doing so but never accomplishes it. She claims she feels no shame for having such thoughts. Furthermore, she claims that the ideas are disturbing her and that she is unable to control them. The thoughts can stop with a seizure or gradually fade away on their own. Which of the following is the root of the problem? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Forced thinking

 

The patient is experiencing intrusive thoughts that she recognizes as her own but finds distressing and cannot control. The key detail here that differentiates from classic OCD is that these thoughts can stop with a seizure. This phenomenon is called ‘forced thinking’ which is a form of psychic aura.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thought insertion: Thought insertion refers to the belief that one's thoughts are being placed into their mind by an external force.

 

Option C. Crowding of thoughts: Crowding of thoughts refers to the rapid succession of multiple thoughts, typically seen in conditions like mania.

 

Option D. Obsession: Obsession in the context of OCD does involve intrusive, distressing thoughts, but these wouldn't typically cease with a seizure.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Forced thinking is a type of psychic aura which is characterized by recurrent intrusive thoughts, or ideas, which subside on seizure activity.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 510.

questions.text: A young patient came with complaints of acute abdominal pain on and off and tingling sensation of limbs and at times weakness of limbs. She had a history of eating paint from the wall of a newly built house. Which of the following enzyme defect will be the cause of her condition? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ALA dehydratase

 

The given clinical history is suggestive of lead poisoning and lead is known to inhibit ALA dehydratase enzyme activity (zinc-containing enzyme).

 

Lead is the most common environmental poison in India. Paint is the major source for exposure, especially in children.

 

More than 10 mg/dL in children and more than 25 mg/dL in adults leads to toxic manifestations.

Anemia, abdominal colic and loss of appetite are very common symptoms.

 

Lead inhibits heme synthesis. Basophilic stippling of red cells is seen in the peripheral blood and bone marrow smears. This is due to the agglutination of ribosomes. Globin synthesis is adversely affected. Lead particularly inhibits ALA-dehydratase and ferrochelatase. Lifespan of RBC is shortened. Anemia enhances lead absorption, lead in turn produces more anemia; thus, a vicious cycle is operating. Lead will inhibit absorption of iron and calcium.

 

Treatment - Calcium dodecyl edetate (Calcium disodium versenate), penicillamine and dimercaprol (BAL) are used as antidotes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ALA synthase: This enzyme catalyzes the first step in heme synthesis but is not directly inhibited by lead.

 

Option C. Heme synthase: Also known as ferrochelatase, this enzyme inserts iron into protoporphyrin IX to form heme. Although lead inhibits this enzyme, ALA dehydratase is more significantly affected in lead poisoning, causing the symptoms described.

 

Option D. Coproporphyrinogen oxidase: This enzyme catalyzes a later step in heme synthesis and is not primarily affected in lead poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead poisoning inhibits ALA dehydratase, causing symptoms such as abdominal pain, tingling, and weakness of limbs. Paint ingestion, particularly in children, is a significant source of lead exposure.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female came for treatment of infertility to OPD, Bromocriptine was prescribed. What could be the possible reason? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hyperprolactinemia

 

Bromocriptine is a dopamine agonist that acts on D2 receptors. It is effective in reducing prolactin secretion, which is useful in treating hyperprolactinemia. Elevated levels of prolactin can inhibit the secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), leading to decreased levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH), which can cause anovulation and infertility.

 

Mechanism of Bromocriptine:

 

  • Action: Bromocriptine stimulates D2 dopamine receptors.
  • Effect: Decreases prolactin secretion from the pituitary gland.
  • Result: Reduction in prolactin levels can restore normal GnRH secretion, normalizing FSH and LH levels and resuming ovulatory cycles, thus addressing infertility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PCOD (Polycystic Ovarian Disease): PCOD is characterized by multiple cysts in the ovaries, insulin resistance, and hyperandrogenism. Treatment usually involves lifestyle changes, metformin, or hormonal therapies, not specifically bromocriptine unless associated with hyperprolactinemia.

 

Option C. Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism: This condition involves low levels of FSH and LH due to hypothalamic or pituitary dysfunction. Treatment often includes gonadotropins or pulsatile GnRH therapy. Bromocriptine is not indicated unless hyperprolactinemia is a contributing factor.

 

Option D. PID (Pelvic Inflammatory Disease): PID is an infection of the female reproductive organs. Treatment typically involves antibiotics. Bromocriptine has no role in treating PID.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bromocriptine is a Dopaminergic agonist that leads to a decrease in the secretion of Prolactin by its action on the D2 dopaminergic receptors of the Nigrostriatal Pathway. Hyperprolactinemia can cause infertility by inhibiting the release of GnRH from the hypothalamus, leading to a decrease in the levels of FSH and LH.

questions.text: A diagram illustrating the natural history of a disease has points marked A, B, C, and D. Which point indicates the onset of symptoms in the disease's natural history? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Point C

 

Point C: Marks onset of clinical signs and symptoms

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Point A: Entry of infectious agent into the host.

 

Option B. Point B: Pathological and physiological changes occur in the stage of the subclinical phase. These changes are induced by the causative agent but are not sufficient enough to cause clinical signs and symptoms.

 

Option D. Point D: Usual time of diagnosis at which clinical signs and symptoms are well evident.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is the least likely condition to exhibit lesions and changes on the anterior shin? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypothyroidism

 

Hypothyroidism is the least likely among the given conditions to present with specific skin lesions or changes on the anterior shin. Hypothyroidism can lead to generalized skin changes like dryness and edema (notably myxedema), but it is not typically associated with localized lesions on the shin.

 

Myxedema (severe hypothyroidism) is unlikely to present with lesions over shin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sarcoidosis: In Lofgren syndrome which is acute form of sarcoidosis, Erythema nodosum Skin lesions can be seen on shin as seen in the image below.

 

 

Option B. Diabetes: Necrobiosis lipoidica Diabeticorum classically seen on anterior surface of legs.

 

 

Necrobiosis lipoidica Diabeticorum

 

Option C. Hyperthyroidism: Pretibial myxoedema is the infiltrative dermopathy (mucin deposition) seen over shin and it can be seen in Grave's disease which is a type of hyperthyroidism.

 

Pretibial myxoedema is depicted in below image:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Page no 59.11, 64.5, 98.6, 149.10

choices.text: Endodermal sinus tumor
Malignant teratoma
Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma

questions.text: A 16-year-old female patient presents with an ovarian mass. On further evaluation, her serum biomarkers are found to be normal except for LDH, which is found to be elevated. The most likely diagnosis is: (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dysgerminoma

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical history of a 16-year-old female presenting with an ovarian mass with raised LDH points towards the diagnosis of dysgerminoma. Dysgerminomas usually arise in young women or in children, with an average incidence at the age of 20. They currently account for approximately one-third of all malignant ovarian germ cell tumors and are the most common malignant ovarian tumors found in pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endodermal sinus tumor: This is typically associated with elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), not LDH.

 

Option C. Malignant teratoma: This type of tumor does not typically present with elevated LDH as the sole abnormal marker.

 

Option D. Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma: This epithelial ovarian tumor is usually associated with elevated CA-125, not LDH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dysgerminoma is the most likely diagnosis in a young female with an ovarian mass and elevated LDH levels.

 

Ref: Page no 381, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: What does the Red Cell Distribution Width (RDW) measure?  (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anisocytosis

 

Red Cell Distribution Width (RDW) is a measure of the variation in red blood cell (RBC) size. Anisocytosis, which is the variation in the sizes of RBCs, is directly assessed by RDW. A higher RDW indicates a greater variation in size. RDW is used clinically to help differentiate between types of anemia and to provide insight into the underlying mechanisms of anemia. Normal RDW values range from 11-14%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypochromia: Refers to RBCs having less color than normal, indicative of less hemoglobin content per cell, not directly related to RDW.

 

Option C. Poikilocytosis: Indicates variation in the shape of RBCs, not their size, hence not directly assessed by RDW.

 

Option D. Anisochromia: Refers to variation in hemoglobin content among RBCs, which is not measured by RDW.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RDW measures the variability in size of red blood cells, which is indicative of anisocytosis. High RDW is associated with conditions like iron deficiency anemia and other types of anemia, where there is significant variation in RBC sizes.

 

Additional Information

 

IDA vs Thalassemia

 

IDA- rbcs are small (low MCV ) with high RDW

 

Thalassemia- RBCs are small (low MCV )  with normal RDW

choices.text: To give oral antibiotics since the given accumulation is normal
To re-explore the wound and insert a T-tube

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He was discharged after removing the drain tube on the first postoperative day. On day three, the patient returned to the hospital and was febrile. On ultrasound examination, there was a 5 x 5 cm collection in the subhepatic space. Next best step is? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insert pigtail catheter for drainage

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a bile duct injury following laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

 

The next best step after imaging would be to control inflammation by

 

  • Drainage of fluid collection (Pigtail insertion and drainage) and
  • Administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics

 

This is the most appropriate next step in managing a subhepatic collection. A pigtail catheter is inserted percutaneously under imaging guidance to drain the collection. This helps in both diagnosing and treating any infection or abscess that may have developed after the surgery. It allows for drainage of the accumulated fluid and may be accompanied by sending the drained fluid for culture and sensitivity testing. This step is less invasive than re-exploration and allows for targeted management of the collection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To give oral antibiotics since the given accumulation is normal: While antibiotics may be considered in some postoperative cases, the presence of a collection along with fever suggests an infection or abscess, making antibiotics alone an inadequate treatment.

 

Option B. To re-explore the wound and insert a T-tube: Re-exploration of the surgical wound and insertion of a T-tube is a more invasive approach and is not the first-line option for managing a postoperative collection.

 

Option D. ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography): ERCP is typically used to evaluate and treat conditions of the bile ducts and pancreatic ducts and is not the primary intervention for managing a postoperative collection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bile duct injury

 

  • Usually manifests in the postoperative period

 

Clinical features

 

  • Fever
  • Increasing abdominal pain
  • Jaundice
  • Bile leakage from an incision

 

Diagnosis

 

Imaging: Ultrasonography

 

  • To assess for a fluid collection and to evaluate the biliary tree

 

Treatment Strategy

 

  • Control of infection, limiting inflammation
  • Percutaneous drainage of periportal fluid collections
  • Parenteral antibiotics
  • Clear and thorough delineation of entire biliary anatomy
  • Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)
  • Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), especially if cystic-duct stump leak is suspected
  • Reestablishment of biliary-enteric continuity (surgery)
    1. Tension-free, mucosa-to-mucosa anastomosis
    2. Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

questions.text: Cause of death in the position shown in the image below is: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Positional asphyxia

 

The position shown is Jack-knife position that leads to positional asphyxia (Restriction of lung expansion d/t abnormal position of the body). It is a position where the victim's thighs and knees are driven against the chest causing indirect compression of the chest and restriction of breathing movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Wedging: Infant falls in the small gap between wall & bed and getting wedged there. It is a type of traumatic asphyxia.

 

Option B) Burking: Accused sits on chest of victim & closes mouth/ nostril as well. Its Mechanism is smothering combined with traumatic asphyxia.

 

Option D) Traumatic asphyxia: it is asphyxia due to restriction of lung expansion as a result of mechanical fixation of chest and not due to abnormal body position hence this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classification of Mechanical Asphyxia

 

1. Suffocation Asphyxia

  • Smothering
  • Gagging
  • Traumatic Asphyxia (Crush Asphyxia)
  • Positional Asphyxia (Postural Asphyxia)
  • Burking
  • Overlaying
  • Choking (Café Coronary)

 

2. Compression of neck

  • Hanging – force is body weight / body is suspended
  • Strangulation – force is anything other than body weight / no suspension.

 

3. Drowning

questions.text: A patient of supracondylar humerus fracture is unable to flex interphalangeal joint of the thumb. No sensory deficit was found. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anterior interosseous nerve

 

  • Flexion at interphalangeal joint of thumb is caused by flexor pollicis longus which is supplied by anterior interosseous nerve, a pure motor branch of median nerve.
  • It branches from the median nerve in the proximal forearm between the two heads of the pronator teres muscle to run deep along the interosseous membrane.
  • From proximal to distal, it innervates the flexor pollicus longus (FPL), the index and long fingers of the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP), and the pronator quadratus (PQ).
  • AIN syndrome is an isolated palsy of these three muscles.
  • It manifests mostly as pain in the forearm accompanied by a characteristic weakness of the index finger and thumb pincer movement.
  • Many cases of AIN syndrome arise secondary to transient neuritis, although nerve compression and trauma are known etiologies as well. 
  • Supracondylar humerus fracture is also a common cause of AIN injury.
  • The most common site of AIN entrapment/compression is the tendinous edge of the deep head of the pronator teres muscle. 
  • True AIN syndrome presentation will present with motor deficits only. 
  • No sensory changes appreciated. There are no numbness, tingling, or sensory deficits.
  • The patient will complain of having difficulty bringing the distal phalanx of the thumb and index finger together.
  • On a physical examination, the pinch grip test is positive. Rather than making the "OK" sign, the patient will clap the sheet between the index finger and an extended thumb.

 

 

  • The patient may also complain of having difficulty forming a fist or the inability to button their shirts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median nerve. The effect of trauma on the median nerve depends on the injury site and may involve the palm, forearm, arm, or axilla. The damage to the nerve can lead to motor, sensory, and vasomotor loss. Most injuries to the median nerve occur at the wrist. Traumatic injuries to the median nerve at the wrist can be due to wrist fractures. Nerve damage can range from compression to nerve contusion. On the wrist, the median nerve is exposed to cutting and penetrating injuries. The signs and symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome include thenar weakness, numbness in the radial 3 ½  fingers, and paresthesias, burning-like pain in the distribution of the median nerve. Symptoms can mimic the effects of an injury to the C6, C7 nerve roots. Symptoms are typically worse at night and awaken patients from sleep. There is no triceps or weakness in wrist extension. Carpal tunnel is also distinguishable with the Tinel and Phalen tests. A positive Tinel sign and positive Phalen maneuver are indicative of carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

 

Phalen’s Test for Carpal Tunnel Syndrome

 

Option B. Superficial Branch of Ulnar Nerve. The superficial branch of the ulnar nerve is a terminal branch of the ulnar nerve. It supplies the palmaris brevis and the skin on the ulnar side of the hand. The ulnar nerve is most susceptible to injury at the elbow and the wrist. Mechanism of injury includes local trauma, nerve impingement, lacerations at the wrist and Guyon canal cyst. Characteristic signs of injury to the ulnar nerve is the inability to grip paper between the fingers (Card Test) with ulnar claw hand deformity. The ulnar nerve injury can be characterized by flattening of medial border of forearm, loss of sensation at distal interphalangeal joints of 4th and 5th digit, loss of hypothenar eminence, loss of adduction of thumb, loss of abduction of fingers, clawing of 4th and 5th digits, and sensory, trophic and vasomotor changes.

 

 

Card Test (Palmar interossei – Loss of Adduction)

 

 

Ulnar Claw Hand Deformity

 

Option D. Posterior Interosseous Nerve. The posterior interosseous nerve is a branch of the radial nerve, The deep branch of the radial nerve dives into the posterior forearm through the heads of the supinator to emerge as the posterior interosseous nerve. The posterior interosseous nerve supplies motor innervation to the posterior forearm. Posterior interosseous nerve syndrome is a compressive neuropathy of the posterior interosseous nerve which innervates the extensor compartment of the forearm. It usually has an insidious onset, often presenting with weakness in finger and thumb extension. However, there is preservation in wrist extension due to the radial nerve innervated extensor carpi radialis longus. It is often self-limiting and resolves with conservative measures. However, symptoms that are refractory to non-operative treatment may require surgical decompression. Posterior interosseous nerve syndrome can be present in Monteggia fractures or radial head fracture-dislocations. The patient may exhibit weakness with finger extension. When asked to make a fist, the wrist may deviate radially due to extensor carpi ulnar is weakness. Depending on injury severity, there may be a positive Tinel sign at the site of injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In case of supracondylar humerus fracture, presenting with an inability to flex the interphalangeal joint of the thumb, without any sensory deficit, the nerve most commonly injured is the anterior interosseous nerve, a terminal branch of the median nerve.

questions.text: Identify the grip in the image given below: (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pawlik grip

 

  • The Leopold's third manuever is also called the Pawlik's grip.
  • It is performed by grasping with the thumb and fingers, the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis. If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass will be felt.

 

Obstetric grips (Leopold maneuvers):

 

  1. Fundal grip (1st Leopold)
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Lateral/umbilical grip (2nd Leopold)
  3. ﻿﻿﻿1st pelvic grip / Pawlik grip (3rd Leopold)
  4. 2nd pelvic grip (4th Leopold)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Second Pelvic grip: This is incorrect. The second pelvic grip, also known as the fourth Leopold maneuver, is used to determine the degree of fetal descent and engagement.

 

Option B. Abdominal grip: This term is not specific to any of the Leopold maneuvers and is not used in this context.

 

Option D. Fundal grip: This is the first Leopold maneuver, used to determine the fetal part located in the fundus of the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Pawlik grip (third Leopold maneuver) involves grasping the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis to assess the engagement of the presenting part of the fetus.

 

Ref: Page no 89-90, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company conducted a double-blind clinical trial comparing a new antidiabetic drug to a placebo. The study enrolled an equal number of participants in both arms. Based on the data below, what are the Relative Risk Reduction (RRR) and Absolute Risk Reduction (ARR) for adverse effects? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) RRR 11%, ARR 1%

 

Calculation -

 

  • Relative risk reduction (RRR): Percentage reduction in one outcome (E.g. Death or Adverse outcome) comparing one group (New drug) with another group (Older drug or Placebo)
  • Absolute risk reduction (ARR): Reduction in outcome (E.g. Death or Adverse outcome) comparing one group (New drug) with another group (Older drug or Placebo)
  • Event is taken as Occurrence of adverse outcome in the given example

 

In the given question,

 

Event rate Drug = 1603/15225 × 100 = 10.5% (0.105)

 

Event rate Placebo = 1804/15225 × 100 = 11.8% (0.118)

 

Hence,

 

  • Relative risk of Event rate = Event rate drug/Event rate Placebo = 0.105/0.118 = 0.9
  • Relative risk reduction (RRR) = (Event rate Placebo – Event rate drug)/Event rate placebo = (0.118)–0.105)/0.118 = 0.11 = 11%
  • Absolute risk reduction = Event rate Drug – Event rate Placebo = 0.105 – 0.118 = – 0.013 = – 1.3%

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Relative Risk Reduction (RRR) reflects the proportionate reduction in risk between two groups, while the Absolute Risk Reduction (ARR) provides the difference in risk between them

questions.text: Which of the following site does the restriction enzyme act when RFLP is used in-order to identify the five different species of staphylococci in a surgical ICU? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GATATC- CTATAG

 

Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism (RFLP) is a difference in homologous DNA sequences that can be detected by the presence of fragments of different lengths after digestion of the DNA samples in question with specific restriction endonucleases.

 

Restriction endonucleases have specific recognition sites where they cut the DNA. These enzymes recognize specific sequence with palindrome arrangement. These are also called inverted repeat sequences, which means the nucleotide sequence in 5′ to 3′ direction is the same in both strands.

 

Option B. is a palindromic sequence, hence the correct the answer.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: ATGGAC – TACGTG 

 

  • This is not a palindrome.
  • 5'-ATGGAC
    3'-TACCTG 

 

Option C: TAGATA – ATCTAT 

 

  • Not a palindrome.
  • 5'-TAGATA
    3'-ATCTAT

 

Option D: AATATA – TATAAT 

 

  • 5'-AATATA
    3'-TATAAT
  • Not a palindrome either. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In RFLP, restriction enzymes recognize and cut at palindromic sequences in DNA. The palindromic sequence GATATC-CTATAG is a correct recognition site for these enzymes, making it crucial for identifying different species, such as staphylococci in a surgical ICU.

choices.text: Continue same diet

questions.text: A pregnant lady of 49 kg is in her first trimester. What are her additional calorie requirements in this trimester? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Continue same diet

 

Explanation:

 

Pregnancy requires an additional 80,000 Kcal; mostly in the latter half. During the first trimester, there is no need for additional calories. The caloric increase is recommended as follows:

 

  • 0 Kcal in 1st trimester
  • 340 Kcal in 2nd trimester
  • 452 Kcal in 3rd trimester

 

In this question, extra calories in the 1st trimester are asked, so the answer will be no additional requirement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

There are no additional calorie requirements in the first trimester of pregnancy.

 

Page no 487, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following drug must always be available for emergency use in labor ward if a patient is on opioid analgesic? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Naloxone

 

Explanation:

 

Naloxone is a narcotic antagonist capable of reversing respiratory depression induced by opioid narcotics. It acts by displacing the narcotic from specific receptors in the central nervous system, thus reversing the effects of the opioid, including respiratory depression. This makes it an essential drug to have on hand in the labor ward when a patient is receiving opioid analgesics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fentanyl: This is an opioid analgesic used for pain management, not for reversing opioid effects.

 

Option C. Morphine: This is another opioid analgesic and would not be used to counteract the effects of other opioids.

 

Option D. Bupivacaine: This is a local anesthetic used for epidural anesthesia, not an opioid antagonist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Naloxone must always be available in the labor ward for emergency use when a patient is on opioid analgesic to promptly reverse opioid-induced respiratory depression.

 

Ref: Page no 546, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: 1 min
3 min
5-7 min
5 min

questions.text: The time required for preoxygenation before tracheal intubation is?(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 3 min

 

Explanation:

 

Preoxygenation or denitrogenation is the process of replacing nitrogen in the lungs with oxygen. This is typically done by giving 100% oxygen to the patient for 3 minutes through a tight-fitting mask or by asking them to take 8 vital capacity breaths. This process helps to lengthen the apnea time, providing an improved margin of safety while the anesthesiologist secures the airway and resumes ventilation.

 

There are two main methods commonly used for preoxygenation:

 

  1. The first method involves utilizing tidal volume ventilation through a face mask for a duration of 3 minutes. This technique allows for the exchange of approximately 95% of the gas present in the lungs.
  2. The second method relies on vital capacity breaths to achieve effective preoxygenation in a shorter time frame. While four breaths over 30 seconds are not as efficient as the tidal volume method, it may still be deemed acceptable in specific clinical scenarios. Research has indicated that eight breaths over a span of 60 seconds are more effective for preoxygenation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 min: This duration is insufficient for effective preoxygenation, as it does not allow adequate time to replace the nitrogen in the lungs with oxygen.

 

Option C. 5-7 min: While longer preoxygenation can ensure thorough denitrogenation, it is not typically necessary beyond the 3 minutes required for effective preoxygenation.

 

Option D. 5 min: Preoxygenation for this duration can be effective, but the standard practice is to use 3 minutes as it is usually sufficient to achieve the desired effect.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Preoxygenation for tracheal intubation is effectively achieved by administering 100% oxygen for 3 minutes through a tight-fitting mask or by taking 8 vital capacity breaths.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1380

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has a lesion over the face as shown below. He complains of bleeding while itching. The most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) BCC (Basal cell carcinoma)

 

The given history with the image showing an ulcer over the face with pearly, rolled-out borders points to a diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma.

 

Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer, especially in older individuals with sun exposure. It often appears as a pearly or waxy bump with central depression, which can bleed easily. Itching is also a common symptom associated with BCC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermatofibrosarcoma: Dermatofibrosarcoma is a rare, slow-growing soft tissue tumor that typically presents as a painless, raised, flesh-colored or brownish lesion. It does not commonly cause bleeding or itching.

 

 

Option B. Marjolin's Ulcer: Marjolin's ulcer refers to a malignant transformation of a chronic non-healing wound, scar, or ulcer. It is often associated with long-standing inflammation or trauma. While it can present with bleeding, it typically doesn't cause itching as a primary symptom.

 

 

Option D. Naevus: A nevus, commonly known as a mole, is a benign skin lesion. While moles can occasionally be itchy, they do not usually cause bleeding unless they are irritated or traumatized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Basal cell carcinoma is an epithelial tumor that arises from basal cells layer of epidermis. It is the most common type of skin cancer. Most commonly seen over the face, above the line joining corner of the mouth, and lobule of the ear. Clinically it can present either as nodular or pigmented BCC. Features of nodular BCC are:

 

  1. Small, slowly growing pearly nodule
  2. Tortuous telangiectatic vessels on the surface
  3. Rolled borders
  4. Central crusting

 

The occasional presence of melanin in the nodular variant of BCC (pigmented BCC) may lead to confusion with melanoma.

questions.text: Identify the organism from the given image? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospira

 

The organisms in the image are leptospira.

 

In spirochetes, the presence of two axial filaments (periplasmic flagella) with polar insertions are located in periplasmic space called as endoflagella, which are responsible for the characteristic corkscrew motion of these bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vibrio: Vibrio species are comma-shaped, Gram-negative bacteria, commonly known for causing cholera (Vibrio cholerae).

 

Option C. Helicobacter: Helicobacter pylori are spiral-shaped bacteria known for causing stomach ulcers and are Gram-negative.

 

Option D. Salmonella: Salmonella species are rod-shaped, Gram-negative bacteria, known for causing foodborne illnesses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leptospira is identified by its spiral morphology with axial filaments (endoflagella) and is a type of spirochete, along with Treponema and Borrelia.

 

Endoflagella are seen in:

 

  • Treponema
  • Borrelia
  • Leptospira

questions.text: A trauma patient suffered a renal laceration with urine extravasation. He was managed conservatively. However, after a few days, he presented with a urinoma. The next best management for this patient would be? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ureteral stenting

 

The patient in the given question has renal laceration with urine extravasation, which classifies as grade 4 renal injury.

 

Ureteral stenting is a minimally invasive procedure that can help alleviate the obstruction and promote urine drainage, reducing the risk of infection and other complications associated with urinomas

 

Ureteral stenting involves the placement of a stent into the ureter to facilitate drainage of urine from the renal pelvis to the bladder. In the context of a urinoma, this can help alleviate the obstruction or urine accumulation, providing relief and preventing further complications. It is similar to placement of CBD stent via ERCP in cystic duct leak.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Surgical Repair and Exploration: Surgical repair and exploration may be considered if there is a significant structural or anatomical issue contributing to the urinoma that cannot be resolved through less invasive methods.

 

Option C. Observation: Observation alone may not be sufficient if the urinoma is causing discomfort, pain, or complications. It's crucial to address the urinoma promptly.

 

Option D. Percutaneous Drainage: Percutaneous drainage may be an option, but ureteral stenting is a more specific approach for managing urinomas resulting from ureteral obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A urinoma is a collection of urine that has leaked from the urinary tract and has accumulated outside its normal anatomical location. This condition typically occurs due to trauma, injury, or obstruction in the urinary system.

 

  1. Causes: Urinomas are usually caused by trauma, such as blunt abdominal or pelvic trauma, that leads to injury to the urinary collecting system. They can also result from urinary tract obstruction, infections, or surgical complications.
  2. Symptoms: Common symptoms of a urinoma may include abdominal or flank pain, fever, and swelling in the affected area. In some cases, urinomas may be asymptomatic and discovered incidentally during imaging studies.
  3. Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a combination of medical history, physical examination, and imaging studies, such as ultrasound, CT scans, or MRI, to visualize the urinoma and determine its size and location.

 

A persistent urinoma (a mass formed by encapsulated extravasated urine) should be managed with the placement of an internal ureteral stent.

 

Patients not cured by ureteral stenting may require percutaneous nephrostomy or transcutaneous drainage.

questions.text: Which of the following is a negative acute phase reactants ? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Albumin

 

Negative acute phase reactants are substances whose serum concentrations decrease in response to systemic inflammation. Albumin is one of the well-recognized negative acute phase reactants. Its levels fall during acute phase response as resources are shifted to produce more critical positive reactants that help in the defense and repair processes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Haptoglobin: This is a positive acute phase reactant, which increases in response to inflammation.

 

Option C. Ferritin: Also a positive acute phase reactant, often increases in states of inflammation and infection.

 

Option D. C-reactive protein: A classic positive acute phase reactant, it increases dramatically in response to inflammation.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: 70% amorphous 30% crystalline
70% crystalline 30% amorphous
Only 70% amorphous
D Other name of NPH insulin

questions.text: Composition of Lente insulin is? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 70% crystalline 30% amorphous

 

Lente insulin has two components in it:

 

  • Ultralente insulin, which is water insoluble insulin zinc suspension with large crystalline particles (70%), it has a long half-life.
  • Semilente insulin, which is amorphous, has smaller particles and is short acting. (30%)
  • These two components are mixed in this 7:3 ratio, making Lente insulin intermediate acting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 70% amorphous 30% crystalline: This is incorrect as the amorphous part makes up only 30% of the composition in Lente insulin.

 

Option C. Only 70% amorphous: This is incorrect because Lente insulin is a mixture of both crystalline and amorphous components, not just one type.

 

Option D. Other name of NPH insulin: This is incorrect. Lente insulin and NPH (Neutral Protamine Hagedorn) insulin are different formulations. NPH insulin is an intermediate-acting insulin that is a suspension of insulin with protamine and zinc, which prolongs its action, but it is not referred to as Lente insulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lente insulin is composed of 70% crystalline (long-acting) and 30% amorphous (short-acting) insulin, making it an intermediate-acting insulin formulation.

questions.text: The cell indicated by the red arrow in the given image inhibits which of the following structures? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Deep nuclei of cerebellum

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a histopathological section of the cerebellum. The cells marked with the arrow are Purkinje cells and they inhibit deep nuclei of the cerebellum.

 

Within the white matter, there are four pairs of deep cerebellar nuclei: the fastigial, globose, emboliform (these last two are collectively called the interposed nuclei), and the dentate nuclei. These nuclei receive inhibitory input from Purkinje cells and excitatory input from cerebellar afferents and provide the primary output from the cerebellum to other brain regions.

 

 

Detailed Overview of Cerebellar Architecture:

 

1. Three Layers of the Cerebellar Cortex:
