  • Molecular Layer: This is the outermost layer and contains stellate and basket cells. The dendrites of Purkinje cells also extend into this layer. The axons of granule cells, called parallel fibers, run horizontally in this layer.
  • Purkinje Cell Layer: This layer contains the large, flask-shaped Purkinje cells, which are the principal neurons of the cerebellar cortex. Purkinje cells have a single axon that travels to the deep cerebellar nuclei and extensive dendritic trees that extend into the molecular layer. They are inhibitory neurons that use GABA as their neurotransmitter.
  • Granule Cell Layer: The innermost layer contains numerous small granule cells, along with Golgi cells. Granule cells are excitatory neurons that use glutamate as their neurotransmitter. Their axons ascend into the molecular layer where they bifurcate and run as parallel fibers, synapsing with Purkinje cell dendrites.

 

2. White Matter: Beneath the cerebellar cortex is the cerebellar white matter, which consists of myelinated axons. These axons form the afferent and efferent connections of the cerebellum.

 

3. Deep Cerebellar Nuclei: Within the white matter are four pairs of deep cerebellar nuclei: the fastigial, globose, emboliform (these last two are collectively called the interposed nuclei), and the dentate nuclei. These nuclei receive inhibitory input from Purkinje cells and excitatory input from cerebellar afferents and provide the primary output from the cerebellum to other brain regions.

 

4. Afferent and Efferent Fibers: The cerebellum receives input (afferent fibers) mainly from the spinal cord, brainstem, and cerebral cortex and sends output (efferent fibers) to the deep cerebellar nuclei and then out to various parts of the brain, primarily the vestibular nuclei and the thalamus.

 

5. Bergmann Glia: These are specialized astrocytes found in the cerebellum. They have long processes that extend through the Purkinje cell layer into the molecular layer, providing support for neurons and playing a role in neurotransmission.

 

6. Foliation: Grossly, the cerebellum exhibits a series of folia (folds) which are a result of the convolution of the cerebellar cortex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Vestibular nuclei and Option C: Basal ganglia are not directly influenced by Purkinje cells.

 

Option B: Anterior horn of spinal is involved in motor neuron activity, unrelated to Purkinje cell output.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Purkinje cells in the cerebellum play a vital inhibitory role on the deep cerebellar nuclei, crucial for coordinating and refining motor movements and cognitive processing related to movement.

choices.text: Oral glucose challenge test with GH level
Insulin like growth factor 1 binding potein -3 (IGFBP-3 )
Insulin like growth factor -1 levels
Random growth hormone levels

questions.text: A 44 yr old man is referred to your center for management of severe hyperglycemia. During examination, you note that patient has enlarged feet, coarse facial features, and prognathism. You suspect acromegaly. Which of the following tests can you use as a screening method for this condition ? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insulin like growth factor-1 levels

 

Acromegaly is a clinical syndrome that results from excessive secretion of growth hormone (GH). Produced mainly in the pituitary gland, GH controls the physical growth of the body. In adults, too much of this hormone causes bones, cartilage, body organs, and other tissues to increase in size. Acromegaly is most often diagnosed in middle-aged adults, but symptoms can appear at any age. In children, too much growth hormone causes a condition called gigantism rather than acromegaly.

 

Best screening test for acromegaly is serum insulin like growth factor-1 (IGF-1).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral glucose challenge test with GH level: While this test is used to diagnose acromegaly by demonstrating a lack of GH suppression after glucose administration, it is more complex and typically performed after IGF-1 screening suggests acromegaly.

 

Option B. Insulin-like growth factor 1 binding protein-3 (IGFBP-3): Although IGFBP-3 levels are influenced by GH, they are not routinely used for screening acromegaly.

 

Option D. Random growth hormone levels: These levels can fluctuate significantly throughout the day and are influenced by various factors, making random GH levels unreliable for diagnosing acromegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serum IGF-1 is the preferred initial test for screening acromegaly due to its reliability and the persistence of elevated levels in the presence of excessive GH production. This test provides a stable indicator of disease activity and is less variable than direct GH measurements.

choices.text: Open wound with fracture, with wound <1 cm
Open wound with fracture, 1 to 10 cm wound size, but mild soft tissue injury
Open wound >10 cm, though soft tissue coverage not required
Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage

questions.text: A patient with open wound, with fracture of both bones of right lower limb came to the emergency. The doctor labelled the injury as type 3B according to Gustilo-Anderson Classification. Which of the following would represent the injury? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage

 

GUSTILO AND ANDERSON CLASSIFICATION FOR OPEN FRACTURE

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open wound with fracture, with wound <1 cm. This is the description of Type I of open fracture where the wound is clean and of <1cm length.  

 

Option B. Open wound with fracture, 1 to 10 cm wound size, but mild soft tissue injury. This is the description of Type II of open fracture where the wound length is >1cm with mild soft tissue damage or skin flap or avulsion.

 

Option C. Open wound >10 cm, though soft tissue coverage not required. This is the description of Type IIIA of the open fracture where there is an adequate periosteal coverage present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type IIIB of the open fracture is the open wound with significant periosteal stripping.
  • It requires secondary bone coverage and procedures like skin grafting or flap.

questions.text: A 5-year-old presents with gradually progressive hoarseness of voice over three months and respiratory distress for 2 weeks. Diagnosis is: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory papillomatosis

 

The given clinical situation suggests that the child is suffering from respiratory papillomatosis.

 

Respiratory Papillomatosis (Juvenile Papillomatosis)

 

  • It is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children.
  • It is caused by HPV 6 and 11.
  • Involves supraglottic and glottic regions of larynx.

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Age 3-5 years
  • Hoarseness or aphonia
  • Respiratory difficulty
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy

 

 

Treatment consists of cold steel/ coblation/ debrider/ radiofrequency/ Laser assisted microlaryngeal surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Croup: Though croup affects young children and presents with respiratory symptoms, it is an acute condition that generally presents rapidly with a characteristic barking cough and stridor, not gradually as in this case.

 

Option C. Vocal nodule: Vocal nodules result from vocal cord trauma and present symmetrically on the free edge of the vocal cords at the junction of the anterior one-third and the posterior two-thirds. They typically cause hoarseness but do not lead to respiratory distress, as they do not obstruct the airway.

 

Option D. Acute epiglottitis: This is another acute condition, presenting with rapid onset and severe symptoms including high fever, throat pain, and significant respiratory distress. The progressive nature of the symptoms described in the question does not align with the acute presentation of epiglottitis.

 

Educational Objective:


Juvenile respiratory papillomatosis should be considered in young children presenting with a gradual worsening of hoarseness and the development of respiratory symptoms. The condition highlights the need for awareness of HPV-related diseases in children and indicates the importance of early and accurate diagnosis followed by appropriate surgical intervention, which may include cold steel, coblation, debrider, radiofrequency, or laser-assisted microlaryngeal surgery to manage the growth and recurrence of papillomas effectively.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition pg 327, 328, 343, 345, 346

questions.text: A patient who used to work out regularly at the gym gradually developed pain in the hip which is aggravated while squatting. He gives history of regular steroid and creatine use over last six months. There is flattening of femoral head and subchondral cysts were seen on X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. AVN of hip

 

AVASCULAR NECROSIS

 

  • Avascular necrosis (AVN) is the cellular death of components of bone due to impaired blood supply.
  • It affects anterolateral aspect of femoral head.
  • Etiopathogenesis: Idiopathic (most common) – called as Chandeliers disease.
  • Causes of AVN of Femoral Head:

 

 

  • Clinical Features:
    • Age 20-50 years with slight male preponderance (Young Male).
    • Bilateral in 50% of idiopathic cases, and 80% of steroid induced cases.
    • Decreased range of motion especially internal rotation followed by abduction.
    • This is a characteristic feature of any disease in which femoral head shape is altered -  abduction and internal rotation is reduced (also seen in Perthes, Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis).
    • A characteristic sign is a tendency for hip to twist into external rotation during passive flexion; this corresponds to the ‘Sectoral sign’ in which, with the hip extended, internal rotation is almost full but with hip flexed it is grossly restricted, it is due to a sector of femoral head being involved in AVN.
    • X-rays shows Sclerosed area – Area of necrosis; Crescent sign – Crescentric defect in subchondral area.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice – Double line sign is seen.
    • T1 – AVN: Reduced intensity or irregular outline of head.
    • T2 – high signal intensity called as double line sign.

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Early stages: protected weight-bearing.
    • Pre-collapse stage: Core decompression to decrease intraosseous pressure in femoral head (Intraosseous pressure Normal 10-20 mm Hg, it is 3-4 times in AVN).  Drill holes are made in femoral head. This procedure also opens the channels for vascular ingrowths and it is also supplemented with bone grafting (Vascular or nonvascular) or electrical stimulation or bone morphogenic proteins.
    • Muscle Pedicle graft: Quadratus femoris (Meyers graft)/Tensor fascia lata graft (Joshi’s graft) can be fixed in femoral head to augment vascularity.
    • Rotational osteotomy: To get the intact part of femoral head in acetabulum weight-bearing area (anterolateral aspect of femur head) this is an extensive procedure requiring vascular repair along with it.
    • Arthritis/Collapse of femoral head: Total hip replacement one of the very commonly done procedure as most patients present at stage of arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TB of hip. Osteoarticular TB is secondary to primary pathology in lungs, lymph nodes or viscera. Through the hematogenous route, the bacteria reach either to synovium or bone. The bacteria may lodge first in the epiphyseal or metaphyseal region of the bones like head or neck of femur, greater trochanter or acetabulum. Pain in the hip, limp, restriction of movements is present in almost all the cases.

 

 

 

Wandering acetabulum seen in stage 4 of hip TB

 

Option C. Fracture neck of femur. Femoral neck fractures are associated with low energy falls in the elderly. In younger patients, the cause is usually high-energy trauma such as motor vehicle accidents. Risk factors for femoral neck fractures include female gender, decreased mobility, and low bone density. The patient will complain of pain with a decreased range of motion of the hip. In undisplaced fractures, there may be no deformity. However, displaced fractures may present with a shortened and externally rotated lower limb.

 

 

Option D. Osteomalacia. Osteomalacia is a disorder of “bone softening” in adults that is due to prolonged deficiency of vitamin D. This deficiency results in abnormal osteoid mineralization. Symptoms are non-specific and may include proximal muscle weakness and wasting, myalgias and arthralgias, muscle spasms, aching bone pain aggravated by activity and weight-bearing. Radiographic findings may include Looser zones or pseudofractures, a classic finding in osteomalacia. They may represent poorly repaired fractures and are visible as transverse lucencies perpendicular to the osseous cortex. They typically occur bilaterally and symmetrically at the femoral necks, shafts, pubic and ischial rami.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pain in the hip aggravated while squatting with history of regular use of steroid over last six months, flattening of femoral head and presence of subchondral cysts on X-ray are suggestive of AVN of the hip.

choices.text: Give IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre
Oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home
No need of treatment only home remedies

questions.text: A pediatrician at a district hospital encounters an 18-month-old boy from a remote village with breathing difficulties, cough, cold, and fever for the past few days. The child is active, with a respiratory rate of 46 breaths per minute and no chest retractions. How should the pediatrician advise the parents? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home

 

  • Based on the provided clinical information, it is evident that the child is suffering from pneumonia.
  • The recommended treatment for pneumonia in children aged 2 months to 5 years involves administering oral amoxicillin along with home care.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: The quantity of sperms
The motility of sperms
The morphology of sperms
The number of sperm

questions.text: Identify the best parameter to assess in case of male infertility? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The morphology of sperms

 

Explanation:

 

The morphology of sperms is considered the best parameter to assess male infertility. Sperm morphology refers to the size and shape of sperm, and abnormalities in these characteristics can significantly affect a man's fertility.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Sperm Morphology: Characterization of normal sperm morphology shows improved correlation with fertilization rates during IVF cycles. A significantly decreased fertilization rate is observed when the normal morphology of the sample falls below the strict criteria of 4%.
  • Sperm Quantity and Number: While the quantity and number of sperms are important, they are not as critical as morphology in determining fertility potential.
  • Sperm Motility: Motility is also a crucial factor, but morphology has a stronger correlation with fertilization success.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The quantity of sperms: Refers to the total volume of ejaculate, which is less indicative of fertility compared to morphology.

 

Option B. The motility of sperms: Important for fertility but not as strongly correlated with fertilization success as morphology.

 

Option D. The number of sperm: Similar to the quantity, the number is important but does not correlate as closely with fertilization rates as morphology does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sperm morphology is the most significant parameter for assessing male infertility, as it closely correlates with fertilization rates during assisted reproductive techniques like IVF.

questions.text: A 53-year-old postmenopausal lady is detected by endometrial hyperplasia with atypia what is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hysterectomy

 

Explanation:

 

Postmenopausal women with atypical hyperplasia should be offered a total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy due to the very high risk of progression to malignancy. This approach effectively removes the source of hyperplasia and eliminates the potential for malignant transformation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progesterone: High dose Progesterones can be used to manage endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, but this is not the recommended approach for atypical hyperplasia in postmenopausal women.

 

Option C. Mirena: The LNG-IUS (Mirena) can be recommended for those who want to preserve fertility and for managing endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. However, it is not suitable for postmenopausal women with atypical hyperplasia due to the high risk of progression to malignancy.

 

Option D. Dilatation and curettage: This procedure may be used for diagnostic purposes but is not treatment for endometrial hyperplasia with atypia in postmenopausal women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postmenopausal women with atypical endometrial hyperplasia should undergo a total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy due to the high risk of progression to malignancy.

 

Ref: Page no 329, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A child presented with complaints of itching and discharges on flexure aspect of elbow and the lesions were red as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Atopic dermatitis

 

The most likely diagnosis for the case presented is atopic dermatitis, a common inflammatory skin condition often associated with the atopic state, which includes eczema, asthma, and allergic rhinitis. This condition is characterized by impaired epidermal barrier function, often due to a genetic predisposition. In many patients, a mutation in the filaggrin gene is responsible for this barrier defect.

 

Atopic dermatitis typically presents with:

 

  • Eczematous lesions: These lesions are often red, inflamed, and may ooze or become crusted. They frequently occur in flexural areas such as the elbows, knees, and neck.
  • Pruritus (itching): Intense itching is a hallmark of atopic dermatitis, often leading to scratching that can exacerbate the lesions.
  • Chronic course: The condition usually has a chronic course with periods of exacerbation and remission. Lesions often persist for more than 6 weeks.
  • Family history: There is often a personal or family history of atopic conditions, including asthma, allergic rhinitis, or food allergies.
  • Lichenification: Chronic scratching may lead to thickened, leathery skin, known as lichenification.

 

The clinical image provided shows red, excoriated lesions in the flexure aspect of the elbow, which is highly characteristic of atopic dermatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus vulgaris: This is an autoimmune blistering disorder that typically presents with flaccid blisters and erosions on the skin and mucous membranes, not with the eczematous lesions seen in atopic dermatitis.

 

Option B. Psoriasis: Psoriasis typically presents with well-demarcated, thick, silvery scales on extensor surfaces like the elbows and knees. It is not associated with the flexural distribution or the intense pruritus seen in atopic dermatitis.

 

Option C. Post-traumatic pigmentation: This refers to skin discoloration following an injury. It does not present with eczematous lesions or intense itching, and it is not limited to flexural areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atopic dermatitis typically presents with pruritic, eczematous lesions on flexural areas, often associated with a personal or family history of atopy.

choices.text: It cannot be grown in sabouraud dextrose agar

questions.text: A patient with HIV develops diarrhea and faecal examination shows Isospora belli. He was treated with cotrimoxazole. Diarrhoea subsided but fever persisted. Bone marrow examination of this patient is shown in the given image below. Which of the following statement is false? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It cannot be grown in sabouraud dextrose agar

 

Based on the clinical picture, an HIV positive patient had infection with Isospora belli which was treated with cotrimoxazole. The bone marrow examination showed narrow based budding yeast cells suggestive of infection with Histoplasma capsulatum

 

  • Histoplasma capsulatum is a thermally dimorphic fungus which exists as a mycelial form at ambient temperatures and grows as small round budding yeast cells at body temperature in mammals.
  • Growth on Sabouraud dextrose agar at 25ºC shows a white to brown colony, cottony mycelium after 2 to 3 weeks.
  • The mold phase is characterized by thin, branching, septate hyphae that produce microconidia and a very distinct spore called a tuberculate macroconidium.
  • Grown at 37ºC shows the budding yeast form. Yeast cells occur within budding yeasts as intracellular fungi.
  • The yeast cell is 2-4 µm in diameter and slightly oval in shape and found exclusively within macrophages.
  • Mode of infection - Inhalation of spores
  • Disseminated infection can occur in immunocompromised patients with reticuloendothelial system being affected the most.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spores are infective form: Correct. Spores of Histoplasma capsulatum are the infective form. They are inhaled into the lungs, where they convert to yeast form and cause infection.

 

Option C. It is intracellular budding yeast: Correct. Histoplasma capsulatum is an intracellular budding yeast when it infects the host. It is typically found within macrophages.

 

Option D. It can cause systemic disease: Correct. Histoplasma capsulatum can cause systemic disease, especially in immunocompromised individuals, affecting the reticuloendothelial system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histoplasma capsulatum, a thermally dimorphic fungus, can grow on Sabouraud dextrose agar, produce infective spores, exist as an intracellular budding yeast in humans, and cause systemic disease, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

questions.text: A study on postpartum depression in mothers compares depression rates based on the gender of their newborns using the Edinburgh Depression Scale Score (EDSS). Which statistical method should be used to determine if there's a significant association between the newborn's gender and postpartum depression? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Chi square test

 

  • The Chi-square test serves the purpose of comparing qualitative data and involves the comparison of two groups with independent measurements.
  • Therefore, it is the most suitable test for this context

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Students t test: Used for comparing means of two independent groups; not suitable for categorical data.

 

Option B. Paired t test: Used for comparing means of related groups; not suitable for independent categorical data.

 

Option C. ANOVA: Used for comparing means of three or more groups; not suitable for categorical data with only two groups.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to emergency following an episode of syncope during his morning walk. His blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. He has a history of myocardial infarction 5yrs back. His ECG is given below. Which is the most appropriate treatment for patient? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) DC Cardioversion.

 

The given ECG shows wide QRS complex with no P wave suggesting the diagnosis of ventricular tachycardia. Clinical features of exercise intolerance and the presence of ischemic heart disease also support the diagnosis of VT. Since patient hemodynamically unstable, next best step is DC Cardioversion. For stable patients, amiodarone is given intravenously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lignocaine and D. Lidocaine: These are antiarrhythmic drugs used for ventricular arrhythmias but are less appropriate in acute, hemodynamically unstable VT where immediate cardioversion is preferred.

 

Option B. Digoxin: Typically used for heart rate control in atrial fibrillation and not suitable for acute VT, especially in the context of hemodynamic instability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with ventricular tachycardia and signs of hemodynamic instability, DC Cardioversion is the recommended treatment to quickly restore normal heart rhythm. Pharmacological treatments like amiodarone may be considered post-cardioversion for rhythm stabilization in stable patients.

questions.text: In the one-month-old embryo shown below, which of the labeled structures develops into the heart in the adult? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. D

 

Explanation:

 

The above image is of the embryo and the structure which gives rise to the heart in an adult is the heart bulge (Cardiac cushion)- a structure marked as ‘D’.

 

The marked structure in the given diagram are

 

A - Head

B – Primitive lens

C – Pharyngeal arches

D – Heart bulge

E – liver bulge

F – Limb bud

G – Leg Bud

H – Tail

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E (Liver bulge): Does not develop into the heart.

 

Option C. F (Limb bud): Develops into limbs, not cardiac structures.

 

Option D. A (Head): Develops into head structures, not the heart.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Detailed Developmental stages:

 

1. Early Formation:

 

  • In the third week of embryonic development, paired strands of lateral plate mesoderm called the "cardiogenic mesoderm" or "cardiogenic fields" begin to form in the anterior region of the embryonic disc.
  • These strands coalesce in the midline of the embryo to form the "cardiac crescent" or "heart bulge".

 

2. Heart Tube Formation:

 

  • By the beginning of the fourth week, as the embryo undergoes lateral folding, the cardiac crescent fuses in the midline to form a straight heart tube. This tube comprises an outer myocardial layer and an inner endocardial layer with a cardiac jelly in between.

 

3. Differential Growth and Looping:

 

  • Soon after its formation, the heart tube undergoes differential growth which leads it to elongate. This elongation and subsequent bending result in the process called "cardiac looping", where the tube forms a C-shaped loop.
  • The original straight tube's sections become discernible regions: the sinus venosus, atrium, ventricle, bulbus cordis, and truncus arteriosus (from caudal to cranial).

 

4. Partitioning:

 

  • The single atrium and ventricle of the looped heart tube undergo partitioning (septation) to form the four chambers of the mature heart.
  • The atrioventricular canal, initially a single passage between the atrium and ventricle, is also divided.

 

5. Formation of Outflow Tracts:

 

  • The bulbus cordis and truncus arteriosus undergo remodeling to give rise to the roots and initial portions of the aorta and pulmonary artery.

 

6. Incorporation of Sinus Venosus:

 

  • Initially, the sinus venosus, which receives all the embryonic venous return, opens into the right side of the primitive atrium. With time, the right side of the sinus venosus is incorporated into the forming right atrium, giving rise to the smooth part of its interior (sinus venarum).

 

7. Valve Formation:

 

  • Valves form from endocardial cushions in the atrioventricular canal and from additional cushions in the truncus arteriosus and bulbus cordis.

 

8. Maturation:

 

  • By the end of the embryonic period (8th week), the heart looks much like it will at birth, though further growth and maturation will occur during the fetal period.

questions.text: The scraping of a painless genital ulcer, when stained with Gram stain and viewed under the microscope, shows a gram-negative coccobacillus surrounded by neutrophils. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Klebsiella granulomatis

 

The above description of a gram stain showing Gram-negative Coccobacillus surrounded by neutrophils is suggestive of Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium donovani)

 

Granuloma inguinale, or donovanosis, is a sexually transmitted chronic inflammatory disease caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, a minute, encapsulated, Coccobacillus.

 

 

Microscopically, the margin of the ulcer shows epithelial hyperplasia. The ulcer bed shows neutrophilic abscesses. The dermis and subcutaneous tissues are infiltrated by numerous histiocytes containing many bacteria called Donovan bodies, and lymphocytes, plasma cells and neutrophils. These organisms are best demonstrated by silver impregnation techniques.

 

Klebsiella granulomatis is difficult to culture and diagnosis needs visualization of dark-staining Donovan bodies on tissue crush preparation or biopsy. The organisms are demonstrable in Giemsa-stained smears of the exudate as a minute, encapsulated Coccobacilli (Donovan bodies) in macrophages.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chlamydia trachomatis and Option D. Neisseria gonorrhea: Both are gram-negative diplococci, not coccobacilli, making them inconsistent with the gram-negative coccobacillus described in the question.

 

Option B. Hemophilus ducreyi: This bacterium, which causes chancroid, typically presents with a "school of fish" appearance on Gram stain and is associated with painful genital ulcers, not the painless ulcer described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 664

questions.text: A 33-year-old male with attempted poisoning was brought to the casualty in a drowsy state. His pulse was 140/min, respiratory rate -30/min. His ABG showed metabolic acidosis. Urine analysis showed Calcium oxalate crystals. Identify the likely poison?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ethylene glycol

 

The presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine is a key diagnostic sign of ethylene glycol poisoning. Metabolic acidosis and drowsiness is also indicating towards ethylene glycol poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formaldehyde is ruled out because the patient’s symptoms like, metabolic acidosis, and the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine, do not align with the typical effects of formaldehyde poisoning, which usually involves respiratory and mucous membrane irritation.

 

Option C. Paraldehyde While drowsiness and metabolic acidosis can be associated with paraldehyde poisoning, the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine is a characteristic feature of ethylene glycol poisoning.

 

Option D. Methyl alcohol (methanol) While drowsiness and metabolic acidosis can be associated with methyl alcohol poisoning, the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine is a characteristic feature of glycol poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning

 

Ethylene glycol is the major constituent of antifreeze solutions. It is a clear, colorless, odorless, non-volatile liquid with a bitter-sweet taste.

 

Action: Ethylene glycol itself is not toxic, but the toxicity is due to metabolites glycolic and oxalic acids which inhibits oxidative phosphorylation.

 

  • Oxalic acid combines with calcium to form calcium oxalate crystals which accumulates in the proximal convoluted tubules causing renal failure.
  • Metabolic acidosis occurs from glycolic acid.
  • Ingestion of ethylene glycol produces CNS depression which may be accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramps. Metabolites of ethylene glycol produce severe metabolic acidosis and damage to the brain, heart, and kidneys

 

Treatment - Sodium bicarbonate, calcium gluconate, and 4-methyl pyrazole.

questions.text: A primigravida came with 6 cm cervical dilatation and a contraction rate of 3/10 minutes. Which stage of labor is she in? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1st stage

 

Explanation:

 

This patient is in the 1st stage of labor, which is defined as the onset of true labor pain until the full dilation of the cervix. The 1st stage of labor can be further classified as:

 

  • Latent phase: Cervical dilation of less than 5 cm.
  • Active phase: Cervical dilation of 5 cm or more.

 

Earlier, this cutoff for the active phase was considered at 4 cm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2nd stage: The second stage of labor begins with complete cervical dilation and ends with the delivery of the fetus. Since the cervix is not fully dilated (10 cm), the patient is not in the second stage.

 

Option C. 3rd stage: The third stage of labor is characterized by the delivery of the placenta. The patient is not in this stage as the fetus has not yet been delivered.

 

Option D. 4th stage: The fourth stage is a stage of observation for at least an hour after the full expulsion of the placenta. The patient is not in this stage as the delivery process is still ongoing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 1st stage of labor, which involves cervical dilation from the onset of true labor pain until full dilation, is divided into latent and active phases, with the active phase beginning at 5 cm dilation.

 

Ref: Page no 155, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: All of the following about grey rami communicants are true, except: (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Preganglionic

 

Explanation:

 

  • The grey rami communicantes are not preganglionic fibers. They are postganglionic fibers.
  • In contrast, the white rami communicantes carry preganglionic sympathetic fibers from the spinal nerve to the sympathetic chain ganglia. Once in the ganglia, these fibers either synapse with postganglionic neurons, which return via the grey rami to spinal nerves, or ascend or descend to synapse at other levels.
  • The sympathetic trunks on either side of the vertebral columns consist of a series of ganglia. They are connected to the spinal nerves by white and grey rami communicantes. The cell bodies of the preganglionic sympathetic neurons are located in the lateral horn in the spinal grey matter. They leave the cord in the ventral nerve roots to form spinal nerves. These fibers enter the sympathetic trunk in white rami communicantes.
  • They synapse with the postganglionic sympathetic neurons in the sympathetic ganglia. The axons of the postganglionic neurons return to the spinal nerve through the grey rami communicantes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unmyelinated: True. Grey rami communicantes primarily contain unmyelinated postganglionic sympathetic fibers. These fibers are responsible for conveying the postganglionic sympathetic impulses to the spinal nerves, which then distribute these impulses to their target tissues.

 

Option B. Connected to spinal nerve: True. Grey rami communicantes connect the sympathetic chain ganglia to the adjacent spinal nerves. They are responsible for transmitting postganglionic sympathetic fibers to all spinal nerves (regardless of whether or not the spinal nerve level has a white ramus communicans).

 

Option D. Present medial to white rami communicantes: True. Anatomically, when observing the sympathetic chain and its connections to the spinal nerves, the grey rami communicantes are located medially (or more centrally) relative to the white rami communicantes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Grey rami communicantes contain postganglionic, unmyelinated fibers that connect the sympathetic chain ganglia to spinal nerves, facilitating the distribution of sympathetic impulses to the body, contrasting with the preganglionic fibers found in white rami communicantes.

questions.text: A new diagnostic test for dengue is being evaluated using a Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) graph. As the curve transitions from the green region to the pink region, what is the most likely change in the test characteristics? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Both sensitivity and specificity increase

 

As the curve transitions from green to pink, both sensitivity and specificity experience an increase.

 

  • Sensitivity: Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who have the disease (cases)

 

Sensitivity = a/ (a + c) × 100 = TP/ (TP + FN) × 100

 

  • Specificity: Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who do not have the disease (healthy)

 

Specificity = d/ (b + d) × 100 = TN/ (TN + FP) × 100

 

 

 

As the curve transitions from green to pink, it increases the count of true positives and negatives while decreases the occurrences of false positives and negatives. Consequently, this shift results in increased sensitivity and specificity.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • On an ROC graph, a transition from one region to another indicating improved test performance generally means that both sensitivity and specificity are increasing.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with neck swelling as shown. The swelling moves with deglutition and tongue protrusion. What is your diagnosis?  (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thyroglossal cyst

 

Among the given options, thyroglossal cyst is the only neck swelling which is midline, moves with deglutition and tongue protrusion. This is because the thyroid gland is fixed to the hyoid.

 

Thyroglossal cysts are cystic swellings that form from the remnants of the thyroglossal duct, which is a duct that connects the developing thyroid gland to the tongue during embryonic development. These cysts often move with deglutition or tongue protrusion and are typically located in the midline of the neck, as seen in the provided image.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Branchial cyst: Branchial cysts are typically located along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle (upper and middle third) and do not move with deglutition. They are congenital and arise from remnants of branchial arches.

 

 

Option B. Cystic hygroma: Cystic hygromas are usually found in the neck and are also congenital, usually in posterior triangle. They are caused by lymphatic malformation and do not typically move with deglutition.

 

 

Option D. Cervical lymphadenopathy: Cervical lymphadenopathy refers to enlarged lymph nodes in the neck. While lymph nodes can sometimes be palpable in the neck, they do not usually move with deglutition and are not typically cystic in nature.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Other neck swellings that move with deglutition are:

 

  • Thyroid swellings
  • Subhyoid bursitis
  • Dermoid cysts attached to the hyoid bone

 

However, amongst these only the thyroglossal cyst moves with tongue protrusion. This occurs because the duct extends from the foramen caecum of tongue to the isthmus of the gland.

 

Sistrunk's operation is the procedure performed to excise the cyst and prevent a recurrence. It involves excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, along with removal of the body of the hyoid bone, and suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen caecum along with the core of tissue on either side.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used as an intravenous induction agent? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Propofol

 

Explanation:

 

Propofol is a short-acting intravenous anesthetic agent widely used for the induction and maintenance of general anesthesia. It has a rapid onset and produces a smooth and quick recovery, but can cause hypotension and respiratory depression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bupivacaine: Bupivacaine is a local anesthetic. It is not used as an intravenous induction agent for general anesthesia. Instead, it's used for regional anesthesia like epidural or nerve blocks. When administered systemically, it can be toxic, especially to the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.

 

Option C. Dexmedetomidine: Dexmedetomidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist. It provides sedation without causing respiratory depression. Although it is used for sedation in the ICU and for certain procedures, it's not typically used as a primary induction agent for general anesthesia.

 

Option D. Neostigmine: Neostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. It is used to reverse neuromuscular blockade (from non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers) at the end of a surgery. It is not used as an induction agent for anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Propofol is a widely used intravenous induction agent for general anesthesia due to its rapid onset and smooth recovery profile.

questions.text: Defect at the level of the optic chiasma will result in which of the following visual field defects? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bitemporal hemianopia

 

Lesion at the level of the optic chiasma causes bitemporal hemianopia.

 

Nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma. Hence, the lesion at this level produces bitemporal hemianopia.

 

 

Common causes of the central chiasmal lesion are as follows:

 

  • Suprasellar aneurysms
  • Tumors of the pituitary gland
  • Craniopharyngioma
  • Suprasellar meningioma
  • Glioma of the third ventricle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central Scotoma - This refers to a loss of vision in the central visual field and is typically associated with diseases affecting the macula or the optic nerve, not lesions at the chiasm.

 

Option B. Bilateral Hemianopia - This would involve a loss of vision in the same half of the visual field of each eye (either left or right), which generally occurs with lesions affecting the optic tract or occipital lobe, not the chiasm.

 

Option C. Binasal Hemianopia - This visual field defect involves loss of vision in the nasal halves (the sides closest to the nose) of both eyes, which is uncommon and would more likely result from unusual patterns of optic nerve damage rather than a central chiasmal lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bitemporal hemianopia is a classic sign of a lesion at the optic chiasm, often caused by conditions like pituitary tumors or chiasmal compression. This key symptom helps in diagnosing issues that may require urgent intervention to prevent further neurological damage.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient has NYHA class III heart failure, with dyspnea, pedal edema and K+ levels of 5.5mg% and creatinine 1.1 mg%. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Furosemide

 

Furosemide can be used in this patient. All the other drugs mentioned are avoided due to the risk of hyperkalemia.

 

Beta – blockers- interferes with beta 2 mediated intracellular potassium uptake.

 

ACE Inhibitors- inhibition of angiotensin II formation with a decrease in aldosterone secretion.

 

Angiotensin II receptors blockers (ARBS)- block AT1 receptor, decreasing in aldosterone.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Digoxin: Typically avoided if there's a risk of hyperkalemia, as it can be dangerous in elevated potassium levels, potentially causing cardiac arrhythmias.

 

Option B. Spironolactone: Being a potassium-sparing diuretic, it is contraindicated in patients with high serum potassium levels as it could exacerbate hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. Enalapril: As an ACE inhibitor, it can increase potassium levels by reducing aldosterone secretion, thus inappropriate for patients already presenting with hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In heart failure patients with elevated potassium levels, loop diuretics like furosemide are preferred to manage fluid overload and avoid exacerbation of hyperkalemia, unlike potassium-sparing diuretics or ACE inhibitors.

questions.text: Which among the following serves as cofactor for Glycogen phosphorylase? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyridoxal Phosphate

 

Glycogen phosphorylase removes glucose as glucose- 1-phosphate from glycogen (phosphorolysis). It contains pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) as a prosthetic group. The alpha-1, 4 linkages in the glycogen are cleaved.

 

PLP also acts as the coenzyme for many enzymes involved in

 

  • Amino acid metabolism, especially transamination and decarboxylation
  • Heme synthesis
  • Production of niacin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine is a cofactor for enzymes involved in carbohydrate metabolism, such as pyruvate dehydrogenase and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, but it is not a cofactor for glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Option B. Niacin: Niacin is a precursor for NAD and NADP, which are important cofactors in redox reactions, but it does not serve as a cofactor for glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Option D. Biotin: Biotin is a cofactor for carboxylation reactions, such as those catalyzed by pyruvate carboxylase, acetyl-CoA carboxylase, and propionyl-CoA carboxylase, but it is not involved with glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) is the cofactor for glycogen phosphorylase and is also involved in amino acid metabolism, heme synthesis, and niacin production.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with a history of intractable diarrhea. Based on the histological image shown below which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Multiple myeloma

 

The given clinical history with Russel bodies on histology points to the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. The image shows Russell bodies which are eosinophilic, large, homogeneous immunoglobulin-containing inclusions usually found in a plasma cell undergoing excessive synthesis of immunoglobulins. Russell bodies (INTRACYTOPLASMIC) are distended endoplasmic reticulum.

 

Multiple myeloma usually presents as destructive plasma cell tumors (plasmacytomas) involving the axial skeleton.

 

Malignant plasma cells have a perinuclear clearing due to a prominent Golgi apparatus and an eccentrically placed nucleus. Relatively normal appearing plasma cells, plasmablasts with vesicular nuclear chromatin and a prominent single nucleolus, or bizarre, multinucleated cells may predominate.

 

Other cytologic variants stem from the dysregulated synthesis and secretion of Ig, which often leads to intracellular accumulation of intact or partially degraded protein.

 

Such variants include –

 

  • Flame cells with fiery red cytoplasm

 

 

  • Mott cells with multiple grapelike cytoplasmic droplets and cells containing a variety of other inclusions, including fibrils, crystalline rods, and globules.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymphoma: Lymphomas are malignancies of lymphoid cells, and while they can involve plasma cells, the presence of Russell bodies and the clinical history provided is more consistent with multiple myeloma.

 

Option B. Leishmaniasis: Leishmaniasis is a parasitic infection caused by protozoa of the genus Leishmania. It typically does not present with Russell bodies or the plasma cell abnormalities seen in multiple myeloma.

 

Option C. Urate nephropathy: Urate nephropathy involves the deposition of uric acid crystals in the kidneys, leading to kidney damage. This condition does not present with the histological features or clinical history described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Russell bodies in plasma cells, along with a clinical history of intractable diarrhea (suggestive of increased risk of infections due to nonfunctional antibodies), strongly suggests a diagnosis of multiple myeloma, a malignancy characterized by the abnormal proliferation of plasma cells.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease, Page No. 1126

questions.text: Which of the following can alter the gene expression by methylation and acetylation but not change the gene sequence? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epigenetics

 

Epigenetics refers to the study of changes in gene function that are heritable through cell division (mitotic and meiotic) but do not involve alterations in the DNA sequence. Epigenetic modifications can regulate gene expression by altering the accessibility of transcription factors to the DNA.

 

Mechanisms of Epigenetics:

 

  1. Histone Acetylation: The acetylation of specific lysine residues in core histones (H3 and H4) leads to an open chromatin structure, facilitating the access of transcription factors to the DNA and thereby promoting gene transcription.
  2. DNA Methylation: The addition of methyl groups to cytosine residues, particularly at CpG dinucleotides within gene promoters, leads to chromatin condensation and transcriptional repression.

Epigenetic modifications such as methylation and acetylation play crucial roles in regulating gene expression and can influence various biological processes, including development, differentiation, and carcinogenesis, without altering the underlying DNA sequence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mutation: Mutations involve changes in the DNA sequence, such as substitutions, deletions, or insertions, which can affect gene function and expression.

 

Option C. Translocation: This refers to the rearrangement of parts between nonhomologous chromosomes, which involves changes in the DNA sequence and can disrupt gene function.

 

Option D. Inversion: An inversion is a chromosomal rearrangement in which a segment of a chromosome is reversed end to end, involving changes in the DNA sequence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epigenetics involves modifications such as methylation and acetylation that regulate gene expression without changing the DNA sequence, playing a crucial role in various biological processes and diseases.

choices.text: Anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries
Sphenopalatine artery
Greater palatine artery
Septal branch of superior labial artery

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of the external carotid artery in Kiesselbach's plexus?(AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries

 

Anterior and posterior ethmoidal artery are branches of ophthalmic artery which in turn is a branch of internal carotid artery.

 

Arterial supply of the nose:

 

Internal carotid system -

 

  • Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Posterior ethmoidal artery

 

External Carotid System -

 

  • Sphenopalatine artery (branch of maxillary artery) gives nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.
  • Septal branch of greater palatine artery (branch of maxillary artery).
  • Septal branch of superior labial artery (branch of facial artery).

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Sphenopalatine artery: Incorrect because the sphenopalatine artery, which is a branch of the maxillary artery (itself a branch of the external carotid artery), contributes to the arterial supply of Kiesselbach's plexus. It gives rise to the nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.

 

Option C. Greater palatine artery: Incorrect because the septal branch of the greater palatine artery, also a branch of the maxillary artery from the external carotid system, supplies the nasal septum and participates in forming Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

Option D. Septal branch of superior labial artery: Incorrect as this artery, a branch of the facial artery (which stems from the external carotid artery), is part of the blood supply to the Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

 

Educational objective

 

Kiesselbach's plexus -

 

Four arteries anastomose at the anterior inferior part of nasal septum to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

  • Anterior ethmoidal
  • Septal branch of superior labial
  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine
  • Septal branch of greater palatine

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 198

questions.text: What is not a feature of myasthenia gravis among the following? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Absent deep tendon reflexes.

 

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by weakness and fatiguability of skeletal muscles. There is decrease in number of available acetylcholine receptors at neuromuscular junction due to an antibody mediated autoimmune attack.

 

  • Visual problems, including drooping eyelids (ptosis) and double vision (diplopia)
  • Muscle weakness and fatigue may vary rapidly in intensity over days or even hours and worsen as muscles are used (early fatigue)
  • Facial muscle involvement causing a mask-like appearance; a smile may appear more like a snarl
  • Trouble swallowing or pronouncing words
  • Weakness of the neck or limbs
  • Weakness increases during repeated use or late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep.
  • Deep tendon reflexes preserved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscle fatigue: This is a defining symptom of MG, characterized by increased muscle weakness with continued activity.

 

Option C. Normal pupillary reflex: MG primarily affects voluntary muscles and typically does not impact the autonomic functions, including pupillary reflexes which remain normal.

 

Option D. Ptosis: Ptosis, or drooping eyelids, is one of the common features of MG due to muscle weakness affecting the muscles that control eyelid elevation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deep tendon reflexes are preserved in myasthenia gravis despite significant muscle weakness and fatigability, distinguishing it from other neuromuscular disorders that might also lead to reflex abnormalities.

questions.text: Slow waves are generated by: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interstitial cells of Cajal

 

Slow waves appear to be caused by complex interactions among the smooth muscle cells and specialized cells, called the interstitial cells of Cajal, that are believed to act as electrical pacemakers for smooth muscle cells.

 

Interstitial cells of Cajal form a network with each other and are interposed between the smooth muscle layers, with synaptic-like contacts to smooth muscle cells and undergo cyclic changes in membrane potential due to unique ion channels that periodically open and produce inward (pacemaker) currents that may generate slow wave activity.

 

The slow waves mainly excite the appearance of intermittent spike potentials, and the spike potentials in turn actually excite the muscle contraction. The slow waves by themselves do not cause muscle contraction except in the stomach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myenteric neurons: Incorrect. Myenteric neurons are part of the enteric nervous system and play a role in regulating gut motility, but they do not generate slow waves.

 

Option B. Smooth muscle cells: Incorrect. Smooth muscle cells respond to slow waves but do not generate them.

 

Option D. Parasympathetic neurons: Incorrect. Parasympathetic neurons modulate gut activity through the autonomic nervous system but do not generate slow waves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Slow waves in the gastrointestinal tract are generated by the interstitial cells of Cajal, which act as electrical pacemakers for smooth muscle cells.

choices.text: To be done in lateral recumbent position
The bevel should face upwards while inserting the needle.

questions.text: Regarding the procedure done with the needle shown below, which of the following is false? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coagulopathy is not a contraindication.

 

The image depicts a spinal needle used primarily for lumbar puncture (LP), a procedure where cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected from the lumbar cistern. The procedure can be conducted in either the lateral recumbent position or sitting position, depending on the patient's comfort and the physician's preference. The bevel orientation during insertion affects the dural fibers; positioning it parallel (typically upwards) minimizes dural fiber tearing and the subsequent likelihood of post-lumbar puncture headaches. Importantly, coagulopathy is a significant contraindication for lumbar puncture due to the increased risk of spinal hematoma and severe complications associated with bleeding around the spinal cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To be done in lateral recumbent position: This is true and is one of the standard positions for performing an LP.

 

Option B. Breath holding is not necessary: During LP, patients are advised to breathe normally to avoid increases in intra-abdominal and intrathoracic pressure, which could affect CSF dynamics.

 

Option C. The bevel should face upwards while inserting the needle: This is a recommended practice to reduce the risk of post-procedure complications, such as a post-dural puncture headache.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coagulopathy is a contraindication for lumbar puncture due to the risk of bleeding and potential for serious complications, contrary to the incorrect statement provided. Always assess the patient’s coagulation status prior to performing an LP.

questions.text: Nerve fibre least susceptible to local anaesthetic is? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. C fibres

 

Explanation:

 

The nerve fibre least susceptible to local anaesthetic is type C. Local anaesthetics work by blocking sodium channels, which prevents the initiation and propagation of action potentials in nerves. The effectiveness of local anaesthetics depends on the diameter and myelination of the nerve fibres.

 

Type C fibres are unmyelinated and have the smallest diameter, making them the least susceptible to local anaesthetics. This means they require a higher concentration of the anaesthetic to achieve the same level of blockade as larger, myelinated fibres.

 

The order of susceptibility of nerve fibres to local anaesthetics is:

 

B > A-d > A-g > A-b > A-a > C

 

  • Nerve fibres most susceptible to local anesthetic: B fibres

  • Nerve fibres most resistant to local anesthetic: C fibres

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A-delta: These are myelinated fibres with a small diameter, making them more susceptible to local anaesthetics compared to C fibres but less susceptible than larger, myelinated fibres like A-beta and A-alpha.

 

Option B. A-gamma: These are myelinated fibres with a moderate diameter, making them more susceptible to local anaesthetics compared to A-delta fibres but less susceptible than A-beta and A-alpha fibres.

 

Option C. A-beta: These are myelinated fibres with a larger diameter, making them more susceptible to local anaesthetics compared to A-delta and A-gamma fibres.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Type C nerve fibres are the least susceptible to local anaesthetics due to their small diameter and lack of myelination.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 1416-1417

questions.text: Identify the following instrument commonly used in obstetrics? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Episiotomy scissors

 

The instrument shown in the picture is an episiotomy scissors. The angulation in the scissor is designed to prevent the extension of a pelvic tear into the anal margins and to avoid obstetric anal sphincter injuries or complete perineal tears.

 

An episiotomy is not given routinely. Its use should be restricted to specific situations such as:

 

  • Macrosomia: When the baby is larger than average.
  • After coming head of breech: To facilitate the delivery of the head in a breech birth.
  • Instrumental delivery: When tools like forceps or vacuum are used to assist in delivery.
  • Shoulder dystocia: A delivery complication where the baby's shoulders get stuck.
  • Rigid perineum: Often seen in primigravida, where the perineum does not stretch easily.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mayo scissors: General-purpose surgical scissors used for cutting tissues.

 

Option B. Curved scissors: Scissors with a curved blade, used for various surgical procedures but not specifically for episiotomy.

 

Option C. Suture remover: Scissors designed specifically for removing sutures, not for performing an episiotomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Episiotomy scissors are specifically designed to perform an episiotomy, which is a surgical incision made in the perineum to facilitate childbirth and prevent severe perineal tears. Their use is restricted to specific obstetric situations to avoid unnecessary complications.

 

Ref: Page no 755 Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: What is the spinal root value of cremasteric reflex? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. L1, L2

 

Explanation:

 

The cremasteric reflex is mediated through the sensory fibers of the ilioinguinal nerve (L1) and the motor fibers of the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve (L1, L2). When the inner thigh is stroked, sensory impulses travel via the ilioinguinal nerve to the spinal cord segments L1 and L2, and motor impulses from these segments, through the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve, cause the cremaster muscle to contract, pulling the testicles upward.

 

The cremasteric reflex's afferent and efferent branches:

 

  • Afferent - Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve
  • Efferent - Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T8, T9: These thoracic spinal nerve roots primarily innervate the muscles and skin of the thoracic region and contribute to the intercostal nerves. They are not involved in the cremasteric reflex.

 

Option C. L3, L4: These lumbar spinal nerve roots are primarily associated with the front of the thigh and the medial side of the leg and foot. The femoral nerve, which is the largest nerve arising from the lumbar plexus, is derived from these roots. These roots are not directly involved in the cremasteric reflex but are important for the patellar (knee-jerk) reflex.

 

Option D. S1, S2: These sacral spinal nerve roots play a major role in innervating the posterior thigh, most of the leg and foot, and the perineum. They contribute to the sciatic nerve, among others. Reflexes like the ankle jerk (Achilles reflex) involve these nerve roots. They are not associated with the cremasteric reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cremasteric reflex is mediated by L1 and L2. In this reflex, there is ipsilateral elevation of the testicle following stroking of the medial thigh.

 

Other clinical reflexes and their root values: -

 

Achilles reflex – S1, S2

Patellar reflex – L3, L4

Biceps and brachio-radialis reflexes – C5, C6

Triceps reflex – C7, C8

Anal wink reflex – S3, S4

Abdominal reflex – T7 – T12

choices.text: In Africanoids the cusps of molars are wide and deep with shovel shaped cusps in incisors
Upper third molar is most commonly absent in Mongolians
Prominent lingual ridge and labial ridge in mongols

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding teeth and ethnicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. In Africanoids the cusps of molars are wide and deep with shovel shaped cusps in incisors

 

The cusps of molars are wide and deep and cusps of incisors are shovel-shaped is typically seen in Mongoloid races not in Africanoids hence the statement is incorrect. In Africanoids there is presence of large teeth and often have more cusps on their molars, even up to eight, with two lingual cusps on the mandibular first premolars as an additional common finding.

 

Option B), Option C), Option D): these statements are correct as explained in the core concept above. The question is asking for the wrong statement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Key differences between race

choices.text: Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true
Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true
Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false
Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false

questions.text: A researcher is analyzing the results of a study comparing two antihypertensive drugs in an Indian population. She comes across the term "p-value" in her statistical analyses. Which of the following best describes the interpretation of a p-value with regard to the probability related to the null hypothesis? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true

 

  • The p-value represents the likelihood of mistakenly rejecting a true null hypothesis. It serves as the threshold for determining statistical significance.
  • In essence, the p-value signifies the probability of erroneously rejecting a valid null hypothesis, leading to a Type I error.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true: This describes a correct decision where the null hypothesis is true, and the researcher correctly decides not to reject it. This scenario does not involve a p-value interpretation.

 

Option C. Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false: This describes a Type II error, where the null hypothesis is false, but the researcher fails to reject it. The p-value is not directly related to this scenario.

 

Option D. Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false: This describes a correct decision where the null hypothesis is false, and the researcher correctly rejects it. This is the goal of hypothesis testing but not the specific interpretation of a p-value.

 

Null Hypothesis

 

  • Hypothesis (H): Is an assumption about the status of a phenomenon
  • Null Hypothesis (H0): In Biostatistics, when we have to prove a particular hypothesis about difference between 2 regimens, we make Null Hypothesis (For examples, If we have to prove that new treatment is better than older treatment, H0 = new treatment is not better than older treatment).

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient was brought to the casualty with high fever and pain in abdomen. He had a history of bloody diarrhea for several months. There was no past history of long-term medications and previous surgeries. The abdominal X-ray image obtained is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxic megacolon

 

The probable diagnosis is toxic megacolon.

 

Toxic megacolon is a severe condition characterized by acute colonic distension and systemic toxicity. It is often associated with inflammatory bowel disease, such as ulcerative colitis. Patients with toxic megacolon can present with high fever, abdominal pain, and a history of bloody diarrhea, which aligns with the patient's symptoms in this case. The abdominal X-ray shows transverse colonic dilation > 6 cm, which is a characteristic finding in toxic megacolon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Volvulus: Volvulus is a condition in which a portion of the bowel twists on itself, leading to obstruction and ischemia. While it can cause abdominal pain, it typically does not present with the same systemic symptoms seen in toxic megacolon.

 

Option C. Ogilvie syndrome: Ogilvie syndrome, also known as acute colonic pseudo-obstruction, is characterized by marked colonic dilation without a mechanical obstruction. It can cause abdominal pain and distension but does not typically present with a history of bloody diarrhea.

 

Option D. Pneumatosis intestinalis: Pneumatosis intestinalis refers to the presence of gas within the wall of the intestine. While it can be seen on imaging studies, it is not a specific diagnosis and does not explain the patient's symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The X-ray image shows a dilated loop of the transverse colon > 6 cm. The history of bloody diarrhea and loss of haustrations are suggestive of ulcerative colitis. Sudden onset of fever, abdominal pain with dilated loops of bowel in a patient with ulcerative colitis point towards toxic megacolon.

 

A plain abdominal X-ray film can indicate the severity of ulcerative colitis in the acute setting and is especially valuable in demonstrating the development of toxic megacolon. The next step would be to perform a CECT abdomen to assess status of bowel and urgent exploration may be needed if ischemia or perforation is seen.

choices.text: Regular checking of LFT once in 6 months
Follow-up with tumor markers once in 6 months

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman was diagnosed with breast cancer of 1.2 X 1 cm with positive axillary nodes and underwent treatment for the same. She completed radiotherapy and chemotherapy and is now receiving tamoxifen. How will you follow up the patient? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Annual mammogram

 

The most important aspect of breast cancer follow-up is regular surveillance mammograms. Annual mammograms are recommended to monitor for any signs of disease recurrence or new breast cancers. Mammograms are effective in detecting early breast cancer and remain a crucial part of long-term follow-up care for breast cancer survivors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Regular checking of LFT once in 6 months: Regular liver function testing (LFT) is not typically indicated for breast cancer follow-up. While liver metastases can occur in breast cancer, LFT monitoring is usually reserved for patients on certain medications or with specific clinical indications.

 

Option C. Follow-up with tumor markers once in 6 months: While tumor markers like CA 15-3 and CA 27.29 can be useful in some cases for monitoring breast cancer, they are not the primary means of follow-up and are not recommended for routine use as they can have limitations in sensitivity and specificity.

 

Option D. Yearly bone scans: Yearly bone scans are not part of routine breast cancer follow-up unless there is clinical suspicion of bone metastases. Performing bone scans annually would expose the patient to unnecessary radiation and costs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follow-up of patients after treatment of breast cancer consists of routine physical examination once in 3 months for a year and annual mammogram.

 

Mammography is the only imaging modality required for follow-up after breast cancer surgery. Tumor markers, serum investigations, or any other imaging studies like bone scan currently have no role in follow-up.

 

Guidelines for follow-up:

 

Physical examination:

 

  • For the first 2 years: once every 3 to 6 months
  • For 3-5 years: once every 6 to 12 months
  • After 5 years: Annually

 

Mammography:

 

  • Initially, 6 months after surgery
  • Thereafter, annually.

questions.text: A 62-year-old presented with diminished vision 1 year after cataract surgery. The findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) After cataract

 

(SYNONYMS: POSTERIOR CAPSULAR OPACIFICATION/SECOND CATARACT)

 

  • Elschnig's pearls are a type of after cataract, a delayed complication of cataract surgery.
  • They are vacuolated subcapsular epithelial cells, clustered like soap bubbles, along the posterior capsule of the lens.

 

Types of after cataract:

 

  • ﻿﻿Thin membranous after-cataract (thickened posterior capsule)
  • ﻿﻿Dense membranous after-cataract
  • ﻿﻿Soemmering ring: peripheral thick ring of opacity between 2 capsules.
  • ﻿Elschnig's pearls

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Irvine-Gass syndrome:

 

  • Postoperative cystoid macular edema classically described as vitreous touch syndrome.
  • Can occur upto 6 months post cataract surgery.
  • Resolves on its own.
  • Non resolving Irvine Gass syndrome is treated with topical NSAID eye drops, intra and periocular steroid injection and intravitreal Anti-VEGF injection.

 

Option C. Endophthalmitis:

 

  • Caused by an organism of low virulence (Propionibacterium acne or Staphylococcus epidermidis) becoming trapped within the capsular bag
  • Characterized by pain and redness
  • Delayed complication
  • Treatment is removal of entire IOL-Bag complex along with vitrectomy and secondary IOL implantation – either sclera fixation / iris claw IOL / Anterior chamber IOL.

 

Option D. Uveitis-glaucoma-hyphema syndrome:

 

  • Uveitis, Glaucoma, Hyphema occurring simultaneously
  • Seen after anterior chamber intraocular lens (IOL) implantation
  • Also seen when foldable hydrophilic IOL is implanted in ciliary sulcus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior capsular opacification or after cataract is a common post-surgical complication following cataract surgery, characterized by the proliferation of lens epithelial cells leading to opacification of the posterior capsule. This can diminish vision and may require further treatment, typically a simple laser procedure called a YAG capsulotomy to restore clarity to the visual axis.

questions.text: Identify the following? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Giardia lamblia

 

  • The above image shows giardia lamblia.
  • Cysts are resistant forms and are responsible for transmission of giardiasis. Both cysts and trophozoites can be found in the feces (diagnostic stages). The cysts are hardy and can survive several months in cold water.
  • Infection occurs by the ingestion of cysts in contaminated water, food, or by the fecal-oral route (hands or fomites).
  • In the small intestine, excystation releases trophozoites (each cyst produces two trophozoites).
  • Trophozoites multiply by longitudinal binary fission, remaining in the lumen of the proximal small bowel where they can be free or attached to the mucosa by a ventral sucking disk.
  • The cysts are infectious when passed in the stool or shortly afterward, person-to-person transmission is possible.
  • Giardia lamblia exists in:
    • Infective form - Quadrinucleate cyst
    • Tennis racket shaped trophozoite is actively motile with central axostyle with pair of nuclei
    • Oval shaped cyst denoted with cyst wall

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Entamoeba dispar: Morphologically similar to E. histolytica but is non-pathogenic and does not cause invasive disease.

 

Option C. Balantidium coli: The only ciliate known to infect humans, characterized by large size and the presence of cilia.

 

Option D. Entamoeba histolytica: Causes amoebiasis, with cysts and trophozoites distinguishable by their size and internal structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Giardia lamblia in its cyst form, is the infective stage responsible for transmission through contaminated water, food, or fecal-oral route.

questions.text: The following image depicts which of the following diseases? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Scabies

 

Special linear tunnel like lesion called Burrow; is depicted in the image given and it is seen in Scabies. Burrow is the pathognomonic lesion of scabies. Usually, S shaped.

 

Scabies is an ectoparasitic infestation caused by the Sarcoptes scabei var hominis.

 

Itch mite

 

Sarcoptes scabei

 

 

  • The incubation period of scabies typically lasts 3-4 weeks (21-28 days). However, in previously cured individuals, reinfection can lead to immediate symptoms.
  • The most common symptom associated with scabies is nocturnal pruritus, and the itching worsens at night and in warm conditions.
  • Scabies is considered a water-washed disease, meaning it is linked to inadequate personal hygiene and limited access to clean water.
  • Distinctive signs of scabies include intense itching and the presence of shallow burrows.

 

Burrows in scabies are typically found in the stratum corneum as depicted in the below image.

 

 

In most people the trails of the burrowing mites appear brownish linear or s shaped tracks in the skin & occur as a result of excavation of the adult mite in the epidermis.

 

S-shaped track, pointed with black arrows in the below image:

 

 

  • Burrows are absent in animal scabies.
  • Lesions are found in the Circle of Hebra (imaginary line formed by connecting the sites of involvement in scabies like, web spaces, feet, ventral wrists, elbows, cack, breasts, buttocks & external genitals).
  • A single overnight application of 5% permethrin cream from neck to toe in adults & from head to toe in children is the drug of choice for the treatment of scabies in all ages including infants (at least 2 months old & pregnant women.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ichthyosis:

 

  • Ichthyosis is a group of skin disorders characterized by dry, scaly skin.
  • It does not have burrowing mites, hence no burrows are seen.
  • It generally presents with large scales, especially on the lower limbs.

 

Option C. Contact dermatitis:

 

  • This is an allergic or irritant-induced skin inflammation.
  • It manifests as red, itchy, and swollen skin, often with vesicles or blisters.
  • There's no mite involvement or formation of burrows in contact dermatitis.

 

Option D. Urticaria:

 

  • Commonly known as hives, urticaria presents as raised, itchy, red lesions on the skin.
  • It is an allergic reaction and can be triggered by a variety of factors.
  • Urticaria does not involve mites or the creation of burrows in the skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of linear tunnel like lesions called as burrows in the stratum corneum of the skin, as depicted in the image, is a hallmark sign of scabies, distinguishing it from other skin conditions like ichthyosis, contact dermatitis, and urticaria.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 34 page no 34.39-34.47

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page no: 3274

questions.text: Identify the egg in the picture given below: (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ancylostoma duodenale

 

The egg in the given picture is that of a hookworm. Eggs of both Ancylostoma Duodenale (old world hookworm) and Necator Americanus (new world hookworm) are identical.

 

The eggs of hookworm are:

 

  • Oval or elliptical
  • Colorless
  • Not bile stained
  • With a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane
  • Thin shell
  • Segmented ovum - 4 to 8 blastomeres
  • There is clear space between segmented ovum and egg shell
  • Eggs float in saturated salt solution.

 

Humans are infected when filariform larvae in moist soil penetrate the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ascaris lumbricoides: Ascaris lumbricoides eggs are round to oval, thick-shelled, and often bile-stained. They have a rough, mammillated outer layer.

 

Option B. Strongyloides stercoralis: Strongyloides stercoralis eggs are usually not seen in stool samples because they hatch within the intestine. The diagnostic stage is the rhabditiform larva found in the stool.

 

Option C. Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm): Enterobius vermicularis eggs are oval, flattened on one side, and have a thick, colorless shell. They are typically detected using the "Scotch tape" method.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hookworm eggs are oval, colorless, thin-shelled, and contain 4 to 8 blastomeres. These eggs are not bile-stained and have a clear space between the ovum and the eggshell.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in low insulin-glucagon ratio?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glycogen storage

 

A low insulin: glucagon ratio (IGR) stimulates mobilization of stored nutrients, increases glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis, ketogenesis and promotes the breakdown of adipose tissue into free fatty acids and glycerol.

 

Conversely, glycogen storage is not promoted during a low insulin-glucagon ratio. Glycogen storage occurs in a high insulin state, where insulin promotes the uptake and storage of glucose as glycogen in liver and muscle tissues.

 

Other Options :

 

The processes influenced by a low IGR include:

 

Option A. Glycogen Breakdown (Glycogenolysis): The breakdown of glycogen into glucose is stimulated to provide immediate energy.

 

Option B. Ketogenesis: The production of ketone bodies from fatty acids occurs in the liver as an alternative energy source, particularly for the brain during prolonged fasting.

 

Option D. Gluconeogenesis: The synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors such as lactate, glycerol, and amino acids is enhanced to maintain blood glucose levels.

 

Educational Objective :

 

A low insulin-glucagon ratio stimulates the mobilization of energy stores by promoting glycogen breakdown, ketogenesis, and gluconeogenesis, while it inhibits glycogen storage.
