questions.text: An autopsy was performed to find the cause of death of a person brought dead to the casualty. It showed abrasions on the neck, fracture of the thyroid cartilage and contused tissues in the neck. The cause of death is? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Throttling

 

The description of the autopsy findings, including abrasions on the neck, fracture of the thyroid cartilage, and contused tissues in the neck, typically indicates death resulting from external pressure on the neck. Throttling is the act of applying pressure to the neck, often by external force or someone’s hands, which can lead to these specific injuries.

 

Manual strangulation, also known as throttling, is a type of asphyxial death where the perpetrator uses his hand to encircle and compress the front and side of the neck.

 

Autopsy finding

 

External Findings:

 

  • Neck abrasions and bruises, often near the laryngeal prominence and jawline.
  • Signs of asphyxia: cyanosis, facial swelling, Tardieu’s spot, and bleeding from the nose and ears.
  • Finger bruises, usually 1.5–2 cm in size.
  • Extent depends on factors like pressure, assailant’s nails, and victim’s resistance.
  • Thumb marks are more prominent, and multiple abrasions may result from victim’s struggle.

 

Internal Findings:

 

  • Muscle tears.
  • Tongue damage.
  • Inward hyoid bone fracture.
  • Thyroid cartilage fracture.
  • Carotid sheath laceration and carotid artery damage.

 

The given autopsy images are suggestive of throttling as bruises and abrasions on the neck is seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hanging: In the case of hanging, there will be a ligature mark, which is not mentioned in the question.

 

Option C. Strangulation: Strangulation is a very generalized term used to describe deaths due to violent asphyxia. Eg- ligature strangulation, throttling etc. Since Throttling is already given in option B we can consider option C strangulation as ligature strangulation. It cannot be the answer as ligature mark is not seen.

 

Option D. Mugging: In mugging cases, the assailant typically compresses or squeezes the victim’s neck by using the crook of their elbow or knee. While a victim killed by this method may exhibit signs of asphyxia, a neck examination may not reveal any signs of violence because the compression is applied using the soft muscles of the arm or leg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Throttling involves manual strangulation by applying pressure to the neck, causing abrasions, contusions, and fractures in the neck structures.

choices.text: Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain

questions.text: A young boy from high altitude came with fever and weakness and had the following reports - Hemoglobin 17 g%, TLC is 21,000 with neutrophils 25, lymphocytes 30, eosinophils 5, myelocytes and metamyelocytes 40 in peripheral smear. Next step in the investigation should be: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Erythropoietin levels

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia (Hb>16 g/dL). Erythropoietin levels should be determined to differentiate primary from secondary forms.

 

Polycythemia vera (PCV) is characterized by increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets (panmyelosis), but it is the increase in red cells (polycythemia) that is responsible for most of the clinical symptoms. PCV must be differentiated from relative polycythemia resulting from hemoconcentration and other causes of absolute polycythemia. PCV is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase JAK2.

 

In PCV the progenitor cells have markedly decreased requirements for erythropoietin and other hematopoietic growth factors due to constitutive JAK2 signaling. Accordingly, serum erythropoietin levels in PCV are very low, whereas secondary forms of absolute polycythemia have high erythropoietin levels.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Philadelphia chromosome: The Philadelphia chromosome is associated with Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) and would not be the primary investigation in a case where polycythemia is suspected.

 

Option B. JAK mutation: While JAK2 mutations are common in Polycythemia Vera, erythropoietin levels should be assessed first to differentiate between primary and secondary causes. If primary polycythemia is suspected after assessing erythropoietin levels, testing for JAK2 mutations would be the next step.

 

Option D. Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain: This test would be more relevant if there is a need to assess bone marrow fibrosis or other marrow abnormalities, but it is not the first-line investigation in the context of suspected polycythemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected polycythemia, particularly in patients from high-altitude areas, erythropoietin levels should be assessed first to differentiate between primary and secondary causes of polycythemia.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortans pathologic basis of disease, Page No.  1161, 1242

questions.text: A new IT employee is feeling guilty, miserable, and unable to concentrate on his task. His symptoms began three years ago, when he began college. The following is the most likely diagnosis: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dysthymia

 

The patient's symptoms of guilt, misery, and concentration issues lasting three years are indicative of dysthymia (Persistent Depressive Disorder).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Depressive disorder: At least 5 out of 9 symptoms should be present to diagnose depressive disorders which include: sad mood, loss of interest, guilt or worthlessness, lack of energy, poor concentration, increased or decreased appetite, increased or decreased psychomotor activity, increased or decreased sleep, and suicidal thoughts. The patient described above has only two of the above three symptoms. Patients with dysthymia have lesser symptoms and also the social occupational dysfunction is lesser in comparison to depressive disorder.

 

Option C. Adjustment disorder: It is characterized by emotional responses to stressful situations such as financial problems, medical illness, relationship problems etc. The symptoms range from anxiety to depressive symptoms. Symptoms usually last no longer than six months after removal of the stressor

 

Option D. Cyclothymia: It is a milder form of bipolar disorder, in which fluctuations between hypomania and mild depressive symptoms occur, but they are never severe enough to make a diagnosis of mania/hypomania or depression. The above described features do not mention any hypomanic symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Dysthymia is characterized by chronic, less severe depressive symptoms lasting at least two years. Symptoms should not even be severe enough to meet the criteria of mild depressive disorder. (Subsyndromal depression >2 years duration). If the depressive disorder continues for more than 2 years, it is known as chronic depression.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 73.

questions.text: Which of the following is the reason for using phenylbutyrate in urea cycle disorders? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It scavenges nitrogen

 

In urea cycle disorders ammonia cannot be converted to urea, but alternatively can be converted to glutamine and glycine. Ammonia scavengers phenylbutyrate and sodium benzoate react with glutamine and glycine and consequently remove excess of ammonia. Phenylglutamine and hippurate are excreted in urine.

 

Phenylbutyrate is metabolized into phenylacetate, which conjugates with glutamine to form phenylacetylglutamine. Similarly, sodium benzoate conjugates with glycine to form hippurate. Both phenylacetylglutamine and hippurate are excreted in the urine, thereby reducing the levels of ammonia in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It maintains renal output: While phenylbutyrate and sodium benzoate are excreted in the urine, their primary function is not to maintain renal output but to remove excess ammonia.

 

Option C. It maintains energy production: Phenylbutyrate does not directly impact energy production. Its primary role is to help remove excess ammonia from the body.

 

Option D. It activates enzymes: Phenylbutyrate does not activate enzymes. Instead, it works by conjugating with amino acids to facilitate the removal of ammonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phenylbutyrate is used in urea cycle disorders to scavenge nitrogen by reacting with glutamine, converting excess ammonia into phenylacetylglutamine, which is then excreted in the urine.

questions.text: Which of the labeled structures in the given image represents the pelvic diaphragm? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked "A" is the levator ani muscle which is part of the pelvic diaphragm.

 

The levator ani is the principal muscle of the pelvic floor and is composed of three parts: the puborectalis, the pubococcygeus, and the iliococcygeus. It is primarily innervated by the pudendal nerve and the S4 nerve root.

 

 

 

The structure marked in the given image are:

 

A. Levator ani

B. Sphincter ani externus

C. Obturator muscle

D. Perianal fascia

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphincter Ani Externus (External Anal Sphincter): This is a circular muscle that surrounds the anus. It's located below the level of the levator ani. It is innervated by the pudendal nerve, allowing for voluntary control over defecation.

 

Option C. Obturator Muscle: This term often refers to two muscles - obturator externus and obturator internus. They are situated on either side of the obturator membrane in the pelvis. Obturator Externus: Obturator nerve and Obturator Internus: Nerve to obturator internus (a branch of the sacral plexus).

 

Option D. Perianal Fascia: The perianal fascia is not a muscle but is the connective tissue located in the perianal region, around the anus. It's part of the deeper layers of the skin in this region.  It's associated with various potential spaces that can become sites of abscess formation if there's an infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The levator ani muscle is a key component of the pelvic diaphragm, supporting pelvic organs and aiding in fecal continence, illustrating its critical role in both pelvic structure and function.

questions.text: The image below illustrates the insertion of the transversus abdominis muscle. Which of the labeled structures represents the conjoint tendon? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. C

 

The structure marked C is the conjoint tendon.

 

The conjoint tendon is formed from the lower fibres of internal oblique and the lower part of the aponeurosis of transversus abdominis. It is attached to the pubic crest and extends to a variable extent along the pectineal line.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A- Thoracolumbar fascia - This fascia covers the deep muscles of the back and abdomen at the thoracic and lumbar regions.

 

Option B. B- Fibers of transverse abdominis

 

Option D. D- Inguinal ligament - A band running from the pubic tubercle to the anterior superior iliac spine, forming the lower border of the abdomen and serving as a landmark in hernia repairs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transversus Abdominis muscle

 

Origin: Internal surface of 7th -12th costal cartilages, thoracolumbar fascia, iliac crest, connective tissue deep to lateral third of inguinal ligament.

 

Insertion: Linea Alba with aponeurosis of internal oblique, pubic crest, and pecten pubis via the conjoint tendon.

choices.text: Normal distribution, evident outliers, negative skewness, positive skewness
Evident positive skewness, normal distribution, negative skewness, outliers present
Binominal distribution, outliers present, skewed negatively, skewed positively
Standard distribution, outliers present, evident positive skewness, negative skewness

questions.text: A hospital biostatistician analyzes patient wait times over several months to find patterns and outliers for optimizing patient flow. After analyzing four different months, the following box plots are created to illustrate the findings. Based on the given plots, match the correct description? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Normal distribution, evident outliers, negative skewness, positive skewness

 

  1. Plot 1 – Normal distribution
    • The box is roughly centered with whiskers of nearly equal length on both sides and no extreme values. This symmetry and lack of outliers indicate an approximately normal spread of wait times.
  2. Plot 2 – Evident outliers
    • Two data points lie clearly beyond the upper whisker (marked in red). These are outliers, while the central box and whiskers remain fairly symmetric.
  3. Plot 3 – Negative skewness
    • The lower whisker (toward shorter wait times) is substantially longer than the upper whisker, and the median line sits above the box’s center. This shows a left (negative) skew, where a few very short waits pull the lower tail.
  4. Plot 4 – Positive skewness
    • The upper whisker (toward longer wait times) is longer than the lower whisker, and the median is below the box’s center. This pattern reflects a right (positive) skew, due to some unusually long waits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Box and whisker plot 

 

  • Description: A convenient way of graphically depicting groups of numerical data through their quartiles 
  • Edges of box: 1st and 3rd Quartile 
  • Line in Box: 2nd Quartile (Median) 
  • Whiskers end: Minimum & maximum values 
  • Outlier: A data point that is located outside the whiskers of the box plot

questions.text: Mutism and akinesis in a person who is aware of his surroundings and somewhat alert is best described as a feature of: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stupor

 

The described features of mutism and akinesis in someone who remains conscious of their surroundings but may appear unresponsive are indicative of a stuporous state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oneroid state and Option B. Twilight state: It is a dream-like state, in which awareness is restricted, and the patient may feel as if they were in a dream.

 

Option D. Delirium: It is characterized by acute disturbances in attention and consciousness that may be reversible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: Sim’s Symptoms in the Mind, 7th edition, Page No 37, 39, 40, 41.

questions.text: Which is a mood stabilizer with an anti-suicidal role? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lithium

 

Lithium is the only mood stabilizer that has been consistently shown to have an anti-suicidal effect in patients with bipolar disorder and major depressive disorder. Numerous studies have demonstrated that lithium reduces the risk of suicide and suicide attempts. It is considered the gold standard for mood stabilization, particularly in bipolar disorder, due to its efficacy in preventing both manic and depressive episodes.

 

Mechanism of Lithium:

 

  • Mood Stabilization: Lithium modulates neurotransmission by affecting various neurotransmitter pathways, including serotonin and norepinephrine.
  • Neuroprotective Effects: Lithium enhances neurogenesis and has neuroprotective effects, potentially contributing to its anti-suicidal properties.
  • Reduction in Aggression and Impulsivity: Lithium has been shown to reduce aggression and impulsivity, which are risk factors for suicide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carbamazepine: Carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant and mood stabilizer used to treat bipolar disorder, particularly in patients with rapid cycling or mixed states. However, it does not have a proven anti-suicidal effect.

 

Option B. Lamotrigine: Lamotrigine is effective as a mood stabilizer, particularly in preventing depressive episodes in bipolar disorder. While it helps in mood stabilization, it does not have a specific anti-suicidal effect.

 

Option D. Valproate: Valproate is another anticonvulsant and mood stabilizer used in bipolar disorder, especially effective in rapid cyclers. It does not have an established anti-suicidal role.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lithium is unique among mood stabilizers for its anti-suicidal properties. It significantly reduces the risk of suicide and is effective in stabilizing mood in patients with bipolar disorder and major depressive disorder. Valproate is the drug of choice in rapid cyclers, whereas Lamotrigine is effective as a mood stabilizer in Depression.

questions.text: In a middle-aged diabetic patient with chronic kidney disease stage 5, which of the following drugs can be given safely without altering the dose? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Linagliptin

 

The gliptins are DPP4 inhibitors used in the management of type 2 DM. They are eliminated through the kidneys and are therefore contraindicated in patients with CKD. Only Linagliptin can be safely administered in such cases, as it is eliminated through the hepatobiliary system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vildagliptin: Vildagliptin is excreted primarily through the kidneys. In patients with severe renal impairment (CKD stage 5), dose adjustments are necessary to avoid drug accumulation and toxicity.

 

Option C. Saxagliptin: Saxagliptin also undergoes significant renal excretion. Therefore, it requires dose adjustments in patients with severe renal impairment to ensure safe and effective use.

 

Option D. Sitagliptin: Similar to vildagliptin and saxagliptin, sitagliptin is primarily excreted by the kidneys. Dose adjustments are necessary in patients with advanced CKD to avoid the risk of adverse effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Linagliptin can be safely administered to patients with chronic kidney disease stage 5 without the need for dose adjustments due to its unique hepatobiliary excretion pathway, making it the preferred DPP-4 inhibitor in such cases.

questions.text:
A drug was given IV at a rate of 1.6 mg/min. The clearance of the drug is 640 ml/min.

The half-life of the drug is 1.8 hour. Calculate the plasma concentration of the drug?(AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 0.002mg/ml

 

Plasma conc of a drug (C) = Amount of drug being eliminated/Clearance

 

When the amount of drug administered equals the amount of drug eliminated from the body, steady-state plasma concentration is reached.

 

The amount of drug being administered = 1.6 mg/min

 

Clearance = 640ml/min

 

Therefore,

 

Plasma concentration of the drug = 1.6 mg/min / 640 ml/min = 0.0025 mg/ml.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When given the rate of infusion and clearance, the steady-state plasma concentration of a drug can be calculated using the formula:

 

Plasma concentration (C)=Rate of infusion (R)/ Clearance (Cl)

choices.text: Inhibition of M2 receptor
Neuraminidase inhibition
Inhibition of RNA dependent DNA polymerase
Apoptosis of infected cells

questions.text: Mechanism of action of Oseltamivir as an antiviral agent is? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Neuraminidase inhibition

 

Oseltamivir, commonly known by its brand name Tamiflu, is an antiviral medication primarily used to treat and prevent Influenza A and B. Its mechanism of action is as follows:

 

  • Neuraminidase inhibition: Oseltamivir works by inhibiting the viral enzyme neuraminidase. Neuraminidase is crucial for the viral life cycle because it cleaves sialic acid residues on the surface of host cells and on viral proteins, which facilitates the release of new viral particles from infected cells. By inhibiting neuraminidase, Oseltamivir prevents the release and spread of the virus, thus limiting the infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of M2 receptor: This is incorrect. The M2 receptor is targeted by another antiviral drug, Amantadine, which is used against influenza A by inhibiting viral uncoating.

 

Option C. Inhibition of RNA dependent DNA polymerase: This is incorrect. Inhibition of RNA-dependent DNA polymerase is the mechanism of action for antiretroviral drugs like reverse transcriptase inhibitors used in HIV treatment.

 

Option D. Apoptosis of infected cells: This is incorrect. Inducing apoptosis of infected cells is not the mechanism by which Oseltamivir works. It primarily prevents the release of new viral particles rather than directly inducing cell death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oseltamivir is a neuraminidase inhibitor that is used to treat Influenza A and B. Inhibition of viral neuraminidase inhibits the release of viral progeny from the infected host cells.

questions.text: A male patient with a psychotic disorder is receiving antipsychotic, antidepressant, and antihypertensive medication. He developed tachycardia and chest tightness all of a sudden. He was diagnosed with metabolic acidosis. The ECG revealed a widened QRS complex and a prolonged QT interval. Which of the following drugs is the cause of this? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amitriptyline

 

Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA). TCAs are known for their potential to cause significant cardiac toxicity, particularly in overdose situations. The mechanism includes:

 

  • Cardiac Sodium Channel Blockade: This leads to a widened QRS complex on the ECG.
  • Prolongation of QT Interval: TCAs can also block potassium channels, leading to a prolonged QT interval and potentially resulting in Torsades de pointes, a life-threatening arrhythmia.
  • Metabolic Acidosis: TCAs can cause metabolic acidosis due to their effects on the central nervous system and cardiovascular system, which can result in decreased perfusion and tissue hypoxia.

 

Management: In cases of TCA overdose, the treatment of choice is intravenous sodium bicarbonate, which helps to narrow the QRS complex and stabilize the cardiac membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amlodipine: Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker used for hypertension and angina. It does not typically cause a widened QRS complex or a prolonged QT interval and is not associated with metabolic acidosis in overdose situations.

 

Option C. Chlorthalidone: Chlorthalidone is a thiazide-like diuretic used for hypertension. It is not associated with the cardiac effects described (widened QRS, prolonged QT) or metabolic acidosis.

 

Option D. Enalapril: Enalapril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor used for hypertension and heart failure. It does not typically cause a widened QRS complex or prolonged QT interval and is not associated with metabolic acidosis in overdose situations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amitriptyline is a TCA which can lead to widened QRS complex in the ECG along with prolonged QT interval-leading to Torsades de pointes. The antidote used in Amitriptyline toxicity is Sodium Bicarbonate.

choices.text: Ranitidine tablet before start of trip
Dimenhydrinate before start of trip
Scopolamine patch the night before trip
Omeprazole the night before and before starts of trip

questions.text: You and your friend plan for a mountain trip for the day after. What medication would you advise him to help with his motion sickness? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Scopolamine patch the night before trip

 

Scopolamine is an anticholinergic drug that is highly effective for the prevention and treatment of motion sickness. It works by blocking the muscarinic receptors in the central nervous system, which helps prevent the nausea and vomiting associated with motion sickness.

 

  • Transdermal Scopolamine Patch: The patch is typically applied behind the ear at least 4-5 hours before the trip and can provide continuous relief for up to 72 hours. This makes it highly convenient for trips that may last for several days

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ranitidine tablet before start of trip: Ranitidine is a histamine-2 receptor antagonist used to reduce stomach acid production. It is not effective for the prevention of motion sickness.

 

Option B. Dimenhydrinate before start of trip: Dimenhydrinate (Dramamine) is an antihistamine that can be effective for treating motion sickness, but it requires more frequent dosing compared to the scopolamine patch. It is taken orally and must be dosed every 4-6 hours.

 

Option D. Omeprazole the night before and before start of trip: Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor used to reduce stomach acid production and treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). It is not effective for preventing motion sickness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scopolamine, particularly in the form of a transdermal patch, is the drug of choice for the prevention of motion sickness. The patch should be applied the night before the trip to ensure it is effective in preventing the symptoms of motion sickness. Ranitidine and Omeprazole are not effective. Dimenhydrinate is an anti-histaminic drug which is not as effective as scopolamine.

choices.text: Increases urine output
Increases mean arterial blood pressure

questions.text: A patient of septicemia was treated with norepinephrine infusion. Which of the following best parameter is used to monitor the effect of therapy? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Increases mean arterial blood pressure

 

Norepinephrine/ Noradrenaline, is a vasopressor commonly used in the management of septic shock. It works primarily by stimulating α1 and α2 adrenergic receptors, leading to vasoconstriction and an increase in systemic vascular resistance. It also stimulates β1 receptors, which increases cardiac output.

 

  • Increase in Mean Arterial Blood Pressure (MAP): The primary goal of using norepinephrine in septic shock is to improve perfusion by increasing MAP. Monitoring MAP is essential because it provides a direct measure of the pressure needed to ensure adequate blood flow to organs. An increase in MAP indicates improved perfusion and is a key indicator of the efficacy of norepinephrine therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bradycardia: Bradycardia can occur as a reflex response to the increase in blood pressure caused by norepinephrine. However, it is not a primary parameter for monitoring the therapeutic effect of norepinephrine in septic shock.

 

Option B. Tachycardia: Tachycardia is not typically expected with norepinephrine therapy and can be a sign of other issues or a compensatory response. It is not a direct indicator of norepinephrine efficacy.

 

Option C. Increases urine output: While increased urine output is a good sign of improved renal perfusion and overall hemodynamic status, it is a secondary measure. The primary aim is to stabilize the patient's blood pressure, making MAP the more direct parameter to monitor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Noradrenaline acts on the α1, α2 and β1 receptors. It leads to an increase in the SBP, a rise in DBP and therefore a rise in MAP. This helps in improving the perfusion in patients suffering from septic shock. The rise in mean arterial pressure also causes reflex bradycardia but it is not a major contributor to the treatment of septic shock

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with severe hypoglycemia after moderate physical activity. Blood tests reveal elevated levels of ketone bodies, lactic acid, triglycerides, and uric acid. Physical examination shows hepatomegaly and renomegaly. A liver biopsy confirms the presence of excess glycogen deposits in the liver and kidneys. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) von Gierke’s disease

 

von Gierke’s disease (Type I glycogen storage disease) is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase, which is essential for both glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. As a result, glycogen accumulates in the liver and renal tubular cells, leading to hepatomegaly, renomegaly, and severe hypoglycemia after fasting or moderate activity. Additional features include lactic acidosis, hypertriglyceridemia, hyperuricemia, and ketosis. A definitive diagnosis can be made with a liver biopsy, and treatment involves dietary management, including restriction of fructose and galactose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pompe’s disease: Pompe’s disease (Type II glycogen storage disease) involves a deficiency in acid alpha-glucosidase, leading to glycogen accumulation in muscle tissues, including the heart. It does not typically cause the severe hypoglycemia or metabolic abnormalities seen in von Gierke’s disease.

 

Option C. McArdle’s disease: McArdle’s disease (Type V glycogen storage disease) is due to a deficiency in muscle glycogen phosphorylase, primarily affecting muscle function. It typically presents with exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, and myoglobinuria, but liver involvement and hypoglycemia are not prominent features.

 

Option D. Cori’s disease: Cori’s disease (Type III glycogen storage disease) involves a deficiency in the debranching enzyme, leading to the accumulation of abnormal glycogen. It can present with hepatomegaly and mild hypoglycemia, but lactic acidosis and the other metabolic disturbances seen in von Gierke’s disease are less prominent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • von Gierke’s disease is the most common glycogen storage disease, caused by a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase.
  • It presents with severe hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hypertriglyceridemia, and hyperuricemia, with glycogen accumulation in the liver and kidneys.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man donates platelets via apheresis for the first time. During the procedure, he develops paresthesias and circumoral numbness. His vitals remain stable, but his ECG shows tachycardia with ST-T changes. Physical examination reveals a positive Chvostek's sign. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypocalcemia

 

The patient's symptoms of paresthesias, circumoral numbness, and ECG changes (including ST-T changes) are classic signs of hypocalcemia. In this case, the hypocalcemia is induced by citrate, which is used as an anticoagulant during platelet apheresis. Citrate acts as a calcium chelator, binding calcium in the blood and leading to symptoms of hypocalcemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypovolemic shock: This is unlikely as the patient’s vitals are stable, and the symptoms described (paresthesia and ECG changes) are not typical for hypovolemic shock.

 

Option C. Seizures: While hypocalcemia can lead to seizures, this patient has not experienced seizures. The symptoms of paresthesias and ECG changes are more consistent with mild hypocalcemia.

 

Option D. Allergic reaction: The absence of symptoms like rash, pruritus, or bronchospasm makes an allergic reaction unlikely in this scenario. The patient's symptoms are better explained by hypocalcemia due to citrate chelation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypocalcemia during apheresis is caused by citrate, an anticoagulant that chelates calcium in the blood.
  • Typical symptoms of hypocalcemia include paresthesias, circumoral numbness, and ECG changes such as QT prolongation.
  • Treatment involves administering calcium gluconate to address acute, symptomatic hypocalcemia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old traveler returns from an endemic area and develops malaria. The initial symptoms resolve with treatment, but a few months later, the patient presents again with recurrent fever and malaise. Laboratory testing reveals Plasmodium species infection. Relapse in malaria is most commonly seen with which of the following species?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Plasmodium vivax and ovale

 

Relapse in malaria is primarily seen with Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale due to the presence of hypnozoites, which are the dormant forms of the parasite in the liver. These hypnozoites can remain inactive for weeks or months before becoming activated, leading to the release of merozoites and a relapse of clinical symptoms. In contrast, Plasmodium falciparum and Plasmodium malariae do not form hypnozoites and do not cause relapses; instead, these species are associated with recrudescence due to incomplete clearance of the parasite.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plasmodium vivax and falciparum: Plasmodium falciparum does not form hypnozoites, so relapse is not seen with this species.

 

Option B. Plasmodium ovale and falciparum: Similar to the explanation for option A, Plasmodium falciparum does not cause relapse, while Plasmodium ovale can due to hypnozoites.

 

Option D. Plasmodium vivax and malariae: Plasmodium malariae does not cause relapse, although Plasmodium vivax does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Relapse in malaria is caused by Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale due to the formation of hypnozoites, which are dormant forms in the liver that can reactivate later.
  • Plasmodium falciparum and Plasmodium malariae do not form hypnozoites, and thus relapse does not occur with these species, although recrudescence (due to incomplete clearance) may occur.

questions.text: A confirmed case of viral hemorrhagic fever was identified in a hospital in India, with transmission occurring person-to-person. The disease is tick-borne and caused by a Nairovirus species. Which of the following viral hemorrhagic fevers was confirmed in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever

 

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is a severe viral hemorrhagic fever caused by the Nairovirus species. It is zoonotic in origin, with ticks serving as vectors. The disease can be transmitted to humans through tick bites or via person-to-person transmission in healthcare settings, particularly during outbreaks. Cases have been reported in several regions, including India.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ebola: Ebola is another viral hemorrhagic fever, but it is caused by a Filovirus, not a Nairovirus, and is primarily found in sub-Saharan Africa.

 

Option B. Yellow fever: Yellow fever is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes and caused by a Flavivirus. It is endemic to regions of Africa and South America, but not typically seen in India.

 

Option D. Marburg: Marburg virus is also a Filovirus, similar to Ebola, and is primarily found in Africa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is a tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever caused by Nairovirus. It has been reported in India and can spread via person-to-person transmission, particularly in healthcare settings.

choices.text: Repeats a sentence of 10 syllables

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic for a well-child visit. The mother asks about developmental milestones and what skills her child should have at this age. Which of the following milestones would you expect a 3-year-old child to display?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Handling a spoon

 

By the age of 3 years, a child is typically expected to be able to handle a spoon and feed themselves well. This milestone is part of fine motor development and generally emerges by 2 years of age. By 3 years, this skill is well-established.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hopping on one foot: This ability generally develops around 4 years of age.

 

Option C. Copying a triangle: The ability to copy complex shapes, such as a triangle, typically develops around 5 years of age.

 

Option D. Repeats a sentence of 10 syllables: This milestone is also expected around 5 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fine motor milestones development includes the following

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is not formed through post-translational modification?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Selenocysteine

 

Selenocysteine is unique in that it is incorporated into proteins co-translationally, meaning it is added during translation, not as a result of post-translational modification. It is encoded by the UGA codon, which is typically a stop codon, but is recognized as a signal for selenocysteine insertion when the mRNA contains a selenocysteine insertion sequence (SECIS) element. Selenocysteine is a key component of several redox-active enzymes like glutathione peroxidase and thioredoxin reductase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Triiodothyronine (T3): T3 is produced by the deiodination of thyroxine (T4) after translation, making it a post-translational modification.

 

Option C. Hydroxyproline: Hydroxyproline is generated through post-translational hydroxylation of proline, a modification critical for collagen stability.

 

Option D. Hydroxylysine: Hydroxylysine is formed by the post-translational hydroxylation of lysine, another modification important for collagen cross-linking.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Selenocysteine is incorporated during translation, not after, and is essential for the function of enzymes involved in redox reactions.
  • Other amino acids, like hydroxyproline, hydroxylysine, and triiodothyronine, are formed through post-translational modifications.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with ascites and undergoes paracentesis. His serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is ≥1.1 g/dL. Which of the following is least likely to be the cause of his ascites?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tuberculous peritonitis

 

The serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) helps differentiate ascites caused by portal hypertension from non-portal hypertensive causes. A SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL is indicative of ascites due to portal hypertension, which is commonly seen in conditions such as cirrhosis, liver failure, and metastasis to the liver.

 

In contrast, tuberculous (TB) peritonitis is associated with a SAAG <1.1 g/dL, as it is not related to portal hypertension. TB peritonitis often presents with ascitic fluid lymphocytosis and an elevated ascitic adenosine deaminase (ADA) level, which is highly sensitive for the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cirrhosis: Cirrhosis is a common cause of portal hypertension, leading to a high SAAG (≥1.1 g/dL).

 

Option B. Liver failure: Liver failure can also result in portal hypertension and ascites with a high SAAG.

 

Option C. Metastasis to the liver: Metastasis to the liver can cause portal hypertension, resulting in a high SAAG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL indicates ascites due to portal hypertension, commonly seen in conditions like cirrhosis, liver metastasis, and cardiac ascites.
  • A SAAG <1.1 g/dL is seen in conditions unrelated to portal hypertension, such as tuberculous peritonitis, peritoneal carcinomatosis, or pancreatic ascites.

questions.text:
Match the following substances with their commonly associated terms or conditions:

 

Column A

 

  1. Cocaine
  2. LSD
  3. Abrus precatorius
  4. Capsaicin

 

Column B

 

  1. Hunan hand
  2. White lady
  3. Purple wedge
  4. Gunji
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1=b, 2=c, 3=d, 4=a

 

  1. Cocaine has various street names, with some common ones including White lady, Coke, Crack, and Snow. These are informal terms used in illicit drug markets for this powerful stimulant.
  2. LSD (Lysergic acid diethylamide) also goes by many street names, including Purple wedge, acid, orange wedges, and white lightning. These terms refer to different forms and variations of the drug.
  3. Abrus precatorius, commonly known as Jequirity bean or Rosary pea, is often referred to by the names Gunji or Gunchi. The seeds of this plant are toxic but are sometimes used in traditional jewelry, such as prayer beads.
  4. Capsaicin, the active ingredient in chili peppers, can cause a condition known as Hunan hand, which involves burning and irritation of the skin, especially in workers handling large quantities of chili-based products like paste or powder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cocaine has various street names, including White lady, Coke, and Snow.
  • LSD is known by names like Purple wedge and Acid.
  • Abrus precatorius (Jequirity bean) is associated with the term Gunji.
  • Capsaicin exposure can cause Hunan hand, especially in workers handling chili peppers.

questions.text: A school bus carrying children was involved in a major accident. You are the physician responsible for triage at the scene. Which of the following should be your first priority in managing the patients?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Airway obstruction

 

In triage, the immediate goal is to prioritize treatment based on which injuries pose the greatest threat to life. The airway is always prioritized first because airway compromise can lead to death within minutes if not addressed. This is part of the ABC (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) approach in trauma care, which ensures that the most critical, rapidly fatal conditions are addressed first.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Grade 4 shock: While shock is a critical condition, it is addressed after airway and breathing concerns in the triage hierarchy.

 

Option C. Flail chest: Flail chest can severely impact breathing but managing the airway takes precedence before addressing other respiratory or circulatory problems.

 

Option D. Severe head injury: Although head injuries are serious, airway management comes first, as brain function relies on adequate oxygenation.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The talocalcaneonavicular joint is classified as which type of joint?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ball and Socket

 

The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ball and socket joint. The ball is formed by the rounded head of the talus, while the socket is made up of the following structures:

 

  • The posterior surface of the navicular bone,
  • The anterior articular surface of the calcaneus, and
  • The upper surface of the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament (also known as the spring ligament).

 

This joint allows for a wide range of movement, particularly important for foot mobility and stability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Saddle type: This type of joint is found in areas like the thumb's carpometacarpal joint.

 

Option C. Plane: Plane joints, such as the intertarsal joints, allow for gliding movements.

 

Option D. Ellipsoid: Ellipsoid joints, such as the radiocarpal joint in the wrist, allow for movement in two planes.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient undergoing anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) develops tingling and numbness in the limbs. Which of the following should be supplemented to improve the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pyridoxine

 

The development of tingling or numbness in a patient receiving isoniazid (INH) as part of anti-tubercular therapy is indicative of INH-induced peripheral neuropathy. This neuropathy occurs because INH depletes pyridoxine (vitamin B6) levels, which are necessary for normal nerve function. Supplementing with pyridoxine (100 mg/day) typically resolves the symptoms.

 

Certain populations, such as alcoholics, malnourished individuals, pregnant and lactating women, and patients with diabetes, HIV, or chronic renal failure, are at higher risk of developing peripheral neuropathy. Pyridoxine supplementation is also recommended in children and adults on isoniazid preventive therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency is associated with conditions like beriberi and Wernicke's encephalopathy, not peripheral neuropathy related to isoniazid.

 

Option C. Folic acid: Folic acid is important in managing certain types of anemia but is not relevant to isoniazid-induced peripheral neuropathy.

 

Option D. Methylcobalamin: Methylcobalamin (vitamin B12) is important in managing B12 deficiency-related neuropathy but is not the treatment for INH-induced neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) should be supplemented in patients on isoniazid to prevent or treat peripheral neuropathy. This supplementation is especially important in high-risk individuals, such as those who are malnourished, pregnant, or have other underlying conditions like HIV or diabetes.

questions.text: A newborn presents with hypotonia and seizures. After further evaluation, the child is diagnosed with Zellweger syndrome. Which of the following accumulates in the brain in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Long-chain fatty acids

 

Zellweger syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a deficiency in functional peroxisomes. These organelles are critical for breaking down very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs). The absence or reduction of peroxisomes leads to the accumulation of VLCFAs in the brain, which contributes to the neurological symptoms such as hypotonia and seizures. Other systemic features include hepatomegaly, renal cysts, and severe developmental delays. Most affected patients have a poor prognosis and die within the first year of life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose: Although glucose metabolism is crucial for brain function, glucose accumulation is not characteristic of Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option B. Lactic acid: Lactic acid can accumulate in mitochondrial disorders but is not related to Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option D. Triglycerides: Triglyceride accumulation is more associated with disorders of lipid metabolism like hyperlipidemia, not Zellweger syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zellweger syndrome is a peroxisomal disorder that results in the accumulation of very long-chain fatty acids in the brain, leading to severe neurological dysfunction, developmental delays, and a high mortality rate.
